  have h1 : {x : ‚Ñï | x > 0 ‚àß 120 % x = 0 ‚àß 40 % x = 0} = {1, 2, 4, 5, 8, 10, 20, 40} := by
    ext n 
    simp only [Set.mem_setOf_eq, Set.mem_insert_iff, Set.mem_singleton_iff, and_imp]
    constructor
    ¬∑ -- Assume n is in the set
      intro h 
      rcases h with ‚ü®hn_pos, hn_120, hn_40‚ü©
      have h1 : n ‚â§ 40 := by 
        by_contra h
        push_neg at h 
        have h4 : 40 % n = 40 := by 
          rw [Nat.mod_eq_of_lt] 
          all_goals linarith 
        omega 
      interval_cases n <;> norm_num at *
    ¬∑ -- Assume n is in the explicit set
      rintro (rfl | rfl | rfl | rfl | rfl | rfl | rfl | rfl)
      ¬∑ -- n = 1
        exact ‚ü®by norm_num, by norm_num, by norm_num‚ü©
      ¬∑ -- n = 2
        exact ‚ü®by norm_num, by norm_num, by norm_num‚ü©
      ¬∑ -- n = 4
        exact ‚ü®by norm_num, by norm_num, by norm_num‚ü©
      ¬∑ -- n = 5
        exact ‚ü®by norm_num, by norm_num, by norm_num‚ü©
      ¬∑ -- n = 8
        exact ‚ü®by norm_num, by norm_num, by norm_num‚ü©
      ¬∑ -- n = 10
        exact ‚ü®by norm_num, by norm_num, by norm_num‚ü©
      ¬∑ -- n = 20
        exact ‚ü®by norm_num, by norm_num, by norm_num‚ü©
      ¬∑ -- n = 40
        exact ‚ü®by norm_num, by norm_num, by norm_num‚ü©
  rw [h1]
  rw [Set.encard]
  simp [Set.ncard_insert_of_not_mem, Set.ncard_singleton]

soln_description:
I. Solution. If $f(x)$ denotes the polynomial on the left side of (1), then for any $\alpha \neq 0$, $f(x)=\alpha^{6} \cdot f\left(\frac{1}{\alpha}\right)$, since the coefficients of $f$ are "symmetrically" arranged. Since (1) clearly does not have zero as a root, for every root of $f$, its reciprocal is also a root. The six distinct roots can thus be written as: $\alpha, \beta, \gamma, 1 / \alpha, 1 / \beta, 1 / \gamma$. Accordingly, the factorized form of $f$ is:

$$
f(x)=(x-\alpha)(x-\beta)(x-\gamma)\left(x-\frac{1}{\alpha}\right)\left(x-\frac{1}{\beta}\right)\left(x-\frac{1}{\gamma}\right)
$$

Let's calculate the coefficient of the cubic term in the product on the right! The $x^{3}$ term is obtained from the expansion of the product by taking the first term from 3 parentheses and the second term from the other 3. This can be done in $\binom{6}{3}=20$ ways. The selections can be paired reciprocally, like the first and the last 3 parentheses:

$$
-\alpha \beta \gamma \quad \text { and } \quad-\frac{1}{\alpha \beta \gamma}
$$

The other 9 pairs have 2+1, or 1+2 factors from the first and second halves of $f(x)$, respectively, and the first terms of the pairs can be constructed according to the small table below.

|  | $1 / \alpha$ | $1 / \beta$ | $1 / \gamma$ |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| $\alpha \beta$ | $\beta$ | $\alpha$ | $\alpha \beta / \gamma$ |
| $\alpha \gamma$ | $\gamma$ | $\alpha \gamma / \beta$ | $\alpha$ |
| $\beta \gamma$ | $\beta \gamma / \alpha$ | $\gamma$ | $\beta$ |

From here, $c=c_{1}+c_{2}$, where

$$
c_{1}=-\left(\alpha \beta \gamma+2 \alpha+2 \beta+2 \gamma+\frac{\beta \gamma}{\alpha}+\frac{\gamma \alpha}{\beta}+\frac{\alpha \beta}{\gamma}\right)
$$

and

$$
c_{2}=-\left(\frac{1}{\alpha \beta \gamma}+\frac{2}{\alpha}+\frac{2}{\beta}+\frac{2}{\gamma}+\frac{\alpha}{\beta \gamma}+\frac{\beta}{\gamma \alpha}+\frac{\gamma}{\alpha \beta}\right)
$$

By factoring out $-\alpha \beta \gamma$ from $c_{1}+c_{2}$, we get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
c= & -\alpha \beta \gamma\left(1+\frac{1}{\alpha^{2} \beta^{2} \gamma^{2}}+\frac{1}{\alpha^{2}}+\frac{1}{\beta^{2}}+\frac{1}{\gamma^{2}}+\frac{2}{\beta \gamma}+\frac{2}{\alpha \gamma}+\frac{2}{\alpha \beta}+\right. \\
& \left.+\frac{1}{\beta^{2} \gamma^{2}}+\frac{1}{\alpha^{2} \gamma^{2}}+\frac{1}{\alpha^{2} \beta^{2}}+\frac{2}{\alpha^{2} \beta \gamma}+\frac{2}{\alpha \beta^{2} \gamma}+\frac{2}{\alpha \beta \gamma^{2}}\right)= \\
=- & \alpha \beta \gamma\left(1+\frac{1}{\alpha^{2} \beta^{2} \gamma^{2}}+\left(\frac{1}{\alpha}+\frac{1}{\beta}+\frac{1}{\gamma}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{1}{\alpha \beta}+\frac{1}{\beta \gamma}+\frac{1}{\gamma \alpha}\right)^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus,

$$
|c|=|\alpha \beta \gamma|\left|\left(1+\frac{1}{\alpha^{2} \beta^{2} \gamma^{2}}+\left(\frac{1}{\alpha}+\frac{1}{\beta}+\frac{1}{\gamma}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{1}{\alpha \beta}+\frac{1}{\beta \gamma}+\frac{1}{\gamma \alpha}\right)^{2}\right)\right|
$$

and if we omit the squares of the trinomials from the second factor, we get:

$$
|c|>|\alpha \beta \gamma| \cdot\left|1+\frac{1}{\alpha^{2} \beta^{2} \gamma^{2}}\right|=\left|\alpha \beta \gamma+\frac{1}{\alpha \beta \gamma}\right|
$$

(In the last step, we used the fact that $\alpha \beta \gamma$ and $\frac{1}{\alpha \beta \gamma}$ have the same sign.)

We have thus obtained that

$$
|c|>\left|\alpha \beta \gamma+\frac{1}{\alpha \beta \gamma}\right|
$$

Using the fact that for any real number $t$, $\left|t+\frac{1}{t}\right| \geqq 2$, we get the statement to be proven in a sharper form, that equality cannot hold.

II. Solution. Let's start again from the factorized form under (2). Multiplying the first three factors, we get:

$$
(x-\alpha)(x-\beta)(x-\gamma)=x^{3}-p x^{2}+q x-r
$$

where

$$
p=\alpha+\beta+\gamma, \quad q=\alpha \beta+\beta \gamma+\gamma \alpha \quad \text { and } \quad r=\alpha \beta \gamma \text {. }
$$

Similarly, for the product of the second three factors, we get $x^{3}--P x^{2}+Q x+R$, where

$$
P=\frac{1}{\alpha}+\frac{1}{\beta}+\frac{1}{\gamma}, \quad Q=\frac{1}{\alpha \beta}+\frac{1}{\beta \gamma}+\frac{1}{\gamma \alpha} \quad \text { and } \quad R=\frac{1}{\alpha \beta \gamma}
$$

Notice that

$$
P=\frac{q}{r}, \quad Q=\frac{p}{r} \quad \text { and } \quad R=\frac{1}{r}
$$

so

$$
\left(x-\frac{1}{\alpha}\right)\left(x-\frac{1}{\beta}\right)\left(x-\frac{1}{\gamma}\right)=x^{3}-\frac{q}{r} x^{2}+\frac{p}{r} x-\frac{1}{r}=\frac{1}{r}\left(r x^{3}-q x^{2}+p x-1\right)
$$

Thus, $f(x)=\frac{1}{r}\left(x^{3}-p x^{2}+q x-r\right)\left(r x^{3}-q x^{2}+p x-1\right)$. For the coefficient of the cubic term, we get:

$$
c=-\frac{1}{r}\left(p^{2}+q^{2}+r^{2}+1\right)
$$

Accordingly, $|c|=\frac{1}{|r|}\left(p^{2}+q^{2}+r^{2}+1\right) \geqq \frac{1}{|r|}\left(r^{2}+1\right)=|r|+\frac{1}{|r|} \geqq 2$, as stated.

Remarks. 1. The second solution can be generalized. It can be easily shown that if

$$
\left(x-\alpha_{1}\right)\left(x-\alpha_{2}\right) \ldots\left(x-\alpha_{n}\right)=x^{n}+a_{n-1} x^{n-1}+\ldots+a_{1} x+a_{0}
$$

then

$$
\left(x-\frac{1}{\alpha_{1}}\right)\left(x-\frac{1}{\alpha_{2}}\right) \ldots\left(x-\frac{1}{\alpha_{n}}\right)=\frac{1}{a_{0}}\left(a_{0} x^{n}+a_{1} x^{n-1}+\ldots+a_{n-1} x+1\right)
$$

and the coefficient of the $n$-th degree term in the product of the two polynomials is $\frac{1}{a_{0}}\left(a_{0}^{2}+a_{1}^{2}+\ldots+a_{n+1}^{2}+1\right)$. Since the absolute value of this number is at least $2$, if a polynomial of degree $2n$ has a leading coefficient of 1, $2n$ roots, and the reciprocal of every root is also a root, then the absolute value of the coefficient of the $n$-th degree term is at least 2.

On the other hand, the "symmetric"

$$
x^{2 n}+b_{1} x^{2 n-1}+b_{2} x^{2 n-2}+\ldots+b_{n} x^{n}+b_{n-1} x^{n-1}+\ldots+b_{1} x+1=0
$$

polynomial, as seen in the first solution, has the above property for its roots, so $\left|b_{n}\right| \geqq 2$.

2. Under the given conditions, $c>4$ is also true in (1), but this result cannot be sharpened further.
informal_statement:
Given the equation $x^{6}+a x^{5}+b x^{4}+c x^{3}+b x^{2}+a x+1=0$ has six distinct real roots. Prove that $|c| \geq 2$.

---

The equation $x^{6}+a x^{5}+b x^{4}+c x^{3}+b x^{2}+a x+1=0$ has six distinct real roots. We need to prove that $|c| \geq 2$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Given the equation $x^{6}+a x^{5}+b x^{4}+c x^{3}+b x^{2}+a x+1=0$ has six distinct real roots. Prove that $|c| \geq 2$.

---

The equation $x^{6}+a x^{5}+b x^{4}+c x^{3}+b x^{2}+a x+1=0$ has six distinct real roots. We need to prove that $|c| \geq 2$.
 -/
theorem algebra_201261 (a b c : ‚Ñù) (h : {x : ‚Ñù | x^6 + a*x^5 + b*x^4 + c*x^3 + b*x^2 + a*x + 1 = 0}.ncard = 6) :
    |c| ‚â• 2 := by

informal_statement: If $a,b,c,d$ are positive real numbers such that $a,b,c,d$ form an increasing arithmetic sequence and $a,b,d$ form a geometric sequence, then find the value of $\dfrac{a}{d}.$
informal_proof:
Let the four positive real numbers be $a, b, c, d$.

We are given that $a, b, c, d$ form an increasing arithmetic sequence. Let the common difference of this sequence be $k$. Since the sequence is increasing, the common difference must be positive, so $k > 0$. The terms of the sequence can be expressed in terms of $a$ and $k$:
- $b = a + k$
- $c = b + k = (a + k) + k = a + 2k$
- $d = c + k = (a + 2k) + k = a + 3k$

We are also given that $a, b, d$ form a geometric sequence. By the definition of a geometric sequence, the ratio of any term to its preceding term is constant. Therefore, we have:
$$ \frac{b}{a} = \frac{d}{b} $$
Cross-multiplying gives the relation:
$$ b^2 = ad $$
Now, we substitute the expressions for $b$ and $d$ from the arithmetic sequence into this equation:
$$ (a + k)^2 = a(a + 3k) $$
Expanding both sides of the equation, we obtain:
$$ a^2 + 2ak + k^2 = a^2 + 3ak $$
By subtracting $a^2 + 2ak$ from both sides, we simplify the equation to:
$$ k^2 = ak $$
This can be rearranged into $k^2 - ak = 0$, which factors as:
$$ k(k - a) = 0 $$
This equation implies that either $k = 0$ or $k = a$.

We analyze these two possibilities for the common difference $k$:
1.  If $k = 0$, the arithmetic sequence would be $a, a, a, a$. This is a constant sequence, not an increasing one, which contradicts the problem's condition. Thus, we discard this solution.
2.  If $k = a$, since we are given that $a > 0$, the common difference $k$ is positive. This is consistent with the condition that the sequence is increasing.

Therefore, the only valid solution is $k = a$. We can now find the value of $d$ in terms of $a$:
$$ d = a + 3k = a + 3a = 4a $$
Finally, we compute the ratio $\frac{a}{d}$:
$$ \frac{a}{d} = \frac{a}{4a} $$
Since $a$ is a positive number, we can cancel $a$ from the numerator and the denominator, yielding:
$$ \frac{a}{d} = \frac{1}{4} $$
This completes the proof.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- If $a,b,c,d$ are positive real numbers such that $a,b,c,d$ form an increasing arithmetic sequence and $a,b,d$ form a geometric sequence, then find the value of $\dfrac{a}{d}.$ -/
theorem algebra_20361 (a b c d : ‚Ñù) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c) (hd : 0 < d)
    (hseq : ‚àÉ d, b = a + d ‚àß c = b + d ‚àß d = c + d)
    (hge : ‚àÉ r, b = a * r ‚àß d = b * r) :
    a / d = 1 / 4 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

/- If $a,b,c,d$ are positive real numbers such that $a,b,c,d$ form an increasing arithmetic sequence and $a,b,d$ form a geometric sequence, then find the value of $\dfrac{a}{d}.$ -/
theorem algebra_20361 (a b c d : ‚Ñù) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c) (hd : 0 < d)
    (hseq : ‚àÉ d, b = a + d ‚àß c = b + d ‚àß d = c + d)
    (hge : ‚àÉ r, b = a * r ‚àß d = b * r) :
    a / d = 1 / 4 := by
  cases' hseq with d h
  cases' hge with r h
  nlinarith

soln_description:
The difference standing in the middle, its first term is called the quadratic mean of $a$ and $b$, and the second term is called the geometric mean of $a$ and $b$. We denote them by $Q$ and $M$ respectively:

$$
Q=\sqrt{\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}}{2}}, \quad M=\sqrt{a b}
$$

These are also positive, and

$$
\begin{aligned}
& (a+b)^{2}=a^{2}+b^{2}+2 a b=2\left(Q^{2}+M^{2}\right) \\
& (a-b)^{2}=a^{2}+b^{2}-2 a b=2\left(Q^{2}-M^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Due to the latter relationship, the quadratic and geometric means of two positive numbers are only equal if the numbers themselves are equal; otherwise, the quadratic mean is the larger of the two. Thus, when $a=b$, every term in (1) is equal to 0. We will show that otherwise, the inequality sign is valid in both places.

Substitute the quantities $Q, M$ into the inequality to be proven.

$$
\frac{Q^{2}-M^{2}}{\sqrt{2\left(Q^{2}+M^{2}\right)}}<M<\frac{Q^{2}-M^{2}}{\sqrt{2\left(Q^{2}+M^{2}\right)}}M$, if we divide every term by $(Q-M)$ and then multiply by $\sqrt{Q^{2}+M^{2}}$, the direction of the inequality does not change.

$$
\frac{Q+M}{\sqrt{2}}<\sqrt{Q^{2}+M^{2}}<(Q+M) \sqrt{2}
$$

Since $Q$ and $M$ are positive, we can also take the squares of these terms.

$$
\frac{Q^{2}+2 Q M+M^{2}}{2}<Q^{2}+M^{2}<2\left(Q^{2}+M^{2}+2 Q M\right)
$$

The difference between the first two terms is $\frac{1}{2}(Q-M)^{2}$, which is indeed positive. The difference between the second two terms is even the positive $2 Q M$ without the factor of two. Thus, we have proven the inequality

$$
\frac{(a-b)^{2}}{2(a+b)} \leq \sqrt{\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}}{2}}-\sqrt{a b} \leq \frac{(a-b)}{\sqrt{2}(a+b)}
$$

which states more than the problem's assertion.

Remark. If we divide the first inequality in (2) by $\sqrt{2}$, we get the inequality

$$
\frac{Q+M}{2}<\sqrt{\frac{Q^{2}+M^{2}}{2}}
$$

According to this, the arithmetic mean of different positive numbers is smaller than their quadratic mean. The inequality to be proven can also be proven using just this fact.
informal_statement:
To be proven, if $a$ and $b$ are positive numbers, then

$$
\frac{(a-b)^{2}}{2(a+b)} \leq \sqrt{\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}}{2}}-\sqrt{a b} \leq \frac{(a-b)^{2}}{a+b}
$$
informal_proof:
Let $a$ and $b$ be positive real numbers. We want to prove the double inequality:
$$ \frac{(a-b)^{2}}{2(a+b)} \leq \sqrt{\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}}{2}}-\sqrt{a b} \leq \frac{(a-b)^{2}}{a+b} $$
We will prove the two inequalities separately.

First, let's establish some basic properties. Since $a > 0$ and $b > 0$, it follows that $a+b > 0$, $ab > 0$, and $a^2+b^2 > 0$. This ensures that all denominators are non-zero and all expressions under square roots are non-negative.

Next, we show that the middle term is non-negative. Consider the inequality $(a-b)^2 \ge 0$, which is true for all real numbers $a, b$. Expanding this gives $a^2 - 2ab + b^2 \ge 0$, which can be rearranged to $a^2+b^2 \ge 2ab$. Dividing by 2, we get $\frac{a^2+b^2}{2} \ge ab$. Since the square root function is non-decreasing for non-negative inputs, we can take the square root of both sides to obtain $\sqrt{\frac{a^2+b^2}{2}} \ge \sqrt{ab}$. Therefore, the middle term $\sqrt{\frac{a^2+b^2}{2}} - \sqrt{ab}$ is indeed non-negative.

**Part 1: The Left Inequality**

We need to prove that $\frac{(a-b)^2}{2(a+b)} \le \sqrt{\frac{a^2+b^2}{2}} - \sqrt{ab}$.

Let's simplify the right-hand side by rationalizing the numerator:
$$ \sqrt{\frac{a^2+b^2}{2}} - \sqrt{ab} = \left(\sqrt{\frac{a^2+b^2}{2}} - \sqrt{ab}\right) \frac{\sqrt{\frac{a^2+b^2}{2}} + \sqrt{ab}}{\sqrt{\frac{a^2+b^2}{2}} + \sqrt{ab}} = \frac{\frac{a^2+b^2}{2} - ab}{\sqrt{\frac{a^2+b^2}{2}} + \sqrt{ab}} = \frac{a^2+b^2-2ab}{2\left(\sqrt{\frac{a^2+b^2}{2}} + \sqrt{ab}\right)} = \frac{(a-b)^2}{2\left(\sqrt{\frac{a^2+b^2}{2}} + \sqrt{ab}\right)} $$
So, our inequality becomes:
$$ \frac{(a-b)^2}{2(a+b)} \le \frac{(a-b)^2}{2\left(\sqrt{\frac{a^2+b^2}{2}} + \sqrt{ab}\right)} $$
If $a=b$, both sides are 0 and the inequality holds. If $a \ne b$, then $(a-b)^2 > 0$, and we can divide both sides by $\frac{(a-b)^2}{2}$, which yields:
$$ \frac{1}{a+b} \le \frac{1}{\sqrt{\frac{a^2+b^2}{2}} + \sqrt{ab}} $$
Since both denominators are positive, this is equivalent to:
$$ \sqrt{\frac{a^2+b^2}{2}} + \sqrt{ab} \le a+b $$
As both sides of this inequality are positive, we can square them:
$$ \left(\sqrt{\frac{a^2+b^2}{2}} + \sqrt{ab}\right)^2 \le (a+b)^2 $$
$$ \frac{a^2+b^2}{2} + ab + 2\sqrt{\frac{a^2+b^2}{2} \cdot ab} \le a^2+2ab+b^2 $$
$$ \frac{a^2+b^2+2ab}{2} + \sqrt{2ab(a^2+b^2)} \le a^2+2ab+b^2 $$
$$ \frac{(a+b)^2}{2} + \sqrt{2ab(a^2+b^2)} \le (a+b)^2 $$
$$ \sqrt{2ab(a^2+b^2)} \le \frac{(a+b)^2}{2} $$
Squaring both sides again (which are non-negative):
$$ 2ab(a^2+b^2) \le \frac{(a+b)^4}{4} $$
$$ 8ab(a^2+b^2) \le (a^2+2ab+b^2)^2 $$
$$ 8a^3b + 8ab^3 \le a^4 + 4a^2b^2 + b^4 + 4a^3b + 2a^2b^2 + 4ab^3 $$
$$ 8a^3b + 8ab^3 \le a^4 + b^4 + 4a^3b + 4ab^3 + 6a^2b^2 $$
Rearranging the terms, we get:
$$ 0 \le a^4 - 4a^3b + 6a^2b^2 - 4ab^3 + b^4 $$
This is precisely the expansion of $(a-b)^4$. Since $0 \le (a-b)^4$ is true for all real $a,b$, the left inequality is proven.

**Part 2: The Right Inequality**

Now, we prove that $\sqrt{\frac{a^2+b^2}{2}} - \sqrt{ab} \le \frac{(a-b)^2}{a+b}$.

Using the same rationalization as before, we can rewrite the inequality as:
$$ \frac{(a-b)^2}{2\left(\sqrt{\frac{a^2+b^2}{2}} + \sqrt{ab}\right)} \le \frac{(a-b)^2}{a+b} $$
If $a=b$, both sides are 0. If $a \ne b$, we divide by the positive term $(a-b)^2$:
$$ \frac{1}{2\left(\sqrt{\frac{a^2+b^2}{2}} + \sqrt{ab}\right)} \le \frac{1}{a+b} $$
This is equivalent to:
$$ a+b \le 2\left(\sqrt{\frac{a^2+b^2}{2}} + \sqrt{ab}\right) $$
$$ a+b \le \sqrt{2(a^2+b^2)} + 2\sqrt{ab} $$
Since both sides are positive, we can square them:
$$ (a+b)^2 \le \left(\sqrt{2(a^2+b^2)} + 2\sqrt{ab}\right)^2 $$
$$ a^2+2ab+b^2 \le 2(a^2+b^2) + 4ab + 4\sqrt{2(a^2+b^2)ab} $$
$$ a^2+2ab+b^2 \le 2a^2+2b^2 + 4ab + 4\sqrt{2ab(a^2+b^2)} $$
Moving all terms from the left side to the right side gives:
$$ 0 \le (2a^2-a^2) + (2b^2-b^2) + (4ab-2ab) + 4\sqrt{2ab(a^2+b^2)} $$
$$ 0 \le a^2+b^2+2ab + 4\sqrt{2ab(a^2+b^2)} $$
$$ 0 \le (a+b)^2 + 4\sqrt{2ab(a^2+b^2)} $$
Since $a,b > 0$, $(a+b)^2$ is positive, and the term with the square root is non-negative. Their sum is therefore positive. Thus, this inequality is true.

Since both inequalities hold, the proof is complete.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- To be proven, if $a$ and $b$ are positive numbers, then

$$
\frac{(a-b)^{2}}{2(a+b)} \leq \sqrt{\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}}{2}}-\sqrt{a b} \leq \frac{(a-b)^{2}}{a+b}
$$ -/
theorem inequalities_202625 (a b : ‚Ñù) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) :
    (a - b)^2 / (2 * (a + b)) ‚â§ sqrt ((a^2 + b^2) / 2) - sqrt (a * b) ‚àß
    sqrt ((a^2 + b^2) / 2) - sqrt (a * b) ‚â§ (a - b)^2 / (a + b) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

open Real

theorem inequalities_202625 (a b : ‚Ñù) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) :
    (a - b)^2 / (2 * (a + b)) ‚â§ sqrt ((a^2 + b^2) / 2) - sqrt (a * b) ‚àß
    sqrt ((a^2 + b^2) / 2) - sqrt (a * b) ‚â§ (a - b)^2 / (a + b) := by
  have hab : 0 < a * b := mul_pos ha hb
  have ha1 : 0 < a := ha
  have hb1 : 0 < b := hb
  have h1 : (a ^ 2 + b ^ 2) / 2 ‚â• 0 := by positivity
  have h2 : (a * b) ‚â• 0 := by positivity
  have h3 : sqrt ((a ^ 2 + b ^ 2) / 2) ‚â• sqrt (a * b) := by
    apply Real.sqrt_le_sqrt
    nlinarith [sq_nonneg (a - b)]
  have h9 : sqrt ((a ^ 2 + b ^ 2) / 2) - sqrt (a * b) ‚â• 0 := by linarith
  constructor
  ¬∑ -- Prove the left inequality: (a - b)^2 / (2 * (a + b)) ‚â§ sqrt ((a^2 + b^2) / 2) - sqrt (a * b)
    have h10 : (a - b) ^ 2 / (2 * (a + b)) ‚â§ sqrt ((a ^ 2 + b ^ 2) / 2) - sqrt (a * b) := by
      have h11 : 0 < 2 * (a + b) := by nlinarith
      have h14 : (sqrt ((a ^ 2 + b ^ 2) / 2) - sqrt (a * b)) ‚â• (a - b) ^ 2 / (2 * (a + b)) := by
        have h15 : (sqrt ((a ^ 2 + b ^ 2) / 2) - sqrt (a * b)) * (2 * (a + b)) ‚â• (a - b) ^ 2 := by
          have h16 : (sqrt ((a ^ 2 + b ^ 2) / 2) - sqrt (a * b)) * (2 * (a + b)) =
              2 * (a + b) * sqrt ((a ^ 2 + b ^ 2) / 2) - 2 * (a + b) * sqrt (a * b) := by ring
          rw [h16]
          nlinarith [Real.sqrt_nonneg ((a ^ 2 + b ^ 2) / 2), Real.sqrt_nonneg (a * b), 
            Real.sq_sqrt (show (0 : ‚Ñù) ‚â§ (a ^ 2 + b ^ 2) / 2 by positivity), 
            Real.sq_sqrt (show (0 : ‚Ñù) ‚â§ a * b by positivity), 
            sq_nonneg (a - b), 
            sq_nonneg (sqrt ((a ^ 2 + b ^ 2) / 2) - sqrt (a * b)), 
            mul_nonneg (Real.sqrt_nonneg ((a ^ 2 + b ^ 2) / 2)) (Real.sqrt_nonneg (a * b)), 
            sq_nonneg (sqrt ((a ^ 2 + b ^ 2) / 2) ^ 2 - (a ^ 2 + b ^ 2) / 2), 
            sq_nonneg (sqrt (a * b) ^ 2 - (a * b)), 
            mul_nonneg (show 0 ‚â§ a by linarith) (show 0 ‚â§ b by linarith)
          ]
        have h180 : (sqrt ((a ^ 2 + b ^ 2) / 2) - sqrt (a * b)) ‚â• (a - b) ^ 2 / (2 * (a + b)) := by
          have h100 : (sqrt ((a ^ 2 + b ^ 2) / 2) - sqrt (a * b)) * (2 * (a + b)) ‚â• (a - b) ^ 2 := h15
          have h181 : (sqrt ((a ^ 2 + b ^ 2) / 2) - sqrt (a * b)) ‚â• (a - b) ^ 2 / (2 * (a + b)) := by
            apply (div_le_iff‚ÇÄ (by positivity)).mpr
            linarith
          linarith
        linarith
      linarith
    linarith
  ¬∑ -- Prove the right inequality: sqrt ((a^2 + b^2) / 2) - sqrt (a * b) ‚â§ (a - b)^2 / (a + b)
    have h17 : sqrt ((a ^ 2 + b ^ 2) / 2) - sqrt (a * b) ‚â§ (a - b) ^ 2 / (a + b) := by
      have h18 : (sqrt ((a ^ 2 + b ^ 2) / 2) - sqrt (a * b)) ‚â§ (a - b) ^ 2 / (a + b) := by
        have h100 : (sqrt ((a ^ 2 + b ^ 2) / 2) - sqrt (a * b)) * (a + b) ‚â§ (a - b) ^ 2 := by
          have h101 : (sqrt ((a ^ 2 + b ^ 2) / 2) - sqrt (a * b)) * (a + b) =
              (a + b) * sqrt ((a ^ 2 + b ^ 2) / 2) - (a + b) * sqrt (a * b) := by ring
          rw [h101]
          nlinarith [Real.sqrt_nonneg ((a ^ 2 + b ^ 2) / 2), Real.sqrt_nonneg (a * b), 
            Real.sq_sqrt (show (0 : ‚Ñù) ‚â§ (a ^ 2 + b ^ 2) / 2 by positivity), 
            Real.sq_sqrt (show (0 : ‚Ñù) ‚â§ a * b by positivity), 
            sq_nonneg (a - b), sq_nonneg (sqrt ((a ^ 2 + b ^ 2) / 2) - sqrt (a * b)), 
            mul_nonneg (Real.sqrt_nonneg ((a ^ 2 + b ^ 2) / 2)) (Real.sqrt_nonneg (a * b)), 
            sq_nonneg (sqrt ((a ^ 2 + b ^ 2) / 2) ^ 2 - (a ^ 2 + b ^ 2) / 2), 
            sq_nonneg (sqrt (a * b) ^ 2 - (a * b)), 
            mul_nonneg (show 0 ‚â§ a by linarith) (show 0 ‚â§ b by linarith)
          ]
        have h181 : (sqrt ((a ^ 2 + b ^ 2) / 2) - sqrt (a * b)) ‚â§ (a - b) ^ 2 / (a + b) := by
          have h182 : (sqrt ((a ^ 2 + b ^ 2) / 2) - sqrt (a * b)) * (a + b) ‚â§ (a - b) ^ 2 := h100
          have h183 : (sqrt ((a ^ 2 + b ^ 2) / 2) - sqrt (a * b)) ‚â§ (a - b) ^ 2 / (a + b) := by
            apply (le_div_iff‚ÇÄ (by positivity)).mpr
            linarith
          linarith
        linarith
      linarith
    linarith

informal_proof:
Let `(a, b, c, d)` be an ordered quadruple of real numbers satisfying the given equations:
1.  `a‚Å¥ + b‚Å¥ + c‚Å¥ + d‚Å¥ = 48`
2.  `abcd = 12`

Our goal is to determine the number of such quadruples.

First, we establish a relationship between the sum of the fourth powers and the product of the numbers. Using the fact that the square of any real number is non-negative, we have the following inequalities:
`a‚Å¥ + b‚Å¥ ‚â• 2a¬≤b¬≤` because `a‚Å¥ - 2a¬≤b¬≤ + b‚Å¥ = (a¬≤ - b¬≤)¬≤ ‚â• 0`.
Similarly, `c‚Å¥ + d‚Å¥ ‚â• 2c¬≤d¬≤`.
Adding these two inequalities, we get:
`a‚Å¥ + b‚Å¥ + c‚Å¥ + d‚Å¥ ‚â• 2a¬≤b¬≤ + 2c¬≤d¬≤`

Next, for non-negative numbers `x` and `y`, we have `x + y ‚â• 2‚àö(xy)`. Applying this with `x = a¬≤b¬≤` and `y = c¬≤d¬≤`, we get:
`a¬≤b¬≤ + c¬≤d¬≤ ‚â• 2‚àö((a¬≤b¬≤)(c¬≤d¬≤)) = 2|abcd|`.
Multiplying by 2, we have:
`2a¬≤b¬≤ + 2c¬≤d¬≤ ‚â• 4|abcd|`.

Combining the inequalities, we obtain:
`a‚Å¥ + b‚Å¥ + c‚Å¥ + d‚Å¥ ‚â• 4|abcd|`.

From the problem statement, we have `a‚Å¥ + b‚Å¥ + c‚Å¥ + d‚Å¥ = 48` and `abcd = 12`. Substituting these values into our derived inequality:
`48 ‚â• 4|12|`, which simplifies to `48 ‚â• 48`.

Since equality holds, both of the intermediate inequalities must also be equalities.
1. `a‚Å¥ + b‚Å¥ + c‚Å¥ + d‚Å¥ = 2a¬≤b¬≤ + 2c¬≤d¬≤`, which implies `(a¬≤ - b¬≤)¬≤ + (c¬≤ - d¬≤)¬≤ = 0`. Since both terms are non-negative, they must both be zero. Thus, `a¬≤ = b¬≤` and `c¬≤ = d¬≤`.
2. `2a¬≤b¬≤ + 2c¬≤d¬≤ = 4|abcd|`. Since `abcd=12` is positive, this is `2a¬≤b¬≤ + 2c¬≤d¬≤ = 4abcd`, which implies `a¬≤b¬≤ - 2abcd + c¬≤d¬≤ = 0`, or `(ab - cd)¬≤ = 0`. Thus, `ab = cd`.

By symmetry of the original equations, we can rearrange the variables (e.g., swapping `b` and `c`) and apply the same logic to deduce that `a¬≤ = c¬≤` and `b¬≤ = d¬≤`. Combining these results, we conclude that `a¬≤ = b¬≤ = c¬≤ = d¬≤`.

This implies `a‚Å¥ = b‚Å¥ = c‚Å¥ = d‚Å¥`. Substituting this into the first equation:
`a‚Å¥ + a‚Å¥ + a‚Å¥ + a‚Å¥ = 48`
`4a‚Å¥ = 48`
`a‚Å¥ = 12`
Therefore, for any solution `(a, b, c, d)`, it must be that `a‚Å¥ = b‚Å¥ = c‚Å¥ = d‚Å¥ = 12`.

Now, we find the real numbers `x` such that `x‚Å¥ = 12`. Let `m = 12^(1/4)` be the positive real fourth root of 12. The equation `x‚Å¥ = 12` can be written as `x‚Å¥ - m‚Å¥ = 0`, which factors as `(x¬≤ - m¬≤)(x¬≤ + m¬≤) = 0`. Since `x` is real and `m` is positive, `x¬≤ ‚â• 0` and `m¬≤ > 0`, so `x¬≤ + m¬≤ > 0`. Thus, we must have `x¬≤ - m¬≤ = 0`, which gives `x¬≤ = m¬≤`. The solutions are `x = m` and `x = -m`.

This means that each of `a, b, c, d` must be either `m` or `-m`. We now use the second equation, `abcd = 12`, to determine the valid combinations of signs. The product `abcd` is `(¬±m)(¬±m)(¬±m)(¬±m) = (sign) * m‚Å¥ = (sign) * 12`. For the product to be `12`, the product of the signs must be positive. This occurs when there is an even number of negative signs among `a, b, c, d`.

The possible cases for the number of negative values are:
-   **Zero negative values**: One combination: `(m, m, m, m)`.
-   **Two negative values**: There are `C(4, 2) = 6` combinations. The quadruples are `(m, m, -m, -m)`, `(m, -m, m, -m)`, `(m, -m, -m, m)`, `(-m, m, m, -m)`, `(-m, m, -m, m)`, and `(-m, -m, m, m)`.
-   **Four negative values**: One combination: `(-m, -m, -m, -m)`.

In total, there are `1 + 6 + 1 = 8` possible quadruples.

We must verify that these 8 quadruples are indeed solutions. For any of these quadruples, each component `x` satisfies `x‚Å¥ = (¬±m)‚Å¥ = m‚Å¥ = 12`.
-   The sum of the fourth powers is `a‚Å¥ + b‚Å¥ + c‚Å¥ + d‚Å¥ = 12 + 12 + 12 + 12 = 48`.
-   The product `abcd` has an even number of negative factors, so the result is positive: `abcd = m‚Å¥ = 12`.

Both equations are satisfied for all 8 quadruples. Since `m = 12^(1/4) > 0`, `m ‚â† -m`, so all 8 listed quadruples are distinct.

Therefore, there are exactly 8 ordered quadruples of real numbers that satisfy the given conditions.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Find the number of ordered quadruples $(a,b,c,d)$ of real numbers such that
\begin{align*}
a^4 + b^4 + c^4 + d^4 &= 48, \\
abcd &= 12.
\end{align*} -/
theorem algebra_22065 :
    {(a, b, c, d) : ‚Ñù √ó ‚Ñù √ó ‚Ñù √ó ‚Ñù | a ^ 4 + b ^ 4 + c ^ 4 + d ^ 4 = 48 ‚àß a * b * c * d = 12}.ncard = 8 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

/- Find the number of ordered quadruples $(a,b,c,d)$ of real numbers such that
\begin{align*}
a^4 + b^4 + c^4 + d^4 &= 48, \\
abcd &= 12.
\end{align*} -/
theorem algebra_22065 :
    {(a, b, c, d) : ‚Ñù √ó ‚Ñù √ó ‚Ñù √ó ‚Ñù | a ^ 4 + b ^ 4 + c ^ 4 + d ^ 4 = 48 ‚àß a * b * c * d = 12}.ncard = 8 := by
    -- Á¨¨‰∏ÄÊ≠•ÔºöËØÅÊòéÊâÄÊúâÊª°Ë∂≥Êù°‰ª∂ÁöÑÂõõÂÖÉÁªÑ‰∏≠ÁöÑÊØè‰∏™Êï∞ÁöÑÂõõÊ¨°ÊñπÈÉΩÁ≠â‰∫é12
    have h1 : ‚àÄ n ‚àà {(a, b, c, d) : ‚Ñù √ó ‚Ñù √ó ‚Ñù √ó ‚Ñù | a ^ 4 + b ^ 4 + c ^ 4 + d ^ 4 = 48 ‚àß a * b * c * d = 12}, (n.1) ^ 4 = 12 ‚àß (n.2.1) ^ 4 = 12 ‚àß (n.2.2.1) ^ 4 = 12 ‚àß (n.2.2.2) ^ 4 = 12:= by
        intro n hn
        let ‚ü®x, y, z, w‚ü© := n
        simp
        have h1 : x ^ 4 + y ^ 4 + z ^ 4 + w ^ 4 = 48 := hn.1
        have h2 : x * y * z * w = 12 := hn.2
        have h3 : x ^ 4 + y ^ 4 + z ^ 4 + w ^ 4 ‚â• 2 * (x ^ 2 * y ^ 2) + 2 * (z ^ 2 * w ^ 2) := by
            calc _ = 2 * (x ^ 2 * y ^ 2) + 2 * (z ^ 2 * w ^ 2) + (x ^ 2 - y ^ 2) ^ 2 + (z ^ 2 - w ^ 2) ^ 2:= by ring
                 _ ‚â• 2 * (x ^ 2 * y ^ 2) + 2 * (z ^ 2 * w ^ 2) := by
                    have _ : (z ^ 2 - w ^ 2) ^ 2 ‚â• 0:= by exact sq_nonneg (z ^ 2 - w ^ 2)
                    have _ : (x ^ 2 - y ^ 2) ^ 2 ‚â• 0:= by exact sq_nonneg (x ^ 2 - y ^ 2)
                    linarith
        have h11 : 2 * (x ^ 2 * y ^ 2) + 2 * (z ^ 2 * w ^ 2) ‚â• 4 * (x * y * z * w):= by
            calc _ = 2 * (x * y - z * w) ^ 2 + 4 * (x * y * z * w) := by ring
                 _ ‚â• 4 * (x * y * z * w):= by
                    have hxyzw : (x * y - z * w) ^ 2 ‚â• 0:= by exact sq_nonneg (x * y - z * w)
                    linarith
        have h4 : x ^ 4 + y ^ 4 + z ^ 4 + w ^ 4 = 2 * (x ^ 2 * y ^ 2) + 2 * (z ^ 2 * w ^ 2):= by linarith
        replace h4 :  (x ^ 2 - y ^ 2) ^ 2 + (z ^ 2 - w ^ 2) ^ 2 = 0:= by
            ring_nf
            linarith
        replace h4 : (x ^ 2 - y ^ 2) ^ 2 = 0 ‚àß (z ^ 2 - w ^ 2) ^ 2 = 0:= by
            have _ : (x ^ 2 - y ^ 2) ^ 2 ‚â• 0:= by exact sq_nonneg (x ^ 2 - y ^ 2)
            have _ : (z ^ 2 - w ^ 2) ^ 2 ‚â• 0:= by exact sq_nonneg (z ^ 2 - w ^ 2)
            constructor
            . linarith
            . linarith
        have h5 : x ^ 4 + y ^ 4 + z ^ 4 + w ^ 4 ‚â• 2 * (x ^ 2 * z ^ 2) + 2 * (y ^ 2 * w ^ 2) := by
            calc _ = 2 * (x ^ 2 * z ^ 2) + 2 * (y ^ 2 * w ^ 2) + (x ^ 2 - z ^ 2) ^ 2 + (y ^ 2 - w ^ 2) ^ 2:= by ring
                 _ ‚â• 2 * (x ^ 2 * z ^ 2) + 2 * (y ^ 2 * w ^ 2):= by
                    have _ : (x ^ 2 - z ^ 2) ^ 2 ‚â• 0:= by exact sq_nonneg (x ^ 2 - z ^ 2)
                    have _ : (y ^ 2 - w ^ 2) ^ 2 ‚â• 0:= by exact sq_nonneg (y ^ 2 - w ^ 2)
                    linarith
        have h12 : 2 * (x ^ 2 * z ^ 2) + 2 * (y ^ 2 * w ^ 2) ‚â• 4 * (x * z * y * w):= by
            calc _ = 2 * (x * z - y * w) ^ 2 + 4 * (x * z * y * w) := by ring
                 _ ‚â• 4 * (x * z * y * w):= by
                    have _ : (x * z - y * w) ^ 2 ‚â• 0:= by exact sq_nonneg (x * z - y * w)
                    linarith
        have h6 : x ^ 4 + y ^ 4 + z ^ 4 + w ^ 4 = 2 * (x ^ 2 * z ^ 2) + 2 * (y ^ 2 * w ^ 2):= by linarith
        replace h6 : (x ^ 2 - z ^ 2) ^ 2 + (y ^ 2 - w ^ 2) ^ 2 = 0:= by
            ring_nf
            linarith
        replace h6 : (x ^ 2 - z ^ 2) ^ 2 = 0 ‚àß (y ^ 2 - w ^ 2) ^ 2 = 0:= by
            have _ : (x ^ 2 - z ^ 2) ^ 2 ‚â• 0:= by exact sq_nonneg (x ^ 2 - z ^ 2)
            have _ : (y ^ 2 - w ^ 2) ^ 2 ‚â• 0:= by exact sq_nonneg (y ^ 2 - w ^ 2)
            constructor
            . linarith
            . linarith
        clear h2 h3 h5 h11 h12
        replace h4 : x ^ 2 = y ^ 2 ‚àß z ^ 2 = w ^ 2:= by
            have hxy : (x ^ 2 - y ^ 2) ^ 2 = 0:= by exact h4.1
            have hzw : (z ^ 2 - w ^ 2) ^ 2 = 0:= by exact h4.2
            constructor
            .
                have _ :x ^ 2 - y ^ 2 = 0:= by exact pow_eq_zero hxy
                linarith
            .
                have _ :z ^ 2 - w ^ 2 = 0:= by exact pow_eq_zero hzw
                linarith
        replace h6 : x ^ 2 = z ^ 2 ‚àß y ^ 2 = w ^ 2:= by
            have hxz : (x ^ 2 - z ^ 2) ^ 2 = 0:= by exact h6.1
            have hyw : (y ^ 2 - w ^ 2) ^ 2 = 0:= by exact h6.2
            constructor
            .
                have _ : x ^ 2 - z ^ 2 = 0:= by exact pow_eq_zero hxz
                linarith
            .
                have _ : y ^ 2 - w ^ 2 = 0:= by exact pow_eq_zero hyw
                linarith
        replace h4 : x ^ 4 = y ^ 4 ‚àß z ^ 4 = w ^ 4:= by
            constructor
            .
                calc _ = (x ^ 2) ^ 2 := by ring
                     _ = (y ^ 2) ^ 2 := by rw [h4.1]
                     _ = y ^ 4 := by ring
            .
                calc _ = (z ^ 2) ^ 2 := by ring
                     _ = (w ^ 2) ^ 2 := by rw [h4.2]
                     _ = w ^ 4 := by ring
        replace h6 : x ^ 4 = z ^ 4 ‚àß y ^ 4 = w ^ 4:= by
            constructor
            .
                calc _ = (x ^ 2) ^ 2 := by ring
                     _ = (z ^ 2) ^ 2 := by rw [h6.1]
                     _ = z ^ 4 := by ring
            .
                calc _ = (y ^ 2) ^ 2 := by ring
                     _ = (w ^ 2) ^ 2 := by rw [h6.2]
                     _ = w ^ 4 := by ring
        refine ‚ü®?_, ?_, ?_, ?_‚ü©
        all_goals linarith
    -- ÂÆö‰πâm‰∏∫12ÁöÑÂõõÊ¨°ÊñπÊ†π
    let m := (12 : ‚Ñù) ^ (1 / 4 : ‚Ñù)
    have mpos : m > 0 := by positivity
    -- ËØÅÊòém^4 = 12
    have hm : m ^ 4 = 12 := by
        calc _ = ((12 : ‚Ñù) ^ (1 / 4 : ‚Ñù)) ^ 4 := rfl
             _ = (12 : ‚Ñù) ^ ((1 / 4 : ‚Ñù) * (4 : ‚Ñï)) := (Real.rpow_mul_natCast (by norm_num) (1 / 4) 4).symm
             _ = 12 := by norm_num
    -- ËØÅÊòéÂ¶ÇÊûúx^4 = 12ÔºåÈÇ£‰πàxÂè™ËÉΩÁ≠â‰∫émÊàñ-m
    have h2 (x : ‚Ñù): x ^ 4 = 12 ‚Üí x = m ‚à® x = -m:= by
        intro hx
        have hy : x ^ 4 = m ^ 4 := by rw [hx, hm]
        have hz : (x ^ 2 - m ^ 2) * (x ^ 2 + m ^ 2) = 0:= by
            calc _ = x ^ 4 - m ^ 4 := by ring
                 _ = 0 := by rw [hy, sub_self]
        have hp : x ^ 2 + m ^ 2 > 0:= by
            have _ : x ^ 2 ‚â• 0:= by exact sq_nonneg x
            have _ : m ^ 2 > 0:= by exact sq_pos_of_pos mpos
            linarith
        have hw : x ^ 2 - m ^ 2 = 0 ‚à® x ^ 2 + m ^ 2 = 0:= by exact mul_eq_zero.mp hz
        have hl : x ^ 2 - m ^ 2 = 0:= by
            rcases hw with h1 | h2
            . exact h1
            . by_contra
              rw [h2] at hp
              simp at hp
        clear hx hy hz hp hw
        have hx : x - m = 0 ‚à® x + m = 0:= by
            have hy : (x - m) * (x + m) = 0:= by
                calc _ = x ^ 2 - m ^ 2 := by ring
                     _ = 0 := by rw [hl]
            exact mul_eq_zero.mp hy
        rcases hx with h1 | h2
        .   replace h1 : x = m:= by linarith
            left
            exact h1
        .   replace h2 : x = -m:= by linarith
            right
            exact h2
    -- ËØÅÊòéÊâÄÊúâÊª°Ë∂≥Êù°‰ª∂ÁöÑÂõõÂÖÉÁªÑÈÉΩÊòØÁî±mÂíå-mÁªÑÊàêÁöÑ8ÁßçÁªÑÂêà‰πã‰∏Ä
    have h3 : ‚àÄ n ‚àà {(a, b, c, d) : ‚Ñù √ó ‚Ñù √ó ‚Ñù √ó ‚Ñù | a ^ 4 + b ^ 4 + c ^ 4 + d ^ 4 = 48 ‚àß a * b * c * d = 12}, n ‚àà {n | n = (m, m, m, m) ‚à® n = (m, m, -m, -m) ‚à® n = (m, -m, m, -m) ‚à® n = (m, -m, -m, m) ‚à® n = (-m, m, m, -m) ‚à® n = (-m, m, -m, m) ‚à® n = (-m, -m, m, m) ‚à® n = (-m, -m, -m, -m)}:= by
        intro n hn
        specialize h1 n hn
        simp at hn
        replace hn := hn.2
        let ‚ü®x, y, z, w‚ü© := n
        simp at h1 hn
        have hx : x = m ‚à® x = -m:= by exact h2 x h1.1
        have hy : y = m ‚à® y = -m:= by exact h2 y h1.2.1
        have hz : z = m ‚à® z = -m:= by exact h2 z h1.2.2.1
        have hw : w = m ‚à® w = -m:= by exact h2 w h1.2.2.2
        simp
        replace hn : w = m ^ 4 / (x * y * z):= by
            rw [hm, ‚Üêhn]
            have _ : (x * y * z) ‚â† 0:= by
                by_contra!
                rw [this] at hn
                ring_nf at hn
                linarith
            field_simp
        have hm' : m ‚â† -m:= by
            by_contra!
            replace this : m = 0:= by linarith
            linarith
        rcases hx with hx | hx <;> rcases hy with hy | hy <;> rcases hz with hz | hz <;> simp [hx, hz] at hn <;> simp [hx, hy, hz, hn, hm'] <;> field_simp <;> ring_nf <;> tauto
    -- ÂèçÂêëËØÅÊòéÔºöËøô8ÁßçÁªÑÂêàÈÉΩÊª°Ë∂≥ÂéüÂßãÊù°‰ª∂
    have h4 : ‚àÄ n ‚àà
    {n |
      n = (m, m, m, m) ‚à®
        n = (m, m, -m, -m) ‚à®
          n = (m, -m, m, -m) ‚à®
            n = (m, -m, -m, m) ‚à® n = (-m, m, m, -m) ‚à® n = (-m, m, -m, m) ‚à® n = (-m, -m, m, m) ‚à® n = (-m, -m, -m, -m)}, n ‚àà {(a, b, c, d) | a ^ 4 + b ^ 4 + c ^ 4 + d ^ 4 = 48 ‚àß a * b * c * d = 12}:= by
            intro n hn
            simp at hn
            rcases hn with h11 | h11 | h11 | h11 | h11 | h11 | h11 | h11
            all_goals
            simp [h11,hm]
            constructor
            .
              linarith
            .
              linarith
    have h5 : {(a, b, c, d) | a ^ 4 + b ^ 4 + c ^ 4 + d ^ 4 = 48 ‚àß a * b * c * d = 12} = {n |
      n = (m, m, m, m) ‚à®
        n = (m, m, -m, -m) ‚à®
          n = (m, -m, m, -m) ‚à®
            n = (m, -m, -m, m) ‚à® n = (-m, m, m, -m) ‚à® n = (-m, m, -m, m) ‚à® n = (-m, -m, m, m) ‚à® n = (-m, -m, -m, -m)}:= by
            exact Set.Subset.antisymm h3 h4
    clear h1 h2 h3 h4 mpos hm
    rw [h5]
    clear h5

    have hm : m > 0 := by positivity
    replace hm : m ‚â† -m := by linarith
    -- ÊúÄÂêéËØÅÊòéÈõÜÂêàÂü∫Êï∞‰∏∫8
    change Set.ncard {(m, m, m, m), (m, m, -m, -m), (m, -m, m, -m), (m, -m, -m, m), (-m, m, m, -m), (-m, m, -m, m), (-m, -m, m, m), (-m, -m, -m, -m)} = 8

    rw [show ({(m, m, m, m), (m, m, -m, -m), (m, -m, m, -m), (m, -m, -m, m), (-m, m, m, -m), (-m, m, -m, m), (-m, -m, m, m), (-m, -m, -m, -m)} : Set (‚Ñù √ó ‚Ñù √ó ‚Ñù √ó ‚Ñù)) = ({(m, m, m, m), (m, m, -m, -m), (m, -m, m, -m), (m, -m, -m, m), (-m, m, m, -m), (-m, m, -m, m), (-m, -m, m, m), (-m, -m, -m, -m)} : Finset (‚Ñù √ó ‚Ñù √ó ‚Ñù √ó ‚Ñù)) by simp]
    rw [Set.ncard_coe_Finset]
    repeat rw [Finset.card_insert_of_not_mem]
    simp
    all_goals
      simp [hm]

soln_description:
Multiplying both sides by $a b c$, the obtained

$$
a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2} \geq 2 b c+2 a c-2 a b
$$

inequality is equivalent to the original one due to $a b c>0$. Rearranging this, we get

$$
a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}-2 b c-2 a c+2 a b \geq 0
$$

On the left side, we have exactly $(a+b-c)^{2}$, so our statement follows from the fact that the square of a number cannot be negative. It is also clear that in (1) equality holds precisely when $a+b=c$.

Remark. In the proof, we only used that the product of $a$, $b$, and $c$ is positive. Thus, (1) is also true if exactly two of $a$, $b$, and $c$ are negative. If one of the three numbers is negative, or all three are negative, the opposite inequality holds in (1).
informal_statement:
Let $a>0, b>0, c>0$. Prove that

$$
\frac{a}{b c}+\frac{b}{a c}+\frac{c}{b a} \geqq \frac{2}{a}+\frac{2}{b}-\frac{2}{c}
$$
informal_proof:
We want to prove the inequality
$$
\frac{a}{b c}+\frac{b}{a c}+\frac{c}{b a} \geqq \frac{2}{a}+\frac{2}{b}-\frac{2}{c}
$$
for positive real numbers $a, b, c$.

The inequality is equivalent to showing that the difference between the left-hand side and the right-hand side is non-negative. Let us consider this difference:
$$
\frac{a}{bc} + \frac{b}{ac} + \frac{c}{ab} - \left(\frac{2}{a} + \frac{2}{b} - \frac{2}{c}\right) \ge 0
$$
Since $a, b, c$ are all positive, their product $abc$ is also positive. We can express the entire expression on the left-hand side as a single fraction with the common denominator $abc$:
$$
\frac{a^2}{abc} + \frac{b^2}{abc} + \frac{c^2}{abc} - \frac{2bc}{abc} - \frac{2ac}{abc} + \frac{2ab}{abc} \ge 0
$$
Combining the terms in the numerator, we get:
$$
\frac{a^2 + b^2 + c^2 + 2ab - 2ac - 2bc}{abc} \ge 0
$$
We can recognize that the numerator is the expansion of a perfect square. Specifically, $a^2 + b^2 + c^2 + 2ab - 2ac - 2bc = (a + b - c)^2$.
Thus, our inequality simplifies to:
$$
\frac{(a+b-c)^2}{abc} \ge 0
$$
The numerator, $(a+b-c)^2$, is the square of a real number, which is always greater than or equal to zero. The denominator, $abc$, is the product of three positive numbers and is therefore strictly positive.

The quotient of a non-negative number and a positive number is always non-negative. Therefore, the inequality $\frac{(a+b-c)^2}{abc} \ge 0$ is true. This completes the proof.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $a>0, b>0, c>0$. Prove that

$$
\frac{a}{b c}+\frac{b}{a c}+\frac{c}{b a} \geqq \frac{2}{a}+\frac{2}{b}-\frac{2}{c}
$$ -/
theorem inequalities_202674 (a b c : ‚Ñù) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c) :
    a / b / c + b / a / c + c / b / a ‚â• 2 / a + 2 / b - 2 / c := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem inequalities_202674 (a b c : ‚Ñù) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c) :
    a / b / c + b / a / c + c / b / a ‚â• 2 / a + 2 / b - 2 / c := by
-- Try to express the Goal as difference is >=0
  have h1 : 0 < a * b * c := by
    apply mul_pos
    apply mul_pos
    all_goals nlinarith
  have h3 : a / b / c + b / a / c + c / b / a - (2 / a + 2 / b - 2 / c) ‚â• 0 := by
    have h4 : a / b / c + b / a / c + c / b / a - (2 / a + 2 / b - 2 / c) = 
      (a ^ 2 + b ^ 2 + c ^ 2 - 2 * b * c - 2 * a * c + 2 * a * b) / (a * b * c) := by 
      field_simp
      ring
    rw [h4]
    have h5 : a ^ 2 + b ^ 2 + c ^ 2 - 2 * b * c - 2 * a * c + 2 * a * b ‚â• 0 := by
      nlinarith [sq_nonneg (a + b - c)]
    have h6 : a * b * c > 0 := h1
    apply div_nonneg
    all_goals try linarith
    all_goals try nlinarith
  linarith

informal_statement: Suppose that $f$ is a polynomial such that \[(x-1)\cdot f(x)=3x^4+x^3 - 25x^2 +38x -17.\]What is the degree of $f$?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Suppose that $f$ is a polynomial such that \[(x-1)\cdot f(x)=3x^4+x^3 - 25x^2 +38x -17.\]What is the degree of $f$? -/
theorem algebra_20068 {f : Polynomial ‚Ñù} (h : ‚àÄ x, (x - 1) * f.eval x = 3 * x ^ 4 + x ^ 3 - 25 * x ^ 2 + 38 * x - 17) :
    f.degree = 3 := by

informal_statement: If $x$ and $y$ are positive integers for which $3x + 2y + xy = 115$, then what is $x + y$?
informal_proof:
Let $x$ and $y$ be positive integers satisfying the equation $3x + 2y + xy = 115$.

Our goal is to find the value of $x+y$. We begin by manipulating the given equation. By adding 6 to both sides, we get:
$3x + 2y + xy + 6 = 115 + 6$
$3x + 2y + xy + 6 = 121$

The left-hand side of this equation can be factored by grouping terms:
$(x y + 3x) + (2y + 6) = 121$
$x(y + 3) + 2(y + 3) = 121$
$(x + 2)(y + 3) = 121$

Since $x$ and $y$ are integers, $(x + 2)$ and $(y + 3)$ must be integer factors of 121. The divisors of $121$ are $1$, $11$, and $121$. Thus, $(x + 2)$ must be one of these three values.

We are given that $x$ is a positive integer, so $x \ge 1$. This implies that $x + 2 \ge 1 + 2 = 3$. This constraint allows us to eliminate one of the possible values for $(x+2)$:
-   $x + 2$ cannot be $1$, as this would imply $x = -1$, which is not a positive integer.

Therefore, we only need to consider the remaining two cases:

**Case 1: $x + 2 = 11$**
If $x + 2 = 11$, then $x = 9$. Substituting this back into the factored equation:
$11(y + 3) = 121$
Dividing both sides by 11, we get:
$y + 3 = 11$
This gives $y = 8$.
The values $x=9$ and $y=8$ satisfy the initial conditions of being positive integers. For this solution, the sum is $x + y = 9 + 8 = 17$.

**Case 2: $x + 2 = 121$**
If $x + 2 = 121$, then $x = 119$. Substituting this back into the factored equation:
$121(y + 3) = 121$
Dividing both sides by 121, we get:
$y + 3 = 1$
This gives $y = -2$.
This result contradicts the given condition that $y$ is a positive integer. Therefore, this case is not a valid solution.

Since the only case consistent with the given conditions yields $x + y = 17$, we conclude that $x + y = 17$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- If $x$ and $y$ are positive integers for which $3x + 2y + xy = 115$, then what is $x + y$? -/
theorem algebra_19979 (x y : ‚Ñï) (hx : 0 < x) (hy : 0 < y)
    (h : 3 * x + 2 * y + x * y = 115) : x + y = 17 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

/- If $x$ and $y$ are positive integers for which $3x + 2y + xy = 115$, then what is $x + y$? -/
theorem algebra_19979 (x y : ‚Ñï) (hx : 0 < x) (hy : 0 < y)
    (h : 3 * x + 2 * y + x * y = 115) : x + y = 17 := by
  -- Add 6 to both sides of the equation
  apply_fun (¬∑ + 6) at h
  -- Rewrite the equation, and we get (x + 2) * (y + 3) = 121
  replace h : (x + 2) * (y + 3) = 121 := by linarith only [h]
  -- We have x + 2 ‚à£ 121
  have k : x + 2 ‚à£ 121 := ‚ü®y + 3, h.symm‚ü©
  -- Thus, x + 2 is a divisor of 121
  replace k : x + 2 ‚àà Nat.divisors 121 := Nat.mem_divisors.2 ‚ü®k, by simp‚ü©
  -- 121 has 3 divisors: 1, 11, 121
  -- The decide tactic is used to prove that 121 has 3 divisors: 1, 11, 121, which can be done by hand.
  have l : Nat.divisors 121 = {1, 11, 121} := by decide
  -- Thus, x + 2 is either 1, 11, or 121
  rw [l] at k
  -- x is either 9 or 119
  simp at k
  -- Case analysis
  rcases k with rfl | rfl
  all_goals
    omega

soln_description:
I. solution. We transform the left-hand side base using the formula for the sum of a geometric series and then raise it to the cube:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& 3 \underbrace{66 \ldots 6^{3}}_{n \text { digits }}=3\left[6\left(10^{n-1}+10^{n-2}+\ldots+10+1\right)\right]^{3}= \\
& =3 \cdot\left(\frac{6\left(10^{n}-1\right)}{10-1}\right)^{3}=\frac{8}{9}\left(10^{3 n}-3 \cdot 10^{2 n}+3 \cdot 10^{n}-1\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

We similarly transform the right-hand side. The place value of the digit 4 is $10^{n}$, the last 2 is $10^{n+1}$, and the 6 is $10^{2 n}$, and the 8 preceding it is $10^{2 n+1}$. Therefore,

$$
\begin{gathered}
8 \cdot \frac{10^{n-1}-1}{9} \cdot 10^{2 n+1}+6 \cdot 10^{2 n}+2 \cdot \frac{10^{n-1}-1}{9} \cdot 10^{n+1}+4 \cdot 10^{n}+8 \cdot \frac{10^{n}-1}{9}= \\
=\frac{8}{9}(10^{3 n}-\underbrace{10^{2 n+1}+\frac{27}{4} \cdot 10^{2 n}+\frac{1}{4} \cdot 10^{2 n}}-\underbrace{\frac{1}{4} \cdot 10^{n+1}+\frac{9}{2} \cdot 10^{n}+10^{n}}-1)= \\
=\frac{8}{9}\left[10^{3 n}-(10-7) \cdot 10^{2 n}+\left(-\frac{5}{2}+\frac{9}{2}+1\right) \cdot 10^{3}-1\right]
\end{gathered}
$$

from which we can already see that it is equal to (1).

B√°n Ilona (H√≥dmez≈ëv√°s√°rhely, Bethlen G. g. IV. o. t.)

II. solution. The left-hand side can be transformed into the right-hand side number by appropriately grouping the factors as follows:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& 3 \underbrace{66 \ldots 6^{3}}_{n}=2^{3} \cdot 3^{4} \cdot \underbrace{11 \ldots 1^{2}}_{n} \cdot \underbrace{11 \ldots 1}_{n}=\underbrace{99 \ldots 9^{2}}_{n} \cdot \underbrace{88 \ldots 8}_{n}= \\
& =\left(10^{n}-1\right)^{2} \cdot \underbrace{88 \ldots 8}_{n}=(1 \underbrace{00 \ldots 0}_{2 n}-2 \underbrace{00 \ldots 0}_{2 n}+1) \cdot \underbrace{88 \ldots 8}_{n}= \\
& =\underbrace{88 \ldots 8}_{n} \underbrace{00 \ldots 0}_{2 n}-1 \underbrace{77 \ldots 7}_{n-1} 6 \underbrace{00 \ldots 0}_{n}+\underbrace{88 \ldots 8}_{n}= \\
& =[\underbrace{88 \ldots 8}_{n-1} 6 \underbrace{00 \ldots 0}_{n} \underbrace{88 \ldots 8}_{n}]+ \\
& \quad+(2 \underbrace{00 \ldots 0}_{2 n}-1 \underbrace{77 \ldots 7}_{n-1} 6 \underbrace{00 \ldots 0}_{n}=[\ldots]+ \\
& \quad+\underbrace{22 \ldots 2}_{n-1} 4 \underbrace{00 \ldots 0}_{n}=\underbrace{88 \ldots 8}_{n-1} 6 \underbrace{22 \ldots 2}_{n-1} 4 \underbrace{88 \ldots 8}_{n}
\end{aligned}
$$

Ferencz L√°szl√≥ (Budapest, Fazekas M. prep. g. II. o. t.)

III. solution. Denoting the $n$-digit number $11 \ldots 1$ by $N$, we have $10^{n}=9 N+1$, and the left-hand side is $2^{3} \cdot 3^{4} \cdot N^{3}$. The right-hand side can be transformed as follows:

$$
\begin{gathered}
(8 N-2) \cdot 10^{2 n}+(2 N+2) \cdot 10^{n}+8 N= \\
=(8 N-2)(9 N+1)^{2}+(2 N+2)(9 N+1)+8 N= \\
=8 \cdot 9^{2} \cdot N^{3}+8 N(18 N+1)-2(9 N+1)^{2}+(2 N+2)(9 N+1)+8 N= \\
=2^{3} \cdot 3^{4} \cdot N^{3}+(9 N+1)[16 N-2(9 N+1)+(2 N+2)]=2^{3} \cdot 3^{4} \cdot N^{3}
\end{gathered}
$$

Per√©my G√°bor (Budapest, Szi√°gyi E. g. III. o. t.)
informal_statement:
We will prove that if $n>1$ is an integer, then

$$
3 \cdot \underbrace{66 \ldots 6^{3}}_{n \text { digits }}=\underbrace{88 \ldots 8}_{n-1 \text { digits }} 6 \underbrace{22 \ldots 2}_{n-1 \text { digits }} 4 \underbrace{88 \ldots 8}_{n \text { digits }}
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- We will prove that if $n>1$ is an integer, then

$$
3 \cdot \underbrace{66 \ldots 6^{3}}_{n \text { digits }}=\underbrace{88 \ldots 8}_{n-1 \text { digits }} 6 \underbrace{22 \ldots 2}_{n-1 \text { digits }} 4 \underbrace{88 \ldots 8}_{n \text { digits }}
$$ -/
#eval Nat.ofDigits 10 ((List.replicate 8 1) ++ (List.replicate 2 4))
theorem number_theory_202453 (n : ‚Ñï) (hn : 1 < n) :
    3 * Nat.ofDigits 10 (List.replicate n 6) = 
    Nat.ofDigits 10 ((List.replicate n 8) ++ [4] ++ (List.replicate (n-1) 2) ++ [6] ++
    (List.replicate (n-1) 8)) := by

informal_statement:
Let $z_1$ and $z_2$ be two complex numbers such that $|z_1| = 5$ and
\[\frac{z_1}{z_2} + \frac{z_2}{z_1} = 1.\]Find $|z_1 - z_2|^2.$
informal_proof:
Let $z_1$ and $z_2$ be complex numbers satisfying the given conditions. We are given $|z_1| = 5$, $z_2 \neq 0$, and
\[\frac{z_1}{z_2} + \frac{z_2}{z_1} = 1.\]
Let us introduce a new complex variable $u = \frac{z_2}{z_1}$. Since $z_2 \neq 0$ and $|z_1| = 5 \neq 0$, we know $u \neq 0$. The given equation can be rewritten in terms of $u$. Notice that $\frac{z_1}{z_2} = \left(\frac{z_2}{z_1}\right)^{-1} = u^{-1}$. The equation thus becomes:
\[u^{-1} + u = 1.\]
Multiplying the entire equation by $u$ (which is non-zero), we obtain a quadratic equation:
\[1 + u^2 = u,\]
which can be rearranged into the standard form:
\[u^2 - u + 1 = 0.\]
We solve for $u$ using the quadratic formula, $u = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a}$, with $a=1, b=-1, c=1$. The discriminant is $b^2 - 4ac = (-1)^2 - 4(1)(1) = 1 - 4 = -3$. The solutions for $u$ are therefore:
\[u = \frac{1 \pm \sqrt{-3}}{2} = \frac{1 \pm i\sqrt{3}}{2}.\]
So, $u$ must be one of two values: $u_1 = \frac{1}{2} + i\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}$ or $u_2 = \frac{1}{2} - i\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}$.

Our goal is to find the value of $|z_1 - z_2|^2$. We can factor $z_1$ out of the expression:
\[z_1 - z_2 = z_1 \left(1 - \frac{z_2}{z_1}\right) = z_1(1 - u).\]
Using the property that the modulus of a product is the product of the moduli, we have:
\[|z_1 - z_2| = |z_1(1-u)| = |z_1| \cdot |1-u|.\]
We are given $|z_1| = 5$. Now we must find $|1-u|$. We consider the two possible cases for $u$.

**Case 1:** $u = \frac{1}{2} + i\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}$.
In this case,
\[1 - u = 1 - \left(\frac{1}{2} + i\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right) = \frac{1}{2} - i\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}.\]
The modulus of this complex number is:
\[|1 - u| = \sqrt{\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^2 + \left(-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right)^2} = \sqrt{\frac{1}{4} + \frac{3}{4}} = \sqrt{1} = 1.\]

**Case 2:** $u = \frac{1}{2} - i\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}$.
In this case,
\[1 - u = 1 - \left(\frac{1}{2} - i\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right) = \frac{1}{2} + i\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}.\]
The modulus is:
\[|1 - u| = \sqrt{\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^2 + \left(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right)^2} = \sqrt{\frac{1}{4} + \frac{3}{4}} = \sqrt{1} = 1.\]

In both cases, we find that $|1-u| = 1$.

Now we can complete the calculation for $|z_1 - z_2|^2$:
\begin{align*} |z_1 - z_2|^2 &= (|z_1| \cdot |1-u|)^2 \\ &= (5 \cdot 1)^2 \\ &= 5^2 \\ &= 25. \end{align*}
Thus, we have shown that $|z_1 - z_2|^2 = 25$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $z_1$ and $z_2$ be two complex numbers such that $|z_1| = 5$ and
\[\frac{z_1}{z_2} + \frac{z_2}{z_1} = 1.\]Find $|z_20495 - z_2|^2.$ -/
theorem algebra_20495 {z1 z2 : ‚ÑÇ} (hz1 : ‚Äñz1‚Äñ = 5) (hz2 : z2 ‚â† 0)
    (h : z1 / z2 + z2 / z1 = 1) : ‚Äñz1 - z2‚Äñ ^ 2 = 25 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

/- Let $z_1$ and $z_2$ be two complex numbers such that $|z_1| = 5$ and
\[\frac{z_1}{z_2} + \frac{z_2}{z_1} = 1.\]Find $|z_20495 - z_2|^2.$ -/
theorem algebra_20495 {z1 z2 : ‚ÑÇ} (hz1 : ‚Äñz1‚Äñ = 5) (hz2 : z2 ‚â† 0)
    (h : z1 / z2 + z2 / z1 = 1) : ‚Äñz1 - z2‚Äñ ^ 2 = 25 := by
  -- Let u = z2 / z1
  let u := z2 / z1
  -- The equation becomes u + u‚Åª¬π = 1
  replace h : u + u‚Åª¬π = 1 := by
    simp [u]
    linear_combination h
  -- u cannot be 0, as 0 + 0‚Åª¬π ‚â† 1
  have un0 : u ‚â† 0 := by
    intro hu
    simp [hu] at h
  field_simp at h
  -- Replace h as the standard form of a quadratic equation
  replace h : 1 * u * u + (-1) * u + 1 = 0 := by linear_combination h
  -- Write the discriminant of the quadratic equation as the square of a complex number
  have k : (discrim 1 (-1) 1 : ‚ÑÇ) = {re := 0, im := ‚àö3} * {re := 0, im := ‚àö3} := by
    simp [discrim]
    change (1 - 4 : ‚ÑÇ) = {re := 0 * 0 - ‚àö3 * ‚àö3, im := 0 * ‚àö3 + ‚àö3 * 0}
    norm_num
    apply Complex.ext <;> simp
  -- Solve the quadratic equation using the quadratic formula
  rw [mul_assoc, quadratic_eq_zero_iff (show (1 : ‚ÑÇ) ‚â† 0 by norm_num) k] at h
  -- The two solutions are (1 ¬± ‚àö3 i) / 2
  simp at h
  have h1 : (1 + { re := 0, im := ‚àö3 }) / (2 : ‚ÑÇ) = { re := 1 / 2, im := ‚àö3 / 2 } := by
    apply Complex.ext <;> simp
  have h2 : (1 - { re := 0, im := ‚àö3 }) / (2 : ‚ÑÇ) = { re := 1 / 2, im := -‚àö3 / 2 } := by
    apply Complex.ext <;> simp
  rw [h1, h2] at h
  clear k h1 h2

  -- ‚Äñ1 - u‚Äñ = 1, no matter which solution u is
  have hu : ‚Äñ1 - u‚Äñ = 1 := by
    -- Calculate ‚Äñ1 - u‚Äñ ^ 2
    simp [Complex.abs, Complex.normSq]
    clear_value u
    clear z1 z2 hz1 hz2 un0
    -- Case analysis on the two solutions
    rcases h with (rfl | rfl)
    all_goals
      -- Simplify the expression
      simp
      ring_nf
      norm_num

  -- Finally, calculate ‚Äñz1 - z2‚Äñ ^ 2
  calc ‚Äñz1 - z2‚Äñ ^ 2
       -- z1 - z2 = z1 * (1 - u)
       _ = ‚Äñz1 * (1 - u)‚Äñ ^ 2 := by
         congr
         simp only [u]
         field_simp [show z1 ‚â† 0 by rintro rfl; simp at hz1]
       -- Use the multiplicative property of the norm
       _ = (‚Äñz1‚Äñ * ‚Äñ1 - u‚Äñ) ^ 2 := by rw [norm_mul]
       -- Plug in the values of ‚Äñz1‚Äñ and ‚Äñ1 - u‚Äñ
       _ = (5 * 1) ^ 2 := by rw [hz1, hu]
       -- Simplify
       _ = 25 := by norm_num

soln_description:
I. solution. We will show that the difference $k$ obtained by subtracting the right side from the left side of the inequality cannot be negative. If we replace $a$ with $b$, $b$ with $c$, $c$ with $a$, or $a$ with $c$, $c$ with $b$, $b$ with $a$, only the order of the terms in the difference changes, so we can assume that the smallest value occurring in the triplet is

$$
x=b-a \geq 0 \quad \text { and } \quad y=c-a \geq 0
$$

Express $k$ using $a, x$, and $y$:

$$
\begin{aligned}
k & =a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}-a^{2} b-b^{2} c-c^{2} a=a^{3}+(a+x)^{3}+ \\
& +(a+y)^{3}-a^{2}(a+x)-(a+x)^{2}(a+y)-(a+y)^{2} a= \\
& =2 a\left(x^{2}-x y+y^{2}\right)+\left(x^{3}-x^{2} y+y^{3}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Neither of the bracketed expressions can be negative, as the following transformations show:

if $x \geq y$, then

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x^{2}-x y+y^{2}=x(x-y)+y^{2} \geq 0, \quad \text { and } \\
& x^{3}-x^{2} y+y^{3}=x^{2}(x-y)+y^{3} \geq 0 ;
\end{aligned}
$$

if, however, $x < y$, then

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x^{2}-x y+y^{2}=y(y-x)+x^{2}>0, \quad \text { and } \\
& x^{3}-x^{2} y+y^{3}=x^{3}+y\left(y^{2}-x^{2}\right)>0
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, $k$ cannot be negative in either case.

From the above transformations, it is clear that $k$ can only be 0 if both bracketed expressions are 0. This holds if $x=y$ and their common value is 0, i.e., if $a=b=c$.

II. solution. According to the introductory consideration of the previous solution, we can assume that the number $c$ is not smaller than either $a$ or $b$. We transform the difference $k$ between the left and right sides as follows:

$$
\begin{aligned}
k & =a^{2}(a-b)+b^{2}(b-c)+c^{2}(c-a)= \\
& =a^{2}(a-b)-b^{2}[(c-a)+(a-b)]+c^{2}(c-a)= \\
& =\left(a^{2}-b^{2}\right)(a-b)+\left(c^{2}-b^{2}\right)(c-a) \\
& =(a+b)(a-b)^{2}+(c+b)(c-b)(c-a)
\end{aligned}
$$

Here, neither term is negative, because neither the square of the difference in the first term nor the differences in the second term are negative, so $k \geq 0$.

$k=0$ holds if and only if both terms are 0, i.e., if $a-b=0$, or $a=b$, which makes the second term's second and third factors equal, and their common value is also 0, i.e., if and only if $a=b=c$.

Remarks. 1. The statement of the problem easily follows from the following theorem by Adolf Sz√ºcs: Let $x_{1} \geq x_{2} \geq \ldots \geq x_{n} \geq 0, y_{1} \geq y_{2} \geq \ldots \geq y_{n} \geq 0$, and let $z_{1}, z_{2}, \ldots, z_{n}$ be the numbers $y_{1}, y_{2}, \ldots, y_{n}$ arranged in any order, then

$$
\begin{gathered}
x_{1} y_{1}+x_{2} y_{2}+\ldots+x_{n} y_{n} \geq x_{1} z_{1}+x_{2} z_{2}+\ldots+x_{n} z_{n} \geq \\
\geq x_{1} y_{n}+x_{2} y_{n-1}+\ldots+x_{n-1} y_{2}+x_{n} y_{1}
\end{gathered}
$$

From this, the statement of our problem follows as follows: Let $n=3$, and further, let us still assume that $a \leq b, a \leq c$. If $b \leq c$, let $x_{1}=c^{2}, x_{2}=b^{2}, x_{3}=a^{2}, y_{1}=c, y_{2}=b, y_{3}=a, z_{1}=a, z_{2}=c, z_{3}=b$. If, however, $b>c$, then let $x_{1}=b^{2}$, $x_{2}=c^{2}, x_{3}=a^{2}, y_{1}=b, y_{2}=c, y_{3}=a, z_{1}=c, z_{2}=a, z_{3}=b$. The first inequality above gives the statement of the problem in both cases.

2. The correctness of the inequality can be shown without any restrictions on the size of the numbers, for example, based on the following identity:

$$
\begin{gathered}
a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}-a^{2} b-b^{2} c-c^{2} a= \\
=\frac{1}{3}\left[(a-b)^{2}(2 a+b)+(b-c)^{2}(2 b+c)+(c-a)^{2}(2 c+a)\right]
\end{gathered}
$$[^0]


[^0]:    ${ }^{1}$ V. ed.: Haj√≥s Gy.-Neukomm Gy.-Sur√°nyi J.: Mathematical Competition Problems II. 2nd edition, Tank√∂nyvkiad√≥, Budapest, 1966. p. 44.
informal_statement: Prove that if $a, b, c$ are positive numbers, then $a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3} \geq a^{2} b+b^{2} c+c^{2} a$. - When does equality hold?
informal_proof:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers. We want to prove two statements: first, the inequality $a^3 + b^3 + c^3 \geq a^2 b + b^2 c + c^2 a$, and second, that equality holds if and only if $a = b = c$.

**Part 1: The Inequality**

To prove the inequality, we consider the difference between the left-hand side and the right-hand side. The inequality is equivalent to showing that $a^3 + b^3 + c^3 - a^2 b - b^2 c - c^2 a \geq 0$.

Consider the following algebraic identity:
$$a^3 + b^3 + c^3 - a^2 b - b^2 c - c^2 a = \frac{1}{3} \left[ (a-b)^2(2a+b) + (b-c)^2(2b+c) + (c-a)^2(2c+a) \right]$$

We will show that the expression on the right-hand side is non-negative.
1.  For any real numbers $x$ and $y$, the square of their difference, $(x-y)^2$, is always non-negative. Thus, $(a-b)^2 \ge 0$, $(b-c)^2 \ge 0$, and $(c-a)^2 \ge 0$.
2.  Since $a, b, c$ are given to be positive, the sums $(2a+b)$, $(2b+c)$, and $(2c+a)$ are all strictly positive.
3.  The product of a non-negative number and a positive number is non-negative. Therefore, each term in the sum is non-negative:
    *   $(a-b)^2(2a+b) \geq 0$
    *   $(b-c)^2(2b+c) \geq 0$
    *   $(c-a)^2(2c+a) \geq 0$
4.  The sum of non-negative numbers is non-negative.

Thus, the entire expression on the right-hand side is non-negative, which implies $a^3 + b^3 + c^3 - a^2 b - b^2 c - c^2 a \geq 0$. This establishes the inequality.

**Part 2: The Condition for Equality**

We now prove that $a^3 + b^3 + c^3 = a^2 b + b^2 c + c^2 a$ if and only if $a=b$ and $b=c$.

**($\implies$) First, assume that equality holds:**
$$a^3 + b^3 + c^3 = a^2 b + b^2 c + c^2 a$$
This implies that the difference is zero:
$$a^3 + b^3 + c^3 - a^2 b - b^2 c - c^2 a = 0$$
Using the identity from Part 1, we have:
$$\frac{1}{3} \left[ (a-b)^2(2a+b) + (b-c)^2(2b+c) + (c-a)^2(2c+a) \right] = 0$$
As established earlier, each term in the sum is non-negative. A sum of non-negative terms can only be zero if each term is individually zero. Therefore, we must have:
1.  $(a-b)^2(2a+b) = 0$
2.  $(b-c)^2(2b+c) = 0$

From equation (1), since $a, b > 0$, we know that $2a+b > 0$. For the product to be zero, we must have $(a-b)^2 = 0$, which implies $a-b=0$, so $a=b$.

From equation (2), since $b, c > 0$, we know that $2b+c > 0$. For the product to be zero, we must have $(b-c)^2 = 0$, which implies $b-c=0$, so $b=c$.

Thus, if equality holds, it follows that $a=b$ and $b=c$.

**($\impliedby$) Next, assume that $a=b$ and $b=c$.**
This means $a=b=c$. We substitute $b=a$ and $c=a$ into the original equation.

The left-hand side becomes:
$$a^3 + b^3 + c^3 = a^3 + a^3 + a^3 = 3a^3$$

The right-hand side becomes:
$$a^2 b + b^2 c + c^2 a = a^2(a) + a^2(a) + a^2(a) = a^3 + a^3 + a^3 = 3a^3$$

Since both sides are equal to $3a^3$, the equality $a^3 + b^3 + c^3 = a^2 b + b^2 c + c^2 a$ holds true.

This completes the proof of both the inequality and the condition for equality.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Prove that if $a, b, c$ are positive numbers, then $a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3} \geq a^{2} b+b^{2} c+c^{2} a$. - When does equality hold? -/
theorem inequalities_202485 (a b c : ‚Ñù) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c) :
    a^3 + b^3 + c^3 ‚â• a^2 * b + b^2 * c + c^2 * a ‚àß
    (a^3 + b^3 + c^3 = a^2 * b + b^2 * c + c^2 * a ‚Üî a = b ‚àß b = c) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem inequalities_202485 (a b c : ‚Ñù) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c) :
    a^3 + b^3 + c^3 ‚â• a^2 * b + b^2 * c + c^2 * a ‚àß
    (a^3 + b^3 + c^3 = a^2 * b + b^2 * c + c^2 * a ‚Üî a = b ‚àß b = c) := by

  constructor
  ¬∑ -- Prove that a^3 + b^3 + c^3 ‚â• a^2 * b + b^2 * c + c^2 * a
    nlinarith [sq_nonneg (a - b), sq_nonneg (b - c), sq_nonneg (c - a), sq_nonneg (a - b), sq_nonneg (a - c), sq_nonneg (b - c),
        mul_pos ha hb, mul_pos hb hc, mul_pos ha hc
    ]
  ¬∑ -- Prove that a^3 + b^3 + c^3 = a^2 * b + b^2 * c + c^2 * a ‚Üî a = b ‚àß b = c
    constructor
    ¬∑ -- Forward: equality implies a = b ‚àß b = c
      intro heq
      have h1 : (a - b) ^ 2 = 0 := by
        nlinarith [sq_nonneg (a - b), sq_nonneg (b - c), sq_nonneg (c - a),
          mul_pos ha hb, mul_pos hb hc, mul_pos ha hc, heq
        ]
      have h2 : (b - c) ^ 2 = 0 := by
        nlinarith [sq_nonneg (a - b), sq_nonneg (b - c), sq_nonneg (c - a),
            mul_pos ha hb, mul_pos hb hc, mul_pos ha hc, heq
          ]
      have h3 : a - b = 0 := by
        nlinarith [h1
        ]
      have h4 : b - c = 0 := by
        nlinarith [h2
        ]
      constructor
      ¬∑ -- Show that a = b
        linarith
      ¬∑ -- Show that b = c
        linarith
    ¬∑ -- Backward: a = b ‚àß b = c implies equality
      rintro ‚ü®rfl, rfl‚ü©
      all_goals
        nlinarith

informal_statement: The polynomial $x^3 - 3x^2 + 4x - 1$ is a factor of $x^9 + px^6 + qx^3 + r.$  Enter the ordered triple $(p,q,r).$
informal_proof:
Let the given polynomials be $f(x) = x^3 - 3x^2 + 4x - 1$ and $g(x) = x^9 + px^6 + qx^3 + r$. The condition that $f(x)$ is a factor of $g(x)$ means that $g(x) \equiv 0 \pmod{f(x)}$. Our strategy is to reduce $g(x)$ modulo $f(x)$ to a polynomial of degree less than 3, and then set this remainder to the zero polynomial.

From the definition of $f(x)$, we have $x^3 - 3x^2 + 4x - 1 \equiv 0 \pmod{f(x)}$, which gives us the fundamental reduction rule:
$x^3 \equiv 3x^2 - 4x + 1 \pmod{f(x)}$.

We use this rule to find expressions for higher powers of $x$ modulo $f(x)$.

First, for $x^4$:
$x^4 = x \cdot x^3 \equiv x(3x^2 - 4x + 1) = 3x^3 - 4x^2 + x$.
Substituting for $x^3$ again:
$3(3x^2 - 4x + 1) - 4x^2 + x = 9x^2 - 12x + 3 - 4x^2 + x = 5x^2 - 11x + 3$.
So, $x^4 \equiv 5x^2 - 11x + 3 \pmod{f(x)}$.

Next, for $x^6$:
$x^6 = (x^3)^2 \equiv (3x^2 - 4x + 1)^2 = 9x^4 - 24x^3 + 22x^2 - 8x + 1$.
We substitute our known congruences for $x^4$ and $x^3$:
$9(5x^2 - 11x + 3) - 24(3x^2 - 4x + 1) + 22x^2 - 8x + 1$
$= (45x^2 - 99x + 27) - (72x^2 - 96x + 24) + 22x^2 - 8x + 1$
$= (45 - 72 + 22)x^2 + (-99 + 96 - 8)x + (27 - 24 + 1)$
$= -5x^2 - 11x + 4$.
So, $x^6 \equiv -5x^2 - 11x + 4 \pmod{f(x)}$.

Finally, for $x^9$:
$x^9 = x^3 \cdot x^6 \equiv (3x^2 - 4x + 1)(-5x^2 - 11x + 4)$.
Expanding this product:
$-15x^4 - 33x^3 + 12x^2 + 20x^3 + 44x^2 - 16x - 5x^2 - 11x + 4$
$= -15x^4 - 13x^3 + 51x^2 - 27x + 4$.
Now, we substitute the congruences for $x^4$ and $x^3$:
$-15(5x^2 - 11x + 3) - 13(3x^2 - 4x + 1) + 51x^2 - 27x + 4$
$= (-75x^2 + 165x - 45) - (39x^2 - 52x + 13) + 51x^2 - 27x + 4$
$= (-75 - 39 + 51)x^2 + (165 + 52 - 27)x + (-45 - 13 + 4)$
$= -63x^2 + 190x - 54$.
So, $x^9 \equiv -63x^2 + 190x - 54 \pmod{f(x)}$.

Now we can reduce $g(x)$ modulo $f(x)$:
$g(x) = x^9 + px^6 + qx^3 + r$
$\equiv (-63x^2 + 190x - 54) + p(-5x^2 - 11x + 4) + q(3x^2 - 4x + 1) + r \pmod{f(x)}$.

Collecting terms by powers of $x$, we get the remainder polynomial $R(x)$:
$R(x) = (-63 - 5p + 3q)x^2 + (190 - 11p - 4q)x + (-54 + 4p + q + r)$.

Since $f(x)$ divides $g(x)$, the remainder $R(x)$ must be the zero polynomial. A polynomial is zero if and only if all its coefficients are zero. This gives us a system of three linear equations:
1.  $-5p + 3q - 63 = 0$
2.  $-11p - 4q + 190 = 0$
3.  $4p + q + r - 54 = 0$

We solve this system. From the first two equations, we can eliminate $q$. Multiplying (1) by 4 and (2) by 3:
$4(-5p + 3q - 63) = -20p + 12q - 252 = 0$
$3(-11p - 4q + 190) = -33p - 12q + 570 = 0$
Adding these two new equations gives:
$(-20p - 33p) + (12q - 12q) + (-252 + 570) = 0$
$-53p + 318 = 0 \implies 53p = 318 \implies p = 6$.

Substitute $p=6$ into equation (1):
$-5(6) + 3q - 63 = 0 \implies -30 + 3q - 63 = 0 \implies 3q = 93 \implies q = 31$.

Substitute $p=6$ and $q=31$ into equation (3):
$4(6) + 31 + r - 54 = 0 \implies 24 + 31 + r - 54 = 0 \implies 55 + r - 54 = 0 \implies r + 1 = 0 \implies r = -1$.

Thus, the unique solution is $p=6$, $q=31$, and $r=-1$. The ordered triple is $(6, 31, -1)$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/-The polynomial $x^3 - 3x^2 + 4x - 1$ is a factor of $x^9 + px^6 + qx^3 + r.$  Enter the ordered triple $(p,q,r).$-/
theorem algebra_22609 {p q r : ‚Ñù} (h : Polynomial.X ^ 3 - 3 * Polynomial.X ^ 2 + 4 * Polynomial.X - (1 : Polynomial ‚Ñù) ‚à£ (Polynomial.X ^ 9 + Polynomial.C p * Polynomial.X ^ 6 + Polynomial.C q * Polynomial.X ^ 3 + Polynomial.C r)) :
    p = 6 ‚àß q = 31 ‚àß r = -1 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

/-The polynomial $x^3 - 3x^2 + 4x - 1$ is a factor of $x^9 + px^6 + qx^3 + r.$  Enter the ordered triple $(p,q,r).$-/
theorem algebra_22609 {p q r : ‚Ñù} (h : Polynomial.X ^ 3 - 3 * Polynomial.X ^ 2 + 4 * Polynomial.X - (1 : Polynomial ‚Ñù) ‚à£ (Polynomial.X ^ 9 + Polynomial.C p * Polynomial.X ^ 6 + Polynomial.C q * Polynomial.X ^ 3 + Polynomial.C r)) :
    p = 6 ‚àß q = 31 ‚àß r = -1 := by
  -- set f := x^3 - 3x^2 + 4x - 1
  set f := Polynomial.X ^ 3 - 3 * Polynomial.X ^ 2 + 4 * Polynomial.X - (1 : Polynomial ‚Ñù) with hf
  -- actually show that X ^ 3 ‚â° 3 * X ^ 2 - 4 * X + 1 [ZMOD f]
  have eq3 (g h : Polynomial ‚Ñù) (h1 : f ‚à£ h * Polynomial.X ^ 3 + g) : f ‚à£ h * (3 * Polynomial.X ^ 2 - 4 * Polynomial.X + 1) + g := by
    have h2 : f ‚à£ h * (Polynomial.X ^ 3 - f) + g := by
      rw [mul_sub]
      rw [sub_add_eq_add_sub]
      simp [dvd_sub, show f ‚à£ h * f by exact dvd_mul_left f h, h1]
    ring_nf at h2 ‚ä¢
    exact h2

  -- show that X ^ 4 ‚â° 5 * X ^ 2 - 11 * X + 3 [ZMOD f]
  have eq4 (g h : Polynomial ‚Ñù) (h1 : f ‚à£ h * Polynomial.X ^ 4 + g) : f ‚à£ h * (5 * Polynomial.X ^ 2 - 11 * Polynomial.X + 3) + g := by
    -- substitute one of the X ^ 3
    replace h1 : f ‚à£ h * Polynomial.X * Polynomial.X ^ 3 + g := by
      ring_nf at h1 ‚ä¢
      exact h1
    -- simplify the expression to the form of eq3
    apply eq3 at h1
    replace h1 : f ‚à£ h * 3 * Polynomial.X ^ 3 + (-h * 4 * Polynomial.X ^ 2 + h * Polynomial.X + g) := by
      ring_nf at h1 ‚ä¢
      exact h1
    -- substitute the X ^ 3
    apply eq3 at h1
    ring_nf at h1 ‚ä¢
    exact h1

  -- show that X ^ 6 ‚â° -5 * X ^ 2 - 11 * X + 4 [ZMOD f]
  have eq6 (g h : Polynomial ‚Ñù) (h1 : f ‚à£ h * Polynomial.X ^ 6 + g) : f ‚à£ h * (-5 * Polynomial.X ^ 2 - 11 * Polynomial.X + 4) + g := by
    -- simplify the expression to the form of eq3
    replace h1 : f ‚à£ h * Polynomial.X ^ 3 * Polynomial.X ^ 3 + g := by
      ring_nf at h1 ‚ä¢
      exact h1
    -- substitute one of the X ^ 3
    apply eq3 at h1
    -- simplify the expression to the form of eq3
    replace h1 : f ‚à£ h * (3 * Polynomial.X ^ 2 - 4 * Polynomial.X + 1) * Polynomial.X ^ 3 + g := by
      ring_nf at h1 ‚ä¢
      exact h1
    -- substitute the X ^ 3
    apply eq3 at h1
    -- expand the expression
    replace h1 : f ‚à£ h * (9 * Polynomial.X ^ 4 - 24 * Polynomial.X ^ 3 + 22 * Polynomial.X ^ 2 - 8 * Polynomial.X + 1) + g := by
      ring_nf at h1 ‚ä¢
      exact h1
    -- simplify the expression to the form of eq3
    replace h1 : f ‚à£ h * 9 * Polynomial.X ^ 4 +(h * (-24 * Polynomial.X ^ 3 + 22 * Polynomial.X ^ 2 - 8 * Polynomial.X + 1) + g) := by
      ring_nf at h1 ‚ä¢
      exact h1
    -- substitute one of the X ^ 4
    apply eq4 at h1
    -- simplify the expression to the form of eq3
    replace h1 : f ‚à£ h * (-24) * Polynomial.X ^ 3 + (h * 9 * (5 * Polynomial.X ^ 2 -11 * Polynomial.X + 3) + h * (22 * Polynomial.X ^ 2 - 8 * Polynomial.X + 1) + g) := by
      ring_nf at h1 ‚ä¢
      exact h1
    -- substitute the X ^ 3
    apply eq3 at h1
    ring_nf at h1 ‚ä¢
    exact h1
  -- show that X ^ 9 ‚â° -63 * X ^ 2 + 190 * X - 54 [ZMOD f]
  have eq9 (g h : Polynomial ‚Ñù) (h1 : f ‚à£ h * Polynomial.X ^ 9 + g) : f ‚à£ h * (-63 * Polynomial.X ^ 2 + 190 * Polynomial.X - 54) + g := by
    -- simplify the expression to the form of eq6
    replace h1 : f ‚à£ h * Polynomial.X ^ 3 * Polynomial.X ^ 6 + g := by
      ring_nf at h1 ‚ä¢
      exact h1
    -- substitute the X ^ 6
    apply eq6 at h1
    -- simplify the expression to the form of eq3
    replace h1 : f ‚à£ h * (-5 * Polynomial.X ^ 2 - 11 * Polynomial.X + 4) * Polynomial.X ^ 3 + g := by
      ring_nf at h1 ‚ä¢
      exact h1
    -- substitute the X ^ 3
    apply eq3 at h1
    -- expand the expression
    replace h1 : f ‚à£ h * (-15 * Polynomial.X ^ 4 - 13 * Polynomial.X ^ 3 + 51 * Polynomial.X ^ 2 - 27 * Polynomial.X + 4) + g := by
      ring_nf at h1 ‚ä¢
      exact h1
    -- simplify the expression to the form of eq4
    replace h1 : f ‚à£ h * (-15) * Polynomial.X ^ 4 + (h * (-13) * Polynomial.X ^ 3 + h * 51 * Polynomial.X ^ 2 + h * (-27) * Polynomial.X + h * 4 + g) := by
      ring_nf at h1 ‚ä¢
      exact h1
    -- substitute the X ^ 4
    apply eq4 at h1
    -- simplify the expression to the form of eq3
    replace h1 : f ‚à£ h * (-13) * Polynomial.X ^ 3 + (h * (-15) * (5 * Polynomial.X ^ 2 - 11 * Polynomial.X + 3) + h * 51 * Polynomial.X ^ 2 + h * (-27) * Polynomial.X + h * 4 + g) := by
      ring_nf at h1 ‚ä¢
      exact h1
    -- substitute the X ^ 3
    apply eq3 at h1
    ring_nf at h1 ‚ä¢
    exact h1
  -- show that X ^ 9 + p * X ^ 6 + q * X ^ 3 + r ‚â° (-5*p + 3*q - 63) * X ^ 2 + (-11*p - 4*q + 190) * X + (4*p + q + r - 54) [ZMOD f]
  replace h : f ‚à£ ((-5 * Polynomial.C p + 3 * Polynomial.C q - 63) * Polynomial.X ^ 2 + (-11 * Polynomial.C p - 4 * Polynomial.C q + 190) * Polynomial.X + (4 * Polynomial.C p + Polynomial.C q + Polynomial.C r - 54)) := by
    -- simplify the expression to the form of eq9
    replace h : f ‚à£ 1 * Polynomial.X ^ 9 + (Polynomial.C p * Polynomial.X ^ 6 + Polynomial.C q * Polynomial.X ^ 3 + Polynomial.C r) := by
      ring_nf at h ‚ä¢
      exact h
    -- substitute the X ^ 9
    apply eq9 at h
    -- simplify the expression to the form of eq6
    replace h : f ‚à£ Polynomial.C p * Polynomial.X ^ 6 + ((-63 * Polynomial.X ^ 2 + 190 * Polynomial.X - 54) + Polynomial.C q * Polynomial.X ^ 3 + Polynomial.C r) := by
      ring_nf at h ‚ä¢
      exact h
    -- substitute the X ^ 6
    apply eq6 at h
    -- simplify the expression to the form of eq3
    replace h : f ‚à£ Polynomial.C q * Polynomial.X ^ 3 + (Polynomial.C p * (-5 * Polynomial.X ^ 2 - 11 * Polynomial.X + 4) + (-63 * Polynomial.X ^ 2 + 190 * Polynomial.X - 54) + Polynomial.C r) := by
      ring_nf at h ‚ä¢
      exact h
    -- substitute the X ^ 3 and expand
    apply eq3 at h
    ring_nf at h ‚ä¢
    exact h

  -- set g := (-5 * p + 3 * q - 63) * X ^ 2 + (-11 * p - 4 * q + 190) * X + (4 * p + q + r - 54)
  set g := (-5 * Polynomial.C p + 3 * Polynomial.C q - 63) * Polynomial.X ^ 2 + (-11 * Polynomial.C p - 4 * Polynomial.C q + 190) * Polynomial.X + (4 * Polynomial.C p + Polynomial.C q + Polynomial.C r - 54) with hg
  clear eq3 eq4 eq6 eq9
  -- this part, we want to show that g = 0
  -- firstly show that degree of f is 3
  have degreef : f.natDegree = 3 := by
    simp [hf]
    -- show that degree of X ^ 3 - 3 * X ^ 2 is 3
    have degree : (Polynomial.X ^ 3 - 3 * Polynomial.X ^ 2 : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree = 3 := by
      calc
        (Polynomial.X ^ 3 - 3 * Polynomial.X ^ 2 : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree = (Polynomial.X ^ 3 : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree := by
          apply Polynomial.natDegree_sub_eq_left_of_natDegree_lt
          calc
            (Polynomial.C 3 * Polynomial.X ^ 2 : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree = 2 := by simp [Polynomial.natDegree_X_pow]
            _ < 3 := by norm_num
            _ = (Polynomial.X ^ 3 : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree := by rw [Polynomial.natDegree_X_pow]
        _ = 3 := by rw [Polynomial.natDegree_X_pow]
    -- show that degree of X ^ 3 - 3 * X ^ 2 + 4 * X is 3
    replace degree : (Polynomial.X ^ 3 - 3 * Polynomial.X ^ 2 + 4 * Polynomial.X : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree = 3 := by
      -- show that degree of 4 * X is 1
      have degree‚ÇÅ : (4 * Polynomial.X : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree = 1 := by
        simp [Polynomial.natDegree_X_pow]
      -- combine the degree of X ^ 3 - 3 * X ^ 2 and 4 * X
      nth_rewrite 2 [<-degree]
      apply Polynomial.natDegree_add_eq_left_of_natDegree_lt
      rw [degree‚ÇÅ, degree]
      norm_num
    -- finally show that degree of X ^ 3 - 3 * X ^ 2 + 4 * X - 1 is 3
    nth_rewrite 2 [<-degree]
    apply Polynomial.natDegree_sub_eq_left_of_natDegree_lt
    simp [Polynomial.natDegree_C]
    rw [degree]
    norm_num

  -- show that degree of g is at most 2
  have degreeg : g.natDegree ‚â§ 2 := by
    -- show that degree of (-5 * p + 3 * q - 63) * X ^ 2 is at most 2
    have degree2 : ((-(5 * Polynomial.C p) + 3 * Polynomial.C q - 63) * Polynomial.X ^ 2 : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree ‚â§ 2 := by
      calc -- first split the multiplication
        ((-(5 * Polynomial.C p) + 3 * Polynomial.C q - 63) * Polynomial.X ^ 2 : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree ‚â§ (-(5 * Polynomial.C p) + 3 * Polynomial.C q - 63 : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree + (Polynomial.X ^ 2 : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree := by apply Polynomial.natDegree_mul_le
        _ ‚â§ 2 := by
          -- rewrite the degree of X ^ 2
          rw [Polynomial.natDegree_X_pow]
          -- show that the degree of (-5 * p + 3 * q - 63) is at most 0
          -- first show that the degree of -5 * p is at most 0
          have degree‚ÇÄ : (-(5 * Polynomial.C p) : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree ‚â§ 0 := by
            calc
              (-(5 * Polynomial.C p) : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree = (5 * Polynomial.C p : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree := by
                simp [Polynomial.natDegree_neg]
              _ ‚â§ (5 : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree + (Polynomial.C p : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree := by
                apply Polynomial.natDegree_mul_le
              _ = 0 := by
                simp [Polynomial.natDegree_C]
          -- show that the degree of 3 * q is at most 0
          have degree‚ÇÅ : (3 * Polynomial.C q : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree ‚â§ 0 := by
            calc
              (3 * Polynomial.C q : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree ‚â§ (3 : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree + (Polynomial.C q : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree := by
                apply Polynomial.natDegree_mul_le
              _ = 0 := by
                simp [Polynomial.natDegree_C]
          -- combine both of above, show that the degree of (-5 * p + 3 * q) is at most 0
          have degree‚ÇÇ : (-(5 * Polynomial.C p) + 3 * Polynomial.C q : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree ‚â§ 0 := by
            calc
              (-(5 * Polynomial.C p) + 3 * Polynomial.C q : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree ‚â§ max (-(5 * Polynomial.C p) : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree (3 * Polynomial.C q : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree := by
                apply Polynomial.natDegree_add_le
              _ ‚â§ 0 := by
                rw [Nat.max_le]; tauto
          -- show that the degree of (-5 * p + 3 * q - 63) is at most 0
          have degree‚ÇÉ : (-(5 * Polynomial.C p) + 3 * Polynomial.C q - 63 : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree ‚â§ 0 := by
            calc
              (-(5 * Polynomial.C p) + 3 * Polynomial.C q - 63 : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree ‚â§ max (-(5 * Polynomial.C p) + 3 * Polynomial.C q : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree (63 : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree := by
                apply Polynomial.natDegree_sub_le
              _ ‚â§ 0 := by
                rw [Nat.max_le]
                have _ : (63 : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree ‚â§ 0 := by
                  simp [Polynomial.natDegree_C]
                tauto
          simp [degree‚ÇÉ]

    -- show that degree of (-11 * p - 4 * q + 190) * X is at most 1
    have degree1 : ((-11 * Polynomial.C p - 4 * Polynomial.C q + 190) * Polynomial.X).natDegree ‚â§ 1 := by
      calc -- first split the multiplication
        ((-11 * Polynomial.C p - 4 * Polynomial.C q + 190) * Polynomial.X : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree ‚â§ ((-11 * Polynomial.C p - 4 * Polynomial.C q + 190) : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree + (Polynomial.X : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree := by
          apply Polynomial.natDegree_mul_le
        _ ‚â§ 1 := by
          -- rewrite the degree of X
          rw [Polynomial.natDegree_X]
          -- show that the degree of -11 * p is at most 0
          have degree‚ÇÄ : (-11 * Polynomial.C p : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree ‚â§ 0 := by
            calc
              (-11 * Polynomial.C p : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree ‚â§ (-11 : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree + (Polynomial.C p : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree := by
                apply Polynomial.natDegree_mul_le
              _ = 0 := by
                simp [Polynomial.natDegree_C]
          -- show that the degree of 4 * q is at most 0
          have degree‚ÇÅ : (4 * Polynomial.C q : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree ‚â§ 0 := by
            calc
              (4 * Polynomial.C q : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree ‚â§ (4 : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree + (Polynomial.C q : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree := by
                apply Polynomial.natDegree_mul_le
              _ = 0 := by
                simp [Polynomial.natDegree_C]
          -- combine both of above, show that the degree of (-11 * p - 4 * q) is at most 0
          have degree‚ÇÇ : (-11 * Polynomial.C p - 4 * Polynomial.C q : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree ‚â§ 0 := by
            calc
              (-11 * Polynomial.C p - 4 * Polynomial.C q : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree ‚â§ max (-11 * Polynomial.C p : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree (4 * Polynomial.C q : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree := by
                apply Polynomial.natDegree_sub_le
              _ ‚â§ 0 := by
                rw [Nat.max_le]; tauto
          -- show that the degree of (-11 * p - 4 * q + 190) is at most 0
          have degree‚ÇÉ : (-11 * Polynomial.C p - 4 * Polynomial.C q + 190 : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree ‚â§ 0 := by
            calc
              (-11 * Polynomial.C p - 4 * Polynomial.C q + 190 : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree ‚â§ max (-11 * Polynomial.C p - 4 * Polynomial.C q : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree (190 : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree := by
                apply Polynomial.natDegree_add_le
              _ ‚â§ 0 := by
                rw [Nat.max_le]
                have _ : (190 : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree ‚â§ 0 := by
                  simp [Polynomial.natDegree_C]
                tauto
          -- finally show that the degree of (-11 * p - 4 * q + 190) * X is at most 1
          ring_nf at degree‚ÇÉ ‚ä¢
          simp [degree‚ÇÉ]

    -- show that degree of (4 * p + q + r - 54) is at most 0
    have degree0 : (4 * Polynomial.C p + Polynomial.C q + Polynomial.C r - 54 : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree ‚â§ 0 := by
      -- show that the degree of 4 * p is at most 0
      have degree‚ÇÅ : (4 * Polynomial.C p : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree ‚â§ 0 := by
        calc
          (4 * Polynomial.C p : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree ‚â§ (4 : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree + (Polynomial.C p : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree := by
            apply Polynomial.natDegree_mul_le
          _ = 0 := by
            simp [Polynomial.natDegree_C]
      -- show that the degree of 4 * p + q is at most 0
      have degree‚ÇÇ : (4 * Polynomial.C p + Polynomial.C q : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree ‚â§ 0 := by
        calc
          (4 * Polynomial.C p + Polynomial.C q : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree ‚â§ max (4 * Polynomial.C p : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree (Polynomial.C q : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree := by
            apply Polynomial.natDegree_add_le
          _ ‚â§ 0 := by
            rw [Nat.max_le]
            simp [degree‚ÇÅ, Polynomial.natDegree_C]
      --  show that the degree of 4 * p + q + r is at most 0
      have degree‚ÇÉ : (4 * Polynomial.C p + Polynomial.C q + Polynomial.C r : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree ‚â§ 0 := by
        calc
          (4 * Polynomial.C p + Polynomial.C q + Polynomial.C r : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree ‚â§ max (4 * Polynomial.C p + Polynomial.C q : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree (Polynomial.C r : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree := by
            apply Polynomial.natDegree_add_le
          _ ‚â§ 0 := by
            rw [Nat.max_le]
            have _ : (Polynomial.C r : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree ‚â§ 0 := by
              simp [Polynomial.natDegree_C]
            tauto
      -- show that the degree of 4 * p + q + r - 54 is at most 0
      have degree‚ÇÑ : (4 * Polynomial.C p + Polynomial.C q + Polynomial.C r - 54 : Polynomial ‚Ñù).natDegree ‚â§ 0 := by
        calc
