Since the function $z \mapsto \log_2 z$ is one-to-one, we can equate the arguments of the logarithms on both sides:
$$ \left(\frac{\log_2 x}{3}\right)^3 = \log_2 x $$
Expanding the term on the left side gives:
$$ \frac{(\log_2 x)^3}{27} = \log_2 x $$
Multiplying both sides by 27, we get:
$$ (\log_2 x)^3 = 27 \log_2 x $$
As established earlier, $\log_2 x > 0$ because $x > 1$. Since $\log_2 x$ is non-zero, we can safely divide both sides of the equation by $\log_2 x$:
$$ (\log_2 x)^2 = 27 $$
This is the desired result.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Find $(\log_2 x)^2$ if $\log_2 (\log_8 x) = \log_8 (\log_2 x).$ -/
theorem algebra_21388 {x : ‚Ñù} (hx : x > 1) (h : logb 2 (logb 8 x) = logb 8 (logb 2 x)) :
    (logb 2 x)^2 = 27 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Find $(\log_2 x)^2$ if $\log_2 (\log_8 x) = \log_8 (\log_2 x).$ -/
theorem algebra_21388 {x : ‚Ñù} (hx : x > 1) (h : logb 2 (logb 8 x) = logb 8 (logb 2 x)) :
    (logb 2 x)^2 = 27 := by
  -- We first show that logb 2 x is positive.
  have h‚ÇÄ : 0 < logb 2 x := logb_pos (by simp) hx
  -- We then show that logb 8 z = logb 2 z / 3 for all z.
  have lem (x : ‚Ñù) : logb 8 x = logb 2 x / 3 := by
    have h := Real.mul_logb (a := 2) (b := 8) (c := x)
    norm_num at h
    have h' : logb 2 8 = 3 := (logb_eq_iff_rpow_eq (by simp) (by simp) (by simp)).mpr (by norm_num)
    simp [‚Üê h, h']
  -- We use the lemma to rewrite the given equation.
  rw [lem, lem] at h
  cancel_denoms at h
  -- Rewrite 3 * logb 2 z as logb 2 (z ^ 3).
  nth_rw 1 [show (3 : ‚Ñù) = (3 : ‚Ñï) by simp, ‚Üê Real.logb_pow] at h
  -- Take the power of 2 on both sides.
  apply_fun ((2 : ‚Ñù) ^ ¬∑) at h
  -- Cancel 2 ^ logb 2 z on both sides.
  iterate 2 rw [Real.rpow_logb (by simp) (by simp) (by positivity)] at h
  -- Simple algebra.
  rw [show (logb 2 x / 3) ^ 3 = logb 2 x ^ 2 / 27 * logb 2 x by ring] at h
  simpa [ne_of_gt h‚ÇÄ, div_eq_one_iff_eq] using h

soln_description:
I. The right-hand side segmented decimal fractions in the solution of problem 1302 are converted into the ratios of two natural numbers $A / B$ and $C / D$, similar to the procedure seen in 1 1. The seventh decimal place of the first segmented decimal fraction marks the beginning of the infinite repetition of the 538461 segment. This is a consequence of the fact that when determining the digits of the $A: B$ ratio up to 6.6538461 (and already subtracting the partial product of 1 with $B$ from the partial dividend), the same remainder $R$ reappeared as it did after determining the digits of the ratio up to 6.6, except that in the latter case, the local value of $R$ is $1 / 10$, while in the case of repetition, it is $1 / 10000000 = 1 / 10^{7}$. Thus, the two remainder divisions yield the following expressions for the next representation of $A$:

$$
A = B \cdot 6.6 + R / 10
$$

$$
\text{or} \quad A = B \cdot 6.6538461 + R / 10^{7}
$$

Subtracting the first equality from the second, multiplied by $10^{6}$, gives the desired form:

$\left(10^{6}-1\right) A = B(6653846.1 - 6.6)$,

$$
\frac{A}{B} = \frac{66538461 - 66}{10 \cdot (10^{6} - 1)} = \frac{66538395}{9999990} = \frac{173}{26}
$$

In the simplification, we used the fact that the denominator can be easily factored:

$$
999999 = 999 \cdot 1001, \quad 999 = 27 \cdot 37, \quad \text{and} \quad 1001 = 7 \cdot 11 \cdot 13
$$

Thus, the first segmented decimal fraction can be converted to the common fraction 173/26, which can be easily verified.

Similarly, the common fraction form of the right-hand side of equation (2) is

$$
\frac{C}{D} = \frac{5769230 - 5}{9999990} = \frac{15}{26}
$$

II. Multiply both equations by $x y$, and add $2 x y$ to the new first equation, so that the left side of the final form is equal to the square of the left side of the new second equation:

$$
\begin{gathered}
x^{2} + y^{2} = \frac{173}{26} x y \\
x + y = \frac{15}{26} x y \\
x^{2} + 2 x y + y^{2} = (x + y)^{2} = \left(\frac{173}{26} + 2\right) x y = \frac{225}{26} x y
\end{gathered}
$$

Thus, dividing (1b) by (2a) and then the square of (2a) by (1b), and rearranging, we get

$$
x + y = 15, \quad x y = 26
$$

(We used the fact that $x \neq 0$ and $y \neq 0$, otherwise the system of equations would have no meaning.) Therefore, $x$ and $y$ are equal to the roots of the equation

$$
z^{2} - 15 z + 26 = 0
$$

which are 13 and 2, in any order:

$$
x_{1} = 13, \quad y_{1} = 2, \quad \text{and} \quad x_{2} = y_{1}, \quad y_{2} = x_{1}
$$

The value pair indeed satisfies the system of equations.

Steiner Gy√∂rgy (Budapest, Radn√≥ti M. gyak. g. III. o. t.) Baranyai Zsolt (Budapest, Fazekas M. gyak. g. III. o. t.)

Remarks. 1. By introducing a new variable $u$ for $x / y$, after converting the infinite decimal fractions to common fractions, we arrive at the system of equations

$$
u + \frac{1}{u} = \frac{173}{26}, \quad \frac{1}{y}\left(\frac{1}{u} + 1\right) = \frac{15}{26}, \quad x = y u
$$

From the first, $u$ is 13/2 and 2/13, from the second, $y$ is 2 and 13, and from the third, $x$ is 13 and 2.

Varga Gabriella (Szombathely, Savaria g. II. o. t.)

2. Most of the solutions chose the method of converting the segmented decimal fractions to common fractions, which, as mentioned in the second remark of problem 1302, proceeds in a way not clarified in the high school curriculum, performing subtraction with numbers written with infinitely many digits as if they were written with finitely many digits. Those who converted the fractions in the manner described above or mentioned this issue received 1 bonus point.[^0]

[^0]: ${ }^{1}$ The editorial board recommended studying the solution of problem 1302 when this exercise was assigned; see K. M. L. 30 (1965) 18. o.
informal_statement:
Solve the following system of equations:
(1) $\quad x / y+y / x=6,6 \dot{5} 3846 \dot{1}$,
(2) $\quad 1 / x+1 / y=0,5 \dot{7} 6923 \dot{0}$.

(The numbers on the right side are repeating decimals. Read the solution to problem 1302, then convert the numbers on the right side to common fractions.)
informal_proof:
We prove the equivalence in two directions.

**($\Rightarrow$)** First, assume that for non-zero real numbers $x$ and $y$, the following two equations hold:
1.  $x / y + y / x = 66/10 + 538461/9999990$
2.  $1 / x + 1 / y = 1/2 + 769230/9999990$

We begin by simplifying the constants on the right-hand side.
For the first equation:
$$ \frac{66}{10} + \frac{538461}{9999990} = \frac{66 \cdot 999999 + 538461}{9999990} = \frac{65999934 + 538461}{9999990} = \frac{66538395}{9999990} = \frac{173}{26} $$
For the second equation:
$$ \frac{1}{2} + \frac{769230}{9999990} = \frac{1 \cdot 4999995 + 769230}{9999990} = \frac{4999995 + 769230}{9999990} = \frac{5769225}{9999990} = \frac{15}{26} $$
The system of equations is thus equivalent to:
1.  $x / y + y / x = 173/26$
2.  $1 / x + 1 / y = 15/26$

Since $x \neq 0$ and $y \neq 0$, we can multiply both equations by $xy$ to clear the denominators.
From equation (1), we get:
$$ x^2 + y^2 = \frac{173}{26} xy \quad (*)$$
From equation (2), we get:
$$ x + y = \frac{15}{26} xy \quad (**)$$
We now solve this new system. From the identity $(x+y)^2 = x^2 + y^2 + 2xy$, we can substitute the expressions from $(*)$ and $(**)$:
$$ \left(\frac{15}{26} xy\right)^2 = \left(\frac{173}{26} xy\right) + 2xy $$
$$ \frac{225}{676} (xy)^2 = \left(\frac{173}{26} + \frac{52}{26}\right) xy = \frac{225}{26} xy $$
Since $x, y \neq 0$, we know $xy \neq 0$, so we can divide both sides by $\frac{225}{26}xy$:
$$ \frac{1}{26} xy = 1 \implies xy = 26 $$
Substituting $xy=26$ back into equation $(**)$:
$$ x + y = \frac{15}{26} (26) \implies x+y = 15 $$
We now have a simple system: $x+y=15$ and $xy=26$. This implies that $x$ and $y$ are the roots of the quadratic equation $z^2 - (x+y)z + xy = 0$, which is $z^2 - 15z + 26 = 0$. Factoring this quadratic, we get $(z-13)(z-2)=0$.
The roots are $z=13$ and $z=2$. Therefore, the set $\{x, y\}$ must be equal to $\{13, 2\}$.

This leads to two possibilities:
*   **Case 1:** If $x = 13$. From $x+y=15$, we find $y = 15 - 13 = 2$. This gives the solution $(x=13, y=2)$.
*   **Case 2:** If $x = 2$. From $x+y=15$, we find $y = 15 - 2 = 13$. This gives the solution $(x=2, y=13)$.

Thus, if the initial equations hold, it must be that $(x = 13 \text{ and } y = 2)$ or $(x = 2 \text{ and } y = 13)$.

**($\Leftarrow$)** Next, we prove the converse. Assume that $(x = 13 \text{ and } y = 2)$ or $(x = 2 \text{ and } y = 13)$. We consider each case.

*   **Case 1:** Assume $x = 13$ and $y = 2$. We substitute these values into the original expressions:
    $$ \frac{x}{y} + \frac{y}{x} = \frac{13}{2} + \frac{2}{13} = \frac{169 + 4}{26} = \frac{173}{26} $$
    $$ \frac{1}{x} + \frac{1}{y} = \frac{1}{13} + \frac{1}{2} = \frac{2 + 13}{26} = \frac{15}{26} $$
    As shown before, these are the simplified values of the right-hand sides of the given equations. Thus, the equations hold for this pair of values.

*   **Case 2:** Assume $x = 2$ and $y = 13$. By symmetry of the expressions in $x$ and $y$:
    $$ \frac{x}{y} + \frac{y}{x} = \frac{2}{13} + \frac{13}{2} = \frac{4 + 169}{26} = \frac{173}{26} $$
    $$ \frac{1}{x} + \frac{1}{y} = \frac{1}{2} + \frac{1}{13} = \frac{13 + 2}{26} = \frac{15}{26} $$
    The equations also hold for this pair of values.

Since both possible pairs of solutions satisfy the system of equations, the reverse implication is true.
This completes the proof of the equivalence.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Solve the following system of equations:
(1) $\quad x / y+y / x=6,6 \dot{5} 3846 \dot{1}$,
(2) $\quad 1 / x+1 / y=0,5 \dot{7} 6923 \dot{0}$.

(The numbers on the right side are repeating decimals. Read the solution to problem 1302, then convert the numbers on the right side to common fractions.) -/
theorem algebra_201348 {x y : ‚Ñù} (hx : x ‚â† 0) (hy : y ‚â† 0) :
    x / y + y / x = 66/10 + 538461/9999990 ‚àß 1 / x + 1 / y = 1/2 + 769230/9999990 ‚Üî (x = 13 ‚àß y = 2) ‚à® (x = 2 ‚àß y = 13) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_201348 {x y : ‚Ñù} (hx : x ‚â† 0) (hy : y ‚â† 0) :
    x / y + y / x = 66/10 + 538461/9999990 ‚àß 1 / x + 1 / y = 1/2 + 769230/9999990 ‚Üî (x = 13 ‚àß y = 2) ‚à® (x = 2 ‚àß y = 13) := by
  constructor
  ¬∑ -- Forward implication: If the equations hold, then (x=13,y=2) or (x=2,y=13).
    intro ‚ü®h1, h2‚ü©
    have eq3 : x^2 + y^2 = (66 / 10 + 538461 / 9999990) * (x * y) := by
      field_simp [hy, hx] at h1 ‚ä¢
      nlinarith
    have eq4 : x + y = (1/2 + 769230 / 9999990) * (x * y) := by
      field_simp [hy, hx] at h2 ‚ä¢
      nlinarith

    have eq6 : (x - 13) * (x - 2) = 0 := by
      nlinarith [sq_pos_of_ne_zero hx, sq_pos_of_ne_zero hy, sq_nonneg (x - y), sq_nonneg (x + y - 0)]
    cases' (mul_eq_zero.1 eq6) with h7 h8
    ¬∑ -- Case x = 13
      have hx13 : x = 13 := by linarith
      have hy2 : y = 2 := by
        nlinarith [hx13, h2]
      left
      exact ‚ü®hx13, hy2‚ü©
    ¬∑ -- Case x = 2
      have hx2 : x = 2 := by linarith
      have hy13 : y = 13 := by
        nlinarith [hx2, h2]
      right
      exact ‚ü®hx2, hy13‚ü©
  ¬∑ -- Backward implication: given the solutions, prove the equations.
    rintro (h | h)
    ¬∑ -- First solution (x = 13, y = 2)
      rw [h.1, h.2]
      constructor <;> norm_num
    ¬∑ -- Second solution (x = 2, y = 13)
      rw [h.1, h.2]
      constructor <;> norm_num

informal_statement: Chris labels every lattice point in the coordinate plane with the square of the distance from the point to the origin (a lattice point is a point such that both of its coordinates are integers). How many times does he label a point with the number $25$?
informal_proof:
We want to find the number of integer pairs `(x, y)` such that `x¬≤ + y¬≤ = 25`. Let `S` be the set of all such pairs. We will show that this set consists of exactly 12 points by explicitly identifying them and proving that no other solutions exist.

Let `T` be the set of 12 pairs:
`T = {(-5, 0), (5, 0), (0, -5), (0, 5), (-4, -3), (-4, 3), (4, -3), (4, 3), (-3, -4), (-3, 4), (3, -4), (3, 4)}`.

We will prove that `S = T` by showing that `S ‚äÜ T` and `T ‚äÜ S`.

**Part 1: Show that every solution is in `T` (S ‚äÜ T)**

Let `(x, y)` be an arbitrary pair of integers such that `x¬≤ + y¬≤ = 25`.
Since `y¬≤ ‚â• 0`, we must have `x¬≤ ‚â§ 25`. This implies that `-5 ‚â§ x ‚â§ 5`. We can therefore check all possible integer values for `x` in this range. For each `x`, we determine the corresponding values of `y` from the equation `y¬≤ = 25 - x¬≤`.

*   **Case x = -5**: `y¬≤ = 25 - (-5)¬≤ = 25 - 25 = 0`, which implies `y = 0`. This gives the solution `(-5, 0)`.
*   **Case x = -4**: `y¬≤ = 25 - (-4)¬≤ = 25 - 16 = 9`, which implies `y = 3` or `y = -3`. This gives the solutions `(-4, 3)` and `(-4, -3)`.
*   **Case x = -3**: `y¬≤ = 25 - (-3)¬≤ = 25 - 9 = 16`, which implies `y = 4` or `y = -4`. This gives the solutions `(-3, 4)` and `(-3, -4)`.
*   **Case x = -2**: `y¬≤ = 25 - (-2)¬≤ = 25 - 4 = 21`. Since 21 is not a perfect square, there is no integer solution for `y`.
*   **Case x = -1**: `y¬≤ = 25 - (-1)¬≤ = 25 - 1 = 24`. Since 24 is not a perfect square, there is no integer solution for `y`.
*   **Case x = 0**: `y¬≤ = 25 - 0¬≤ = 25`, which implies `y = 5` or `y = -5`. This gives the solutions `(0, 5)` and `(0, -5)`.
*   **Case x = 1**: `y¬≤ = 25 - 1¬≤ = 24`. No integer solution for `y`.
*   **Case x = 2**: `y¬≤ = 25 - 2¬≤ = 21`. No integer solution for `y`.
*   **Case x = 3**: `y¬≤ = 25 - 3¬≤ = 16`, which implies `y = 4` or `y = -4`. This gives the solutions `(3, 4)` and `(3, -4)`.
*   **Case x = 4**: `y¬≤ = 25 - 4¬≤ = 9`, which implies `y = 3` or `y = -3`. This gives the solutions `(4, 3)` and `(4, -3)`.
*   **Case x = 5**: `y¬≤ = 25 - 5¬≤ = 0`, which implies `y = 0`. This gives the solution `(5, 0)`.

Combining all the solutions found, we see that any pair `(x, y)` satisfying the equation must be an element of the set `T`. Thus, `S ‚äÜ T`.

**Part 2: Show that every pair in `T` is a solution (T ‚äÜ S)**

We now verify that each of the 12 pairs in `T` satisfies the equation `x¬≤ + y¬≤ = 25`.
*   For `(¬±5, 0)`: `(¬±5)¬≤ + 0¬≤ = 25 + 0 = 25`.
*   For `(0, ¬±5)`: `0¬≤ + (¬±5)¬≤ = 0 + 25 = 25`.
*   For `(¬±4, ¬±3)`: `(¬±4)¬≤ + (¬±3)¬≤ = 16 + 9 = 25`.
*   For `(¬±3, ¬±4)`: `(¬±3)¬≤ + (¬±4)¬≤ = 9 + 16 = 25`.

All 12 pairs in `T` satisfy the equation, so `T ‚äÜ S`.

**Conclusion**

Since `S ‚äÜ T` and `T ‚äÜ S`, the set of all solutions is precisely the set `T`. The set `T` contains 12 distinct elements. Therefore, the number 25 appears 12 times as a label on the lattice points.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Chris labels every lattice point in the coordinate plane with the square of the distance from the point to the origin (a lattice point is a point such that both of its coordinates are integers). How many times does he label a point with the number $25$? -/
theorem algebra_22154 : {(x, y) : ‚Ñ§ √ó ‚Ñ§ | x^2 + y^2 = 25}.ncard = 12 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

/- Chris labels every lattice point in the coordinate plane with the square of the distance from the point to the origin (a lattice point is a point such that both of its coordinates are integers). How many times does he label a point with the number $25$? -/
theorem algebra_22154 : {(x, y) : ‚Ñ§ √ó ‚Ñ§ | x^2 + y^2 = 25}.ncard = 12 := by
  -- It suffices to find out all the lattice points that satisfy x^2 + y^2 = 25
  suffices H : {(x, y) : ‚Ñ§ √ó ‚Ñ§ | x^2 + y^2 = 25} = {(-3, -4), (-3, 4), (-4, -3), (-4, 3), (3, -4), (3, 4), (4, -3), (4, 3), (-5, 0), (5, 0), (0, -5), (0, 5)} by
    rw [H, ‚Üê Set.coe_toFinset {(-3, -4), (-3, 4), (-4, -3), (-4, 3), (3, -4), (3, 4), (4, -3), (4, 3), (-5, 0), (5, 0), (0, -5), (0, 5)}, Set.ncard_coe_Finset]
    simp

  -- We prove mutual inclusion
  ext ‚ü®x, y‚ü©
  simp
  constructor
  . -- First inclusion
    intro h
    -- We have -5 ‚â§ x ‚â§ 5
    have hx1 : x ‚â• -5 := by nlinarith
    have hx2 : x ‚â§ 5 := by nlinarith
    -- Case analysis on x
    interval_cases x
    all_goals
      clear x hx1 hx2
      simp
      norm_num at h
      -- Two goals are trivial
      try
        trivial
      -- Five goals are the form of y = -n ‚à® y = n
      try
        rw [Or.comm]
        apply eq_or_eq_neg_of_sq_eq_sq
        linarith
    -- Four goals remain, they are the form: h : a + y^2 = 25, and we need to prove False
    all_goals
        -- Get the value of y^2
        apply eq_sub_of_add_eq' at h
        norm_num at h
        have H : IsSquare (y^2) := ‚ü®y, pow_two y‚ü©
        rw [h] at H
        -- But the value of y^2 is not a perfect square, contradiction
        absurd H
        -- The use of native_decide here can be replaced by hand calculation
        native_decide

  . -- Second inclusion
    -- We check all the cases
    rintro (‚ü®rfl, rfl‚ü© | ‚ü®rfl, rfl‚ü© | ‚ü®rfl, rfl‚ü© | ‚ü®rfl, rfl‚ü© | ‚ü®rfl, rfl‚ü© | ‚ü®rfl, rfl‚ü© | ‚ü®rfl, rfl‚ü© | ‚ü®rfl, rfl‚ü© | ‚ü®rfl, rfl‚ü© | ‚ü®rfl, rfl‚ü© | ‚ü®rfl, rfl‚ü© | ‚ü®rfl, rfl‚ü©)
    all_goals
      simp

informal_statement: The Fibonacci sequence is defined as follows: $F_{0}=0, F_{1}=1$, and $F_{n}=F_{n-1}+F_{n-2}$ for all integers $n \geq 2$. Find the smallest positive integer $m$ such that $F_{m} \equiv 0(\bmod 127)$ and $F_{m+1} \equiv 1(\bmod 127)$.
informal_proof:
Let $F_n$ denote the $n$-th Fibonacci number, where $F_0=0$ and $F_1=1$. We want to find the smallest positive integer $m$ such that $F_m \equiv 0 \pmod{127}$ and $F_{m+1} \equiv 1 \pmod{127}$. We will show that this integer is 256.

To prove that 256 is the smallest such integer, we must establish two facts:
1. The integer 256 satisfies the given conditions.
2. No positive integer smaller than 256 satisfies the conditions.

**Part 1: Verifying the conditions for m = 256**

First, we check if $m=256$ satisfies the properties.
- The condition $m > 0$ is clearly met, as $256 > 0$.
- We then need to verify the two congruences. A direct computation of the Fibonacci sequence modulo 127 shows that:
  - $F_{256} \equiv 0 \pmod{127}$
  - $F_{257} \equiv 1 \pmod{127}$
Thus, 256 is a positive integer that satisfies the required conditions.

**Part 2: Proving the minimality of 256**

Next, we must show that there is no smaller positive integer with these properties. We can prove this by contradiction. Assume there exists a positive integer $m$ such that $0 < m < 256$ and it satisfies the congruences:
- $F_m \equiv 0 \pmod{127}$
- $F_{m+1} \equiv 1 \pmod{127}$

To show this assumption is false, we can perform an exhaustive check of all integers $m$ in the range $1 \le m \le 255$. For each such $m$, we compute the pair $(F_m \pmod{127}, F_{m+1} \pmod{127})$ and check if it equals $(0, 1)$. A systematic computation for all values of $m$ from 1 to 255 reveals that no such $m$ exists for which both congruences hold simultaneously.

Since our exhaustive check fails to find any integer $m$ in the range $0 < m < 256$ that satisfies the conditions, our initial assumption must be false. Therefore, no such smaller positive integer exists.

**Conclusion**

Since 256 satisfies the conditions and no positive integer smaller than 256 does, we conclude that 256 is the smallest such integer.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- The Fibonacci sequence is defined as follows: $F_{0}=0, F_{1}=1$, and $F_{n}=F_{n-1}+F_{n-2}$ for all integers $n \geq 2$. Find the smallest positive integer $m$ such that $F_{m} \equiv 0(\bmod 127)$ and $F_{m+1} \equiv 1(\bmod 127)$. -/
theorem number_theory_609646 :
    IsLeast {m | 0 < m ‚àß Nat.fib m ‚â° 0 [MOD 127] ‚àß Nat.fib (m + 1) ‚â° 1 [MOD 127]} 256 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

/- The Fibonacci sequence is defined as follows: $F_{0}=0, F_{1}=1$, and $F_{n}=F_{n-1}+F_{n-2}$ for all integers $n \geq 2$. Find the smallest positive integer $m$ such that $F_{m} \equiv 0(\bmod 127)$ and $F_{m+1} \equiv 1(\bmod 127)$. -/
theorem number_theory_609646 :
    IsLeast {m | 0 < m ‚àß Nat.fib m ‚â° 0 [MOD 127] ‚àß Nat.fib (m + 1) ‚â° 1 [MOD 127]} 256 := by
  constructor
  . -- Let's compute fib 256 and fib 257
    norm_num
    -- Calculate their values modulo 127
    decide
  . -- We show that 256 is the smallest such number
    intro m ‚ü®h‚ÇÅ, h‚ÇÇ, h‚ÇÉ‚ü©
    -- We can prove that any m < 256 is not a solution by brute force
    by_contra! h‚ÇÑ
    revert h‚ÇÅ h‚ÇÇ h‚ÇÉ
    revert m
    native_decide

soln_description:
To solve the equation, it is necessary to observe that the two terms on the left side are reciprocals of each other. This is true because

$$
(\sqrt{5}+2) \cdot(\sqrt{5}-2)=(\sqrt{5})^{2}-2^{2}=1
$$

Let $y=(\sqrt{5}+2)^{x}$. Based on the above, $(\sqrt{5}-2)^{x}=\frac{1}{y}$. Substituting these into the equation:

$$
y+\frac{1}{y}=18
$$

Multiplying by $y$ and rearranging, we get the quadratic equation $y^{2}-18 y+1=0$, which has two solutions: $9+\sqrt{80}$ and $9-\sqrt{80}$, which are also reciprocals of each other.

It is easily verifiable that

$$
9+\sqrt{80}=(\sqrt{5}+2)^{2} \quad \text { and } \quad 9-\sqrt{80}=(\sqrt{5}-2)^{2}=(\sqrt{5}+2)^{-2}
$$

Since neither base is 1, it follows from these that the equation is satisfied only by $x=2$ and $x=-2$. The reversibility of our steps also confirms that these are indeed solutions.

Thus, the equation has two solutions: $x_{1}=2$ and $x_{2}=-2$.
informal_statement:
Solve the following equation in the set of real numbers:

$$
(\sqrt{5}+2)^{x}+(\sqrt{5}-2)^{x}=18
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Solve the following equation in the set of real numbers:

$$
(\sqrt{5}+2)^{x}+(\sqrt{5}-2)^{x}=18
$$ -/
theorem algebra_203298 (x : ‚Ñù) :
    (Real.sqrt 5 + 2)^x + (Real.sqrt 5 - 2)^x = 18 ‚Üî x = 2 ‚à® x = -2 := by

informal_statement:
Let $\mathbf{a} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix},$ $\mathbf{b} = \begin{pmatrix} -11 \\ 5 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix},$ and $\mathbf{c} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 + \sqrt{5} \\ 4 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix}.$  Find $k$ if the vectors $\mathbf{a} + \mathbf{b} + \mathbf{c}$ and
\[3 (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}) - 8 (\mathbf{c} \times \mathbf{a}) + k (\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b})\]are orthogonal.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real
open scoped BigOperators

/- Let $\mathbf{a} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix},$ $\mathbf{b} = \begin{pmatrix} -11 \\ 5 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix},$ and $\mathbf{c} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 + \sqrt{5} \\ 4 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix}.$  Find $k$ if the vectors $\mathbf{a} + \mathbf{b} + \mathbf{c}$ and
\[3 (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}) - 8 (\mathbf{c} \times \mathbf{a}) + k (\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b})\]are orthogonal. -/
theorem calculus_22016
  (a b c : Fin 3 ‚Üí ‚Ñù)
  (ha : a = ![1, 3, 0])
  (hb : b = ![-11, 5, 2])
  (hc : c = ![1 + sqrt 5, 4, -5]) :
  (a + b + c) ‚Ä¢ (3 * (crossProduct b c) - 8 * (crossProduct c a) +
    k * (crossProduct a b)) = 0 ‚Üî k = 5 := by

soln_description:
Consider the sum up to $\frac{1}{a_{m}}$ in general. By definition, $a_{n}=k$ if $k-\frac{1}{2}0$, so

$$
x_{0}=\frac{-1+\sqrt{4 m-3}}{2}
$$

and $p \leq x_{0}<p+1$ implies

$$
p=\left[x_{0}\right]=\left[\frac{-1+\sqrt{4 m-3}}{2}\right]
$$

The sum of the reciprocals can then be written as follows:

$$
\begin{gathered}
\underbrace{2+2+\cdots+2}_{p \text { terms }}+\underbrace{\frac{1}{p+1}+\cdots+\frac{1}{p+1}}_{m-2(1+2+\cdots+p)=m-p(p+1)}=2 p+\frac{m}{p+1}-\frac{p(p+1)}{p+1}= \\
=p+\frac{m}{p+1}=\left[\frac{-1+\sqrt{4 m-3}}{2}\right]+\frac{m}{\left[\frac{-1+\sqrt{4 m-3}}{2}\right]+1}
\end{gathered}
$$

For the case $m=1994$, the sum is $\frac{3974}{45}$.

Based on the work of Gyula Pap (Debrecen, Fazekas M. Gymnasium, 1st year)
informal_statement:
Let $a_{n}$ denote the integer closest to $\sqrt{n}$. What is the value of

$$
\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{1994}}
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Let $a_{n}$ denote the integer closest to $\sqrt{n}$. What is the value of

$$
\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{1994}}
$$ -/
theorem number_theory_203328 (a : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñ§) (ha : ‚àÄ n, a n = round (sqrt n)) :
    ‚àë i in Finset.range 1994, ((1 : ‚Ñö) / a (i + 1)) = 3974 / 45 := by

informal_statement: A parabola with equation $y=ax^2+bx+c$ has a vertical line of symmetry at $x=2$ and goes through the two points $(1,1)$ and $(4,-1)$. The quadratic $ax^2 + bx +c$  has two real roots. The greater root is $\sqrt{n}+2$. What is $n$?
informal_proof:
Let the equation of the parabola be $f(x) = ax^2+bx+c$.

First, we determine the coefficients $a, b, c$.
The condition that the parabola has a vertical line of symmetry at $x=2$ is given by the identity $f(4-x) = f(x)$ for all $x \in \mathbb{R}$. Specifically, for $x=0$, we have $f(4) = f(0)$.
This gives the equation:
$a(4)^2 + b(4) + c = a(0)^2 + b(0) + c$
$16a + 4b + c = c$
$16a + 4b = 0$
which simplifies to $b = -4a$.

The parabola passes through the points $(1,1)$ and $(4,-1)$, which gives us two equations:
1. $f(1) = a(1)^2 + b(1) + c = a + b + c = 1$
2. $f(4) = a(4)^2 + b(4) + c = 16a + 4b + c = -1$

Substituting $b = -4a$ into the second equation gives:
$16a + 4(-4a) + c = -1$
$16a - 16a + c = -1$
$c = -1$

Now, substituting $b = -4a$ and $c = -1$ into the first equation gives:
$a + (-4a) + (-1) = 1$
$-3a - 1 = 1$
$-3a = 2$
$a = -2/3$

Finally, we find $b$:
$b = -4a = -4(-2/3) = 8/3$.

So the equation of the parabola is $y = -\frac{2}{3}x^2 + \frac{8}{3}x - 1$.

Next, we find the roots of the quadratic equation $-\frac{2}{3}x^2 + \frac{8}{3}x - 1 = 0$. The discriminant is $\Delta = b^2 - 4ac$:
$\Delta = (8/3)^2 - 4(-2/3)(-1) = 64/9 - 8/3 = 64/9 - 24/9 = 40/9$.

The roots are given by the quadratic formula $x = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{\Delta}}{2a}$:
$x = \frac{-(8/3) \pm \sqrt{40/9}}{2(-2/3)} = \frac{-8/3 \pm (\sqrt{40})/3}{-4/3}$
Multiplying the numerator and denominator by 3, we get:
$x = \frac{-8 \pm \sqrt{40}}{-4} = \frac{8 \mp \sqrt{40}}{4} = \frac{8 \mp 2\sqrt{10}}{4} = 2 \mp \frac{\sqrt{10}}{2}$.

The two roots are $x_A = 2 + \frac{\sqrt{10}}{2}$ and $x_B = 2 - \frac{\sqrt{10}}{2}$.
We are given that $x_1$ and $x_2$ are the roots and $x_1 > x_2$. Since $\frac{\sqrt{10}}{2} > 0$, we have $2 + \frac{\sqrt{10}}{2} > 2 - \frac{\sqrt{10}}{2}$. Thus, we must have:
$x_1 = 2 + \frac{\sqrt{10}}{2}$
$x_2 = 2 - \frac{\sqrt{10}}{2}$

Finally, we are given that the greater root is $x_1 = \sqrt{n} + 2$. Equating the two expressions for $x_1$:
$\sqrt{n} + 2 = 2 + \frac{\sqrt{10}}{2}$
Subtracting 2 from both sides gives:
$\sqrt{n} = \frac{\sqrt{10}}{2}$

To find $n$, we square both sides of the equation:
$n = \left(\frac{\sqrt{10}}{2}\right)^2 = \frac{10}{4} = \frac{5}{2}$.

Thus, $n = 5/2$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- A parabola with equation $y=ax^2+bx+c$ has a vertical line of symmetry at $x=2$ and goes through the two points $(1,1)$ and $(4,-1)$. The quadratic $ax^2 + bx +c$  has two real roots. The greater root is $\sqrt{n}+2$. What is $n$? -/
theorem algebra_22113 {a b c : ‚Ñù} (ha : a ‚â† 0) (h : ‚àÄ x, a * (4 - x) ^ 2 + b * (4 - x) + c = a * x ^ 2 + b * x + c)
    (h1 : a * 1 ^ 2 + b * 1 + c = 1) (h2 : a * 4 ^ 2 + b * 4 + c = -1)
    (x1 x2 : ‚Ñù)
    (root1: x1 > x2)
    (root2: a * x1 ^ 2 + b * x1 + c = 0 ‚àß a * x2 ^ 2 + b * x2 + c = 0)
    (n: ‚Ñù)
    (root3: x1 = Real.sqrt n + 2) : n = 5 / 2 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

/- A parabola with equation $y=ax^2+bx+c$ has a vertical line of symmetry at $x=2$ and goes through the two points $(1,1)$ and $(4,-1)$. The quadratic $ax^2 + bx +c$  has two real roots. The greater root is $\sqrt{n}+2$. What is $n$? -/
theorem algebra_22113 {a b c : ‚Ñù} (ha : a ‚â† 0) (h : ‚àÄ x, a * (4 - x) ^ 2 + b * (4 - x) + c = a * x ^ 2 + b * x + c)
    (h1 : a * 1 ^ 2 + b * 1 + c = 1) (h2 : a * 4 ^ 2 + b * 4 + c = -1)
    (x1 x2 : ‚Ñù)
    (root1: x1 > x2)
    (root2: a * x1 ^ 2 + b * x1 + c = 0 ‚àß a * x2 ^ 2 + b * x2 + c = 0)
    (n: ‚Ñù)
    (root3: x1 = Real.sqrt n + 2) : n = 5 / 2 := by
  simp at *
  -- solve a, b, c
  have h3 : -4 * a = b := by
    specialize h 0
    linarith
  rw [<- h3] at h1
  rw [<- h3] at h2
  ring_nf at h2
  rw [h2] at h1
  ring_nf at h1
  have h1 : a = -2/3 := by linarith
  rw [h1] at h3
  ring_nf at h3

  -- solve x1, x2
  have disc: discrim a b c = 40/9 := by
    rw [h1, <- h3, h2]
    unfold discrim
    ring_nf
  let s := (Real.sqrt 40) / 3
  have s2 : discrim a b c = s * s := by
    rw [disc]
    ring_nf
    simp
    ring_nf

  -- solve x1
  have x1p: a * (x1 * x1) + b * x1 + c = 0 := by rw [<- root2.1]; ring_nf
  rw [(quadratic_eq_zero_iff ha s2 x1), h1, <- h3] at x1p
  ring_nf at x1p

  -- solve x2
  have x2p: a * (x2 * x2) + b * x2 + c = 0 := by rw [<- root2.2]; ring_nf
  rw [(quadratic_eq_zero_iff ha s2 x2), h1, <- h3] at x2p
  ring_nf at x2p

  -- use x1 > x2
  match x1p with
  | Or.inl h => {
    -- x1 is the smaller root
    match x2p with
    | Or.inl h' => {
      -- x1, x2 is the smaller root
      linarith
    }
    | Or.inr h' => {
      -- x2 is the larger root
      -- x2 > x1
      rw [h, h'] at root1
      simp at root1
      ring_nf at root1
      linarith
    }
  }
  | Or.inr h => {
    -- x1 is the larger root
    match x2p with
    | Or.inl h' => {
      rw [h] at root3
      ring_nf at root3
      simp at root3

      have n_pos : 0 < n := by rw [<- Real.sqrt_pos, <- root3]; simp
      have n_pos : 0 ‚â§ n := le_of_lt n_pos
      rw [<- Real.sq_sqrt n_pos, <- root3]
      ring_nf
      simp
      ring_nf
    }
    | Or.inr h' => {
      -- x1, x2 is the larger root
      linarith
    }
  }

soln_description:
Evaluate the product of the digits, replacing each digit, except the first, with ten.

## Solution

Let the number $\mathrm{N}$ be represented in decimal notation by the digits $\mathrm{a}_{0}, \mathrm{a}_{1}, \mathrm{a}_{2}, \ldots, \mathrm{a}_{\mathrm{n}}, \mathrm{n}>0$. Then the product of the digits of the number $\mathrm{N}$ is $\mathrm{P}=\mathrm{a}_{0} \mathrm{a}_{1} \mathrm{a}_{2} \ldots \mathrm{a}_{\mathrm{n}}$, which is less than $\mathrm{a}_{0} * 10^{\mathrm{n}}$, since each of the digits $\mathrm{a}_{1}, \mathrm{a}_{2}, \ldots, \mathrm{a}_{\mathrm{n}}$ is less than 10. The number $\mathrm{a}_{0} * 10^{\mathrm{n}}$ has in its decimal representation the digit $\mathrm{a}_{0}$ followed by $\mathrm{n}$ zeros. Therefore, $\mathrm{a}_{0} * 10^{\mathrm{n}}$ is not greater than $\mathrm{N}$.

Submit a comment
informal_statement:
[ Decimal numeral system ]

Prove that the product of the digits of any natural number greater than 9 is less than the number itself.

#
informal_proof:
Let `n` be a natural number such that `n > 9`. We want to show that the product of the base-10 digits of `n` is strictly less than `n`.

First, we establish that `n` must have at least two digits. Assume for contradiction that `n` has at most one digit. A number is always strictly less than the base raised to the power of its number of digits. In our case, this means `n < 10¬π`, which simplifies to `n < 10`. This contradicts our initial assumption that `n > 9`. Therefore, `n` must have at least two digits.

Let the number of digits of `n` be `L`, where we have shown `L ‚â• 2`. Let `k = L - 1`, so `k ‚â• 1`. We can represent the list of digits of `n` (from least to most significant) as `[d‚ÇÄ, d‚ÇÅ, ..., d‚Çñ]`, where `d‚Çñ` is the most significant digit. The product of all digits is `(d‚ÇÄ * d‚ÇÅ * ... * d‚Çñ‚Çã‚ÇÅ) * d‚Çñ`.

We will now form a chain of inequalities.

1.  Consider the product of the `k` least significant digits: `P' = d‚ÇÄ * d‚ÇÅ * ... * d‚Çñ‚Çã‚ÇÅ`. Each digit `d·µ¢` in base 10 is less than 10, meaning `d·µ¢ ‚â§ 9`. Therefore, the product of these `k` digits is at most `9^k`:
    `P' ‚â§ 9^k`

2.  Since `k ‚â• 1` and `9 < 10`, it follows that `9^k < 10^k`. Combining this with the previous inequality, we get a strict inequality for `P'`:
    `P' < 10^k`

3.  Now, we multiply this inequality by the most significant digit, `d‚Çñ`. Since `n > 9`, `n` is positive, which implies its most significant digit `d‚Çñ` must be positive. Multiplying a strict inequality by a positive number preserves the inequality:
    `P' * d‚Çñ < 10^k * d‚Çñ`
    This means the product of all digits is strictly less than `10^k` times the most significant digit.

4.  Finally, we relate `10^k * d‚Çñ` to `n`. The number `n` can be expressed as the sum of the values represented by its digits:
    `n = d‚ÇÄ * 10‚Å∞ + d‚ÇÅ * 10¬π + ... + d‚Çñ‚Çã‚ÇÅ * 10·µè‚Åª¬π + d‚Çñ * 10·µè`
    Since all terms in this sum are non-negative, the value of `n` must be greater than or equal to any single term. In particular:
    `10^k * d‚Çñ ‚â§ n`

By combining our findings, we have the following chain of relations:
`Product of digits = P' * d‚Çñ < 10^k * d‚Çñ ‚â§ n`

By the transitivity of inequality, we conclude that the product of the digits of `n` is strictly less than `n`.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib


/- [ Decimal numeral system ]

Prove that the product of the digits of any natural number greater than 9 is less than the number itself.

# -/
theorem number_theory_202501:
  ‚àÄ(n:‚Ñï), n > 9 ‚Üí (Nat.digits 10 n).prod < n := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib


/- [ Decimal numeral system ]

Prove that the product of the digits of any natural number greater than 9 is less than the number itself.

# -/
theorem number_theory_202501:
  ‚àÄ(n:‚Ñï), n > 9 ‚Üí (Nat.digits 10 n).prod < n := by
  intro n hn
  -- n ‚â• 10, digit length ‚â• 2.
  have h1: (Nat.digits 10 n).length ‚â• 2 := by
    by_contra!
    replace: (Nat.digits 10 n).length ‚â§ 1 := Nat.le_of_lt_succ this
    replace hn: n ‚â• 10 := by exact hn
    have h: n < 10^(Nat.digits 10 n).length := by
      exact Nat.lt_base_pow_length_digits'
    absurd hn
    push_neg
    apply lt_of_lt_of_le h ?_
    nth_rw 3 [‚Üê pow_one 10]
    apply (Nat.pow_le_pow_iff_right (by norm_num)).mpr this

  have h1': Nat.digits 10 n ‚â† [] := by
    refine List.ne_nil_of_length_pos ?_
    omega
  obtain ‚ü®k, kpos, hk‚ü©: ‚àÉ (k: Fin (Nat.digits 10 n).length),
    ‚ü®0, (by omega)‚ü© < k ‚àß
    (Nat.digits 10 n).length = k + 1 := by
    use ‚ü®(Nat.digits 10 n).length - 1, (by omega)‚ü©
    simp only [Nat.reduceLeDiff, Fin.mk_lt_mk, tsub_pos_iff_lt]
    omega
  have keq: (k:‚Ñï) = (Nat.digits 10 n).length - 1 := by
    omega

  -- single out most significant digit
  have h2: (Nat.digits 10 n) = (Nat.digits 10 n).take (k + 1) := by
    rw [‚Üê hk, List.take_length]
  rw [h2, List.prod_take_succ _ _ k.is_lt]

  -- product of remaining digits ‚â§ 9^k
  have h3: ((Nat.digits 10 n).take k).prod ‚â§ 9^(k:‚Ñï) := by
    nth_rw 2 [‚Üê List.length_take_of_le k.is_le']
    apply List.prod_le_pow_card
    intro i hi
    replace hi: i ‚àà Nat.digits 10 n := List.mem_of_mem_take hi
    suffices i < 10 by exact Nat.le_of_lt_succ this
    exact Nat.digits_lt_base' hi
  replace h3: ((Nat.digits 10 n).take k).prod < 10^(k:‚Ñï) := by
    refine lt_of_le_of_lt h3 ?_
    apply (Nat.pow_lt_pow_iff_left ?_).mpr (by norm_num)
    exact Nat.not_eq_zero_of_lt kpos
  replace h3: ((Nat.digits 10 n).take k).prod *
    (Nat.digits 10 n)[k] < 10^(k:‚Ñï) * (Nat.digits 10 n)[k] := by
    refine Nat.mul_lt_mul_of_pos_right h3 ?_
    simp only [Nat.reduceLeDiff, Fin.getElem_fin,
    gt_iff_lt, keq]
    rw [List.getElem_length_sub_one_eq_getLast]
    refine Nat.zero_lt_of_ne_zero ?_
    refine Nat.getLast_digit_ne_zero 10 (by omega)

  -- and 10^k multiply most siginificant digit ‚â§ n
  have h4: 10^(k:‚Ñï) * (Nat.digits 10 n)[k] ‚â§ n := by
    rw [mul_comm (10^(k:‚Ñï)) _, ‚Üê Nat.le_div_iff_mul_le (by simp),
    Nat.self_div_pow_eq_ofDigits_drop _ _ (by norm_num)]
    rw [keq, List.drop_length_sub_one h1',
    ‚Üê List.get_length_sub_one (by omega)]
    simp [keq]

  -- done.
  exact lt_of_lt_of_le h3 h4

informal_statement: Given that the two roots of the quadratic equation ${{x}^{2}}+mx+2520=0$ are positive integers, find the maximum possible value of $m$.
informal_proof:
We want to find the maximum value of $m$ such that the equation $x^2 + mx + 2520 = 0$ has two positive integer roots. Let $S$ be the set of all such real numbers $m$. We will show that $-101$ is the greatest element of $S$. This requires proving two things:
1.  $-101$ is in $S$.
2.  For any $m \in S$, we have $m \le -101$.

**Part 1: Show that $-101$ is a possible value for $m$.**

Consider the quadratic equation for $m = -101$: $x^2 - 101x + 2520 = 0$.
We need to show that this equation has two positive integer roots. Let's propose the roots $a=45$ and $b=56$. Both are positive integers.

We verify that they are indeed roots of the equation:
- For $x=45$: $45^2 - 101 \cdot 45 + 2520 = 2025 - 4545 + 2520 = 0$.
- For $x=56$: $56^2 - 101 \cdot 56 + 2520 = 3136 - 5656 + 2520 = 0$.

Furthermore, since the polynomial can be factored as $(x-45)(x-56)$, the equation $(x-45)(x-56)=0$ implies that $x=45$ or $x=56$. Thus, these are the only two roots. Since we have found two positive integer roots for $m=-101$, we conclude that $-101 \in S$.

**Part 2: Show that for any $m \in S$, $m \le -101$.**

Let $m$ be an arbitrary element of $S$. By definition, there exist two positive integers, let's call them $a$ and $b$, that are the roots of the equation $x^2 + mx + 2520 = 0$. We consider two cases based on whether the roots are distinct or not.

**Case 1: The roots are identical ($a=b$).**
If $a$ is a double root, the quadratic polynomial must be of the form $(x-a)^2 = x^2 - 2ax + a^2$. Comparing the coefficients of this polynomial with $x^2 + mx + 2520 = 0$, we must have $m = -2a$ and $a^2 = 2520$.
However, $a^2 = 2520$ has no integer solution for $a$, because $2520$ is not a perfect square (we have $50^2 = 2500$ and $51^2 = 2601$). Therefore, this case is impossible.

**Case 2: The roots are distinct ($a \neq b$).**
Since $a$ and $b$ are the distinct roots of $x^2+mx+2520=0$, by Vieta's formulas we have:
1. $a + b = -m$
2. $a \cdot b = 2520$

We want to show that $m \le -101$. We will prove this by contradiction. Assume that $m > -101$. Multiplying by $-1$, we get $-m < 101$. Using the first formula from Vieta, this is equivalent to:
$a + b < 101$.

So, our assumption leads to the claim that there exist two distinct positive integers $a$ and $b$ such that $a \cdot b = 2520$ and $a + b < 101$. Let us investigate this claim.

For a fixed product $ab=2520$, the sum $a+b$ is minimized when $a$ and $b$ are as close to each other as possible, i.e., close to $\sqrt{2520} \approx 50.199$. We need to find the pair of integer factors of 2520 that are closest to this value.
By checking factors of 2520 around 50, we find the pair $(45, 56)$, since $45 \cdot 56 = 2520$. The sum for this pair is $45 + 56 = 101$.

For any other pair of distinct integer factors $(a', b')$ of 2520, one factor must be further from $\sqrt{2520}$ than 45 or 56, and consequently, their sum $a'+b'$ will be greater than 101. For example, the next closest pair of factors is $(42, 60)$, whose sum is $42+60=102$.

Therefore, the minimum possible sum for two distinct positive integer factors of 2520 is 101. This contradicts our derived condition that $a+b < 101$. The assumption that $m > -101$ must be false.

Thus, we must have $m \le -101$.

**Conclusion**

We have shown that $m=-101$ is a possible value and that any possible value of $m$ must be less than or equal to $-101$. Therefore, the maximum possible value of $m$ is $-101$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

-- we write the simp form of vieta's formula as a lemma
lemma vieta_formula {p q x1 x2: ‚Ñù} (ne: x1 ‚â† x2) (h1: x1 ^ 2 + p * x1 + q = 0) (h2: x2 ^ 2 + p * x2 + q = 0):
    x1 + x2 = -p ‚àß x1 * x2 = q := by

  have h: (x1 - x2) * (x1 + x2 + p) = 0 := by nlinarith
  replace ne: ¬¨ x1 - x2 = 0 := by
    by_contra! i
    replace i: x1 = x2 := by linarith
    simp [i] at ne
  simp [ne] at h
  constructor
  .
    linarith
  .
    have f: (x1 + x2) ^ 2 - 2 * (x1 * x2) + p * (x1 + x2) + 2 * q = 0 := by
      nlinarith
    replace h: x1 + x2 = -p := by linarith
    simp [h] at f
    nlinarith

/-Given that the two roots of the quadratic equation
x^2 +mx+2520=0 are positive integers,
find the maximum possible value of m -/

theorem algebra_628897: IsGreatest {m: ‚Ñù | ‚àÉ a b: ‚Ñ§, 0 < a ‚àß 0 < b ‚àß
  a ^ 2 + m * a + 2520 = 0 ‚àß b ^ 2 + m * b + 2520 = 0 ‚àß ‚àÄ y: ‚Ñù, y ^ 2 + m * y + 2520 = 0 ‚Üí y = a ‚à® y = b} (-101) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

-- we write the simp form of vieta's formula as a lemma
lemma vieta_formula {p q x1 x2: ‚Ñù} (ne: x1 ‚â† x2) (h1: x1 ^ 2 + p * x1 + q = 0) (h2: x2 ^ 2 + p * x2 + q = 0):
    x1 + x2 = -p ‚àß x1 * x2 = q := by

  have h: (x1 - x2) * (x1 + x2 + p) = 0 := by nlinarith
  replace ne: ¬¨ x1 - x2 = 0 := by
    by_contra! i
    replace i: x1 = x2 := by linarith
    simp [i] at ne
  simp [ne] at h
  constructor
  .
    linarith
  .
    have f: (x1 + x2) ^ 2 - 2 * (x1 * x2) + p * (x1 + x2) + 2 * q = 0 := by
      nlinarith
    replace h: x1 + x2 = -p := by linarith
    simp [h] at f
    nlinarith

/-Given that the two roots of the quadratic equation
x^2 +mx+2520=0 are positive integers,
find the maximum possible value of m -/

theorem algebra_628897: IsGreatest {m: ‚Ñù | ‚àÉ a b: ‚Ñ§, 0 < a ‚àß 0 < b ‚àß
  a ^ 2 + m * a + 2520 = 0 ‚àß b ^ 2 + m * b + 2520 = 0 ‚àß ‚àÄ y: ‚Ñù, y ^ 2 + m * y + 2520 = 0 ‚Üí y = a ‚à® y = b} (-101) := by

    constructor

    -- the forward direction
    .
      simp
      use 45
      norm_num
      use 56
      norm_num
      intro y h
      rw [show y ^ 2 + -(101 * y) + 2520 = (y - 45) * (y - 56) by ring] at h
      simp at h
      rcases h with h | h
      .
        left
        linarith
      .
        right
        linarith

    -- the backward direction
    .
      intro m h
      simp only [Set.mem_setOf_eq] at h
      obtain ‚ü®a, b, la, lb, ha, hb, hy‚ü© := h
      by_cases l: a = b

      -- case1, multiple roots
      .
        simp [‚Üê l] at hy
        clear hb l lb
        set c:= -m - a -- we show that c is also a root
        specialize hy c
        have o: c ^ 2 + m * c + 2520 = 0 := by
          simp [c]
          nlinarith
        simp [o] at hy -- hence c = a
        simp [c] at hy
        replace hy: m = -2 * a := by nlinarith
        simp [hy] at ha
        ring_nf at ha
        norm_cast at ha
        have la1: 50 < a := by nlinarith
        have la2: a < 51 := by nlinarith
        omega

      -- case2, distinct roots
      .
        clear hy
        replace l: (a: ‚Ñù) ‚â† b := by
          by_contra! i
          simp at i
          simp [i] at l

        -- then we apply vieta's formula
        have f:= vieta_formula l ha hb
        rcases f with ‚ü®f, g‚ü©
        norm_cast at g
        have d: a ‚à£ 2520 := by
          rw [‚Üê g]
          simp

        -- for convenience, prove by contradction
        by_contra! i
        replace i: -m < 101 := by linarith
        rw [‚Üê f] at i
        clear f ha hb
        norm_cast at i
        by_cases r: a < b
        
        -- case a < b
        .
          have ra: a < 51 := by nlinarith
          have rb: b < 100 := by nlinarith
          replace la: 25 < a := by nlinarith

          -- then we check all value of a
          interval_cases a
          all_goals norm_num at d
          all_goals omega

        -- case a > b
        .
          simp at l
          replace r: b < a := by omega
          clear l
          have ra: a < 100 := by nlinarith
          have rb: b < 51 := by nlinarith
          replace lb: 25 < b := by nlinarith

          -- then we check all value of b
          interval_cases b
          all_goals norm_num at d
          all_goals omega

informal_statement: Suppose that $N$ can be written in base $6$ as $531340_6$ and in base $8$ as $124154_8$. In base $10$, what is the remainder when $N$ is divided by $210$?
informal_proof:
We are given the representations of a natural number $N$ in base 6 and base 8:
1. $N = 5 \cdot 6^5 + 3 \cdot 6^4 + 1 \cdot 6^3 + 3 \cdot 6^2 + 4 \cdot 6 + 0$
2. $N = 1 \cdot 8^5 + 2 \cdot 8^4 + 4 \cdot 8^3 + 1 \cdot 8^2 + 5 \cdot 8 + 4$

Our goal is to find the remainder of $N$ when divided by $210$. We will use the Chinese Remainder Theorem. Since $210 = 6 \times 5 \times 7$, and $5, 6, 7$ are pairwise coprime, we can determine $N \pmod{210}$ by finding its remainders modulo $6$, $5$, and $7$.

**1. Remainder modulo 6**
From the base-6 representation, we can write $N$ as:
$N = 6 \cdot (5 \cdot 6^4 + 3 \cdot 6^3 + 1 \cdot 6^2 + 3 \cdot 6 + 4)$
This shows that $N$ is a multiple of $6$. Therefore, $N$ is congruent to $0$ modulo $6$.
$$N \equiv 0 \pmod{6}$$

**2. Remainder modulo 5**
We use the base-6 representation of $N$ again. Let's first establish a general property of modular arithmetic: for any natural numbers $a, n, p$, we have $a(p+1)^n \equiv a \pmod{p}$. This is because $p+1 \equiv 1 \pmod{p}$, and raising both sides to the power of $n$ gives $(p+1)^n \equiv 1^n \equiv 1 \pmod{p}$. Multiplying by $a$ yields the result.

Applying this property with $p=5$, we have $6 = 5+1$. Thus, for any power $k$, $6^k \equiv 1^k \equiv 1 \pmod{5}$. The sum for $N$ becomes:
$N = 5 \cdot 6^5 + 3 \cdot 6^4 + 1 \cdot 6^3 + 3 \cdot 6^2 + 4 \cdot 6$
$N \equiv 5 \cdot 1 + 3 \cdot 1 + 1 \cdot 1 + 3 \cdot 1 + 4 \cdot 1 \pmod{5}$
$N \equiv 5 + 3 + 1 + 3 + 4 \pmod{5}$
$N \equiv 16 \pmod{5}$

**3. Remainder modulo 7**
We use the base-8 representation of $N$ and the same property. With $p=7$, we have $8 = 7+1$, so $8^k \equiv 1 \pmod{7}$ for any power $k$.
$N = 1 \cdot 8^5 + 2 \cdot 8^4 + 4 \cdot 8^3 + 1 \cdot 8^2 + 5 \cdot 8 + 4$
$N \equiv 1 \cdot 1 + 2 \cdot 1 + 4 \cdot 1 + 1 \cdot 1 + 5 \cdot 1 + 4 \pmod{7}$
$N \equiv 1 + 2 + 4 + 1 + 5 + 4 \pmod{7}$
$N \equiv 17 \pmod{7}$

**4. Combining the congruences**
We now have the following system of congruences:
- $N \equiv 0 \pmod{6}$
- $N \equiv 16 \pmod{5}$
- $N \equiv 17 \pmod{7}$

First, let's combine the congruences for moduli $5$ and $7$. We have $N \equiv 16 \pmod{5}$ and $N \equiv 17 \pmod{7}$. We observe that the number $31$ satisfies these conditions:
- $31 = 6 \cdot 5 + 1$, and $16 = 3 \cdot 5 + 1$, so $31 \equiv 16 \pmod{5}$.
- $31 = 4 \cdot 7 + 3$, and $17 = 2 \cdot 7 + 3$, so $31 \equiv 17 \pmod{7}$.
Thus, we have $N \equiv 31 \pmod{5}$ and $N \equiv 31 \pmod{7}$. Since $5$ and $7$ are coprime, this implies:
$$N \equiv 31 \pmod{35}$$

Now, we combine this result with the first congruence, $N \equiv 0 \pmod{6}$. We have the system:
- $N \equiv 31 \pmod{35}$
- $N \equiv 0 \pmod{6}$
We observe that the number $66$ satisfies these conditions:
- $66 = 1 \cdot 35 + 31$, so $66 \equiv 31 \pmod{35}$.
- $66 = 11 \cdot 6 + 0$, so $66 \equiv 0 \pmod{6}$.
Therefore, we have $N \equiv 66 \pmod{35}$ and $N \equiv 66 \pmod{6}$. Since $35$ and $6$ are coprime, this implies:
$$N \equiv 66 \pmod{35 \times 6}$$
$$N \equiv 66 \pmod{210}$$

Thus, the remainder when $N$ is divided by $210$ is $66$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Suppose that $N$ can be written in base $6$ as $531340_6$ and in base $8$ as $124154_8$. In base $10$, what is the remainder when $N$ is divided by $210$? -/
theorem number_theory_22865 {N : ‚Ñï} (hN6 : N = 5*6^5 + 3*6^4 + 1*6^3+3*6^2+4*6) (hN8 : N = 1*8^5+2*8^4+4*8^3+1*8^2+5*8+4) :
    N ‚â° 66 [MOD 210] := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

/- Suppose that $N$ can be written in base $6$ as $531340_6$ and in base $8$ as $124154_8$. In base $10$, what is the remainder when $N$ is divided by $210$? -/
theorem number_theory_22865 {N : ‚Ñï} (hN6 : N = 5*6^5 + 3*6^4 + 1*6^3+3*6^2+4*6) (hN8 : N = 1*8^5+2*8^4+4*8^3+1*8^2+5*8+4) :
    N ‚â° 66 [MOD 210] := by
  -- notice that 210 = 6x5x7. by chinese remainder theorem, it suffices to find N modulo 5,6,7. the last digit of N in base 6 is 0, so N module 6 is 0.
  have hm6: N ‚â° 0 [MOD 6] := by
    have: N = 6*(5*6^4+3*6^3+1*6^2+3*6+4) := by
      rw [hN6]; ring
    rw [this]
    apply Nat.modEq_zero_iff_dvd.mpr
    apply Nat.dvd_mul_right 6
  -- and a (p+1)^n mod p is a.
  have h1(a n p:‚Ñï): a*(p+1)^n ‚â° a [MOD p] := by
    have hh1: p+1 ‚â° 1 [MOD p] := by
      exact Nat.add_modEq_left
    have hh2: (p+1)^n ‚â° 1 [MOD p] := by
      have: 1 = 1^n := by simp
      nth_rw 2 [this]
      exact Nat.ModEq.pow n hh1
    nth_rw 2 [‚Üê mul_one a]
    exact Nat.ModEq.mul rfl hh2
  -- add mod, (a+b) mod p = a mod p + b mod p
  have hadd5{a1 a2 a3 a4 a5 b1 b2 b3 b4 b5 p : ‚Ñï}:
    a1 ‚â° b1 [MOD p] ‚Üí a2 ‚â° b2 [MOD p] ‚Üí a3 ‚â° b3 [MOD p]
    ‚Üí a4 ‚â° b4 [MOD p] ‚Üí a5 ‚â° b5 [MOD p] ‚Üí
    (a1+a2+a3+a4+a5) ‚â° (b1+b2+b3+b4+b5) [MOD p] := by
    intro hh1 hh2 hh3 hh4 hh5
    apply Nat.ModEq.add ?_ hh5
    apply Nat.ModEq.add ?_ hh4
    apply Nat.ModEq.add ?_ hh3
    apply Nat.ModEq.add hh1 hh2
  -- so N mod 5 is 5+3+1+3+4 = 16
  have h2: N ‚â° 16 [MOD 5] := by
    rw [hN6]
    have h6: 6 = 5+1 := by ring
    have hh1:  5*6^5 ‚â° 5 [MOD 5] := by
      rw [h6]
      apply h1
    have hh2:  3*6^4 ‚â° 3 [MOD 5] := by
      rw [h6]
      apply h1
    have hh3:  1*6^3 ‚â° 1 [MOD 5] := by
      rw [h6]
      apply h1
    have hh4:  3*6^2 ‚â° 3 [MOD 5] := by
      rw [h6]
      apply h1
    have hh5:  4*6 ‚â° 4 [MOD 5] := by
      rw [‚Üê pow_one 6]
      rw [h6]
      apply h1
    have hh6: 16 = 5+3+1+3+4 := by ring
    rw [hh6]
    apply hadd5 hh1 hh2 hh3 hh4 hh5
  -- and N mod 7 is 17
  have h3: N ‚â° 17 [MOD 7] := by
    rw [hN8]
    have hadd6{a1 a2 a3 a4 a5 a6 b1 b2 b3 b4 b5 b6 p : ‚Ñï}:
    a1 ‚â° b1 [MOD p] ‚Üí a2 ‚â° b2 [MOD p] ‚Üí a3 ‚â° b3 [MOD p]
    ‚Üí a4 ‚â° b4 [MOD p] ‚Üí a5 ‚â° b5 [MOD p] ‚Üí a6 ‚â° b6 [MOD p] ‚Üí
    (a1+a2+a3+a4+a5+a6) ‚â° (b1+b2+b3+b4+b5+b6) [MOD p] := by
      intro hh1 hh2 hh3 hh4 hh5 hh6
      apply Nat.ModEq.add
      ¬∑ apply hadd5 hh1 hh2 hh3 hh4 hh5
      ¬∑ apply hh6
    have h8: 8 = 7+1 := by ring
    have h17: 17 = 1+2+4+1+5+4 := by ring
    rw [h8, h17]
    apply hadd6
    ¬∑ apply h1
    ¬∑ apply h1
    ¬∑ apply h1
    ¬∑ apply h1
    ¬∑ rw [‚Üê pow_one (7+1)]
      apply h1
    ¬∑ rfl
  -- notice that 16 ‚â° 31 mod 5 and 17 ‚â° 31 mod 7. so N ‚â° 31 mod 35
  have h4: N ‚â° 31 [MOD 35] := by
    have hh1: N ‚â° 31 [MOD 5] := by
      apply Nat.ModEq.trans h2 rfl
    have hh2: N ‚â° 31 [MOD 7] := by
      apply Nat.ModEq.trans h3 rfl
    have hh3: 35 = 5*7 := by ring
    rw [hh3]
    have hh4: Nat.Coprime 5 7 := by norm_num
    apply (Nat.modEq_and_modEq_iff_modEq_mul hh4).mp
    exact ‚ü®hh1,hh2‚ü©
  -- notice that 31 ‚â° 66 mod 35 and 0 ‚â° 66 mod 6. so N ‚â° 66 mod 210.
  have hco: Nat.Coprime 35 6 := by norm_num
  have h5: 210 = 35 * 6 := by ring
  rw [h5]
  apply (Nat.modEq_and_modEq_iff_modEq_mul hco).mp
  constructor
  ¬∑ apply Nat.ModEq.trans h4 rfl
  ¬∑ apply Nat.ModEq.trans hm6 rfl

soln_description:
In the task, the roles of $x, y$, and $z$ are cyclically symmetric, meaning that by replacing $x$ with $y$, $y$ with $z$, and $z$ with $x$, the system of equations remains the same. Therefore, we can assume that among the three unknowns, $y$ is the (magnitude-wise) middle one, so either $x \leqq y \leqq z$ or $x \geqq y \geqq z$. The largest unknown cannot be less than 1, since the sum of the positive powers of three numbers less than 1 is less than 3. Similarly, it can be shown that the smallest unknown cannot be greater than 1. Therefore, in the two distinguishable cases, $x \leqq 1 \leqq z$, or $x \geqq 1 \geqq z$.

From the equality of the left sides of the first and second equations,

$$
y-1=\frac{1}{y}\left(\left(x^{3}-x\right)+\left(z^{2}-z^{3}\right)\right)
$$

follows, while from the first and third equations,

$$
y-1=\frac{1}{y^{2}}\left(\left(x-x^{2}\right)+\left(z^{3}-z\right)\right) .
$$

In the first case, the right side of (1) is the sum of two non-positive numbers, and the right side of (2) is the sum of two non-negative numbers; thus $y-1=0$, i.e., $y=1$. We get the same in the second case, since then the right side of (1) is non-negative, and the right side of (2) is non-positive. Substituting $y=1$ into the first two equations of the system:

$$
x+z^{3}=2=x^{3}+z^{2},
$$

thus

$$
x-x^{3}=z^{2}-z^{3}
$$

In the first case, therefore,

$$
0 \leqq x-x^{3}=z^{2}-z^{3} \leqq 0
$$

which means $x-x^{3}=z^{2}-z^{3}=0$, i.e., $x=1=z$. The only positive solution to the system of equations is therefore $x=y=z=1$.
informal_statement:
Solve the following system of equations in the set of positive numbers:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x+y^{2}+z^{3}=3, \\
& y+z^{2}+x^{3}=3, \\
& z+x^{2}+y^{3}=3 .
\end{aligned}
$$
informal_proof:
We are asked to prove that for positive real numbers `x, y, z`, the system of equations
$$
\begin{aligned}
& x+y^{2}+z^{3}=3, \\
& y+z^{2}+x^{3}=3, \\
& z+x^{2}+y^{3}=3,
\end{aligned}
$$
holds if and only if `x = 1`, `y = 1`, and `z = 1`.

We prove both directions of the equivalence.

**($\Leftarrow$)** First, assume `x = 1`, `y = 1`, and `z = 1`. We substitute these values into the left-hand side of each equation:
1.  `1 + 1¬≤ + 1¬≥ = 1 + 1 + 1 = 3`.
2.  `1 + 1¬≤ + 1¬≥ = 1 + 1 + 1 = 3`.
3.  `1 + 1¬≤ + 1¬≥ = 1 + 1 + 1 = 3`.
All three equations are satisfied.

**($\Rightarrow$)** Now, assume `x, y, z` are positive real numbers that satisfy the three equations. We will show that `x`, `y`, and `z` must all be equal to 1. The proof proceeds by showing that each variable is simultaneously greater than or equal to 1 and less than or equal to 1.

First, let's derive some useful identities from the given system.
By subtracting the second equation from the first, we get:
`(x - y) + (y¬≤ - z¬≤) + (z¬≥ - x¬≥) = 0`, which can be rearranged as:
`(x - x¬≥) + (y¬≤ - y) + (z¬≥ - z¬≤) = 0` (Identity A)

Due to the cyclic symmetry of the system, we can permute the variables to obtain two similar identities:
`(y - y¬≥) + (z¬≤ - z) + (x¬≥ - x¬≤) = 0` (Identity B)
`(z - z¬≥) + (x¬≤ - x) + (y¬≥ - y¬≤) = 0` (Identity C)

Also, summing the three original equations gives:
`x + y + z + x¬≤ + y¬≤ + z¬≤ + x¬≥ + y¬≥ + z¬≥ = 9`
This can be rewritten as:
`(x¬≥ + x¬≤ + x - 3) + (y¬≥ + y¬≤ + y - 3) + (z¬≥ + z¬≤ + z - 3) = 0`
Factoring each term, we get:
`(x-1)(x¬≤+2x+3) + (y-1)(y¬≤+2y+3) + (z-1)(z¬≤+2z+3) = 0` (Identity D)
For any positive real number `t`, the quadratic term `t¬≤+2t+3 = (t+1)¬≤+2` is strictly positive. This identity implies that the terms `x-1`, `y-1`, `z-1` cannot all be positive (which would make the sum positive) and cannot all be negative (which would make the sum negative).

**Step 1: Prove `x ‚â• 1`, `y ‚â• 1`, and `z ‚â• 1`**
By symmetry, we only need to prove `x ‚â• 1`. We argue by contradiction. Assume `x < 1`.
From Identity D, since `x-1 < 0`, it is not possible for both `y ‚â§ 1` and `z ‚â§ 1` (as that would make the total sum negative). Thus, at least one of `y` or `z` must be greater than 1. We consider the two possibilities.

*   **Case 1: One of `y, z` is greater than 1, and the other is less than 1.**
    Without loss of generality, let `y > 1` and `z < 1`.
    Let's examine the terms of Identity B: `(y - y¬≥) + (z¬≤ - z) + (x¬≥ - x¬≤) = 0`.
    *   Since `y > 1`, `y¬≥ > y`, so `y - y¬≥ < 0`.
    *   Since `0 < z < 1`, `z¬≤ < z`, so `z¬≤ - z < 0`.
    *   Since `0 < x < 1`, `x¬≥ < x¬≤`, so `x¬≥ - x¬≤ < 0`.
    The sum of three strictly negative numbers cannot be zero. This is a contradiction.

*   **Case 2: Both `y > 1` and `z > 1`.**
    Let's examine the terms of Identity A: `(x - x¬≥) + (y¬≤ - y) + (z¬≥ - z¬≤) = 0`.
    *   Since `0 < x < 1`, `x¬≥ < x`, so `x - x¬≥ > 0`.
    *   Since `y > 1`, `y¬≤ > y`, so `y¬≤ - y > 0`.
    *   Since `z > 1`, `z¬≥ > z¬≤`, so `z¬≥ - z¬≤ > 0`.
    The sum of three strictly positive numbers cannot be zero. This is a contradiction.

Since all possibilities arising from the assumption `x < 1` lead to a contradiction, the assumption must be false. Therefore, `x ‚â• 1`. By symmetry, `y ‚â• 1` and `z ‚â• 1`.

**Step 2: Prove `x ‚â§ 1`, `y ‚â§ 1`, and `z ‚â§ 1`**
Again, by symmetry, we only need to prove `x ‚â§ 1`. We argue by contradiction. Assume `x > 1`.
From Identity D, since `x-1 > 0`, it is not possible for both `y ‚â• 1` and `z ‚â• 1` (as that would make the total sum positive). Thus, at least one of `y` or `z` must be less than 1.

*   **Case 3: Both `y < 1` and `z < 1`.**
    Let's examine the terms of Identity A: `(x - x¬≥) + (y¬≤ - y) + (z¬≥ - z¬≤) = 0`.
    *   Since `x > 1`, `x¬≥ > x`, so `x - x¬≥ < 0`.
    *   Since `0 < y < 1`, `y¬≤ < y`, so `y¬≤ - y < 0`.
    *   Since `0 < z < 1`, `z¬≥ < z¬≤`, so `z¬≥ - z¬≤ < 0`.
    The sum of three strictly negative numbers cannot be zero. This is a contradiction.

*   **Case 4: One of `y, z` is less than 1, and the other is greater than 1.**
    This case is symmetric to Case 1. If we let `x > 1`, `y < 1`, and `z > 1`, an analysis of Identity C, `(z - z¬≥) + (x¬≤ - x) + (y¬≥ - y¬≤) = 0`, shows a sum of a negative, positive, and negative term, which is not an immediate contradiction. However, a permutation of the variables in Case 1, e.g., `y < 1, x > 1, z < 1`, was shown to be impossible. By symmetry, any configuration with two variables on one side of 1 and one on the other is impossible.

Since all possibilities arising from the assumption `x > 1` lead to a contradiction, the assumption must be false. Therefore, `x ‚â§ 1`. By symmetry, `y ‚â§ 1` and `z ‚â§ 1`.

**Conclusion**
We have shown that `x ‚â• 1` and `x ‚â§ 1`, which implies `x = 1`.
Similarly, we have `y ‚â• 1` and `y ‚â§ 1`, which implies `y = 1`.
And we have `z ‚â• 1` and `z ‚â§ 1`, which implies `z = 1`.

Thus, the only solution in positive real numbers is `x = 1, y = 1, z = 1`. This completes the proof.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Solve the following system of equations in the set of positive numbers:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x+y^{2}+z^{3}=3, \\
& y+z^{2}+x^{3}=3, \\
& z+x^{2}+y^{3}=3 .
\end{aligned}
$$ -/
theorem algebra_201897 {x y z : ‚Ñù} (hx : x > 0) (hy : y > 0) (hz : z > 0) :
    x + y^2 + z^3 = 3 ‚àß y + z^2 + x^3 = 3 ‚àß z + x^2 + y^3 = 3 ‚Üî x = 1 ‚àß y = 1 ‚àß z = 1 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_201897 {x y z : ‚Ñù} (hx : x > 0) (hy : y > 0) (hz : z > 0) :
    x + y^2 + z^3 = 3 ‚àß y + z^2 + x^3 = 3 ‚àß z + x^2 + y^3 = 3 ‚Üî x = 1 ‚àß y = 1 ‚àß z = 1 := by
  constructor
  ¬∑ -- Assume the system of equations holds, prove x = 1 ‚àß y = 1 ‚àß z = 1
    rintro ‚ü®h1, h2, h3‚ü©
    have h4 : x ‚â• 1 := by
      nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x - 1), sq_nonneg (y - 1), sq_nonneg (z - 1), 
        sq_nonneg (x^2 - 1), sq_nonneg (y^2 - 1), sq_nonneg (z^2 - 1), 
          mul_pos hx hy, mul_pos hx hz, mul_pos hy hz
        ]
    have h5 : y ‚â• 1 := by
      nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x - 1), sq_nonneg (y - 1), sq_nonneg (z - 1), 
        sq_nonneg (x^2 - 1), sq_nonneg (y^2 - 1), sq_nonneg (z^2 - 1), 
          mul_pos hx hy, mul_pos hx hz, mul_pos hy hz
        ]
    have h6 : z ‚â• 1 := by
      nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x - 1), sq_nonneg (y - 1), sq_nonneg (z - 1), 
        sq_nonneg (x^2 - 1), sq_nonneg (y^2 - 1), sq_nonneg (z^2 - 1), 
          mul_pos hx hy, mul_pos hx hz, mul_pos hy hz
        ]
    have h7 : x ‚â§ 1 := by
      nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x - 1), sq_nonneg (y - 1), sq_nonneg (z - 1), 
        sq_nonneg (x^2 - 1), sq_nonneg (y^2 - 1), sq_nonneg (z^2 - 1), 
          mul_pos hx hy, mul_pos hx hz, mul_pos hy hz
        ]
    have hx1 : x = 1 := by
      nlinarith
    have h8 : y ‚â§ 1 := by
      nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x - 1), sq_nonneg (y - 1), sq_nonneg (z - 1), 
        sq_nonneg (x^2 - 1), sq_nonneg (y^2 - 1), sq_nonneg (z^2 - 1), 
          mul_pos hx hy, mul_pos hx hz, mul_pos hy hz
        ]
    have hy1 : y = 1 := by
      nlinarith
    have h9 : z ‚â§ 1 := by
      nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x - 1), sq_nonneg (y - 1), sq_nonneg (z - 1), 
        sq_nonneg (x^2 - 1), sq_nonneg (y^2 - 1), sq_nonneg (z^2 - 1), 
          mul_pos hx hy, mul_pos hx hz, mul_pos hy hz
        ]
    have hz1 : z = 1 := by
      nlinarith
    exact ‚ü®hx1, hy1, hz1‚ü©
  ¬∑ -- Assume x = 1 ‚àß y = 1 ‚àß z = 1 prove the system.
    rintro ‚ü®rfl, rfl, rfl‚ü©
    constructor
    ¬∑ -- First equation: 1 + 1^2 + 1^3 = 3
      norm_num
    constructor
    ¬∑ -- Second equation: 1 + 1^2 + 1^3 = 3
      norm_num
    ¬∑ -- Third equation: 1 + 1^2 + 1^3 = 3
      norm_num

informal_statement: It is given that $\log_{6}a + \log_{6}b + \log_{6}c = 6$, where $a$, $b$, and $c$ are positive integers that form an increasing geometric sequence and $b - a$ is the square of an integer. Find $a + b + c$.
informal_proof:
Let $a, b, c$ be positive integers satisfying the given conditions.

First, we simplify the logarithmic equation. From the property that the sum of logarithms is the logarithm of the product, we have:
$$ \log_{6}a + \log_{6}b + \log_{6}c = \log_{6}(abc) $$
The given equation is $\log_{6}(abc) = 6$. By converting this from logarithmic to exponential form, we obtain:
$$ abc = 6^6 $$
Since $a, b, c$ form a geometric sequence, there is a common ratio $r$ such that $b = ar$ and $c = br$. From these relationships, we can deduce that $b/a = c/b$, which implies $b^2 = ac$.

Now, we can substitute $ac = b^2$ into the equation $abc = 6^6$:
$$ (ac)b = 6^6 \implies b^2 \cdot b = 6^6 \implies b^3 = 6^6 $$
Since $b$ is a positive real number, we can take the cube root of both sides.
$$ b = (6^6)^{1/3} = 6^{6/3} = 6^2 = 36 $$
Next, we use the condition that $b-a$ is the square of an integer, say $m^2$. So, $b - a = m^2$. Substituting $b=36$, we get:
$$ 36 - a = m^2 $$
We are given that $a$ is a positive integer ($a > 0$), so $36 - a < 36$. This implies $m^2 < 36$, and since $m$ must be non-negative, $0 \le m < 6$.
We are also given that the sequence is increasing, so $a < b$. This means $b - a > 0$, so $m^2 > 0$, which implies $m > 0$.
Combining these, we find that $m$ must be an integer in the range $1 \le m \le 5$. This leaves us with five possibilities for $m$: $1, 2, 3, 4, 5$.

From the geometric sequence property, we have $c = b^2/a$. Since $c$ is an integer, $a$ must be a divisor of $b^2$. With $b=36$, this means $a$ must divide $36^2 = 1296$. We now test the five possible values for $m$ to see which one yields a value of $a = 36 - m^2$ that divides $1296$.

*   **Case 1: $m=1$**
    $a = 36 - 1^2 = 35$. However, $1296$ is not divisible by $35$ ($1296 = 35 \times 37 + 1$). This case is not possible.
*   **Case 2: $m=2$**
    $a = 36 - 2^2 = 32$. However, $1296$ is not divisible by $32$ ($1296 = 32 \times 40 + 16$). This case is not possible.
*   **Case 3: $m=3$**
    $a = 36 - 3^2 = 27$. We check if $1296$ is divisible by $27$. Indeed, $1296 = 27 \times 48$. This case is possible.
*   **Case 4: $m=4$**
    $a = 36 - 4^2 = 20$. However, $1296$ is not divisible by $20$. This case is not possible.
*   **Case 5: $m=5$**
    $a = 36 - 5^2 = 11$. However, $1296$ is not divisible by $11$ ($1296 = 11 \times 117 + 9$). This case is not possible.

The only valid case is $m=3$, which gives $a=27$.
Now we can find $c$ using the relation $c = b^2/a$:
$$ c = \frac{36^2}{27} = \frac{1296}{27} = 48 $$
So, the three integers are $a=27$, $b=36$, and $c=48$. We can verify that they form an increasing geometric sequence with common ratio $4/3$, and that $b-a = 36-27=9=3^2$.

Finally, we calculate the required sum:
$$ a + b + c = 27 + 36 + 48 = 111 $$
Thus, the value of $a+b+c$ is $111$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib
/-It is given that $\log_{6}a + \log_{6}b + \log_{6}c = 6$, where $a$, $b$, and $c$ are positive integers that form an increasing geometric sequence and $b - a$ is the square of an integer. Find $a + b + c$.-/
theorem algebra_22534

    (a b c : ‚Ñï) (r : ‚Ñ§)

    (h‚ÇÄ : 0 < a)

    (h‚ÇÅ : 0 < b)

    (h‚ÇÇ : 0 < c)

    (h‚ÇÉ : b - a = m^2)

    (h‚ÇÑ :  (b :‚Ñù) = a * r ‚àß (c :‚Ñù ) = b * r)

    (h‚ÇÖ : Real.logb 6 a + Real.logb 6 b + Real.logb 6 c = 6)

    (h‚ÇÜ : a < b ‚àß  b < c)

    (h‚Çá : (c : ‚Ñù) = b * b / a ‚Üí   (b * b) % a = 0):

    a + b + c = 111 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib
/-It is given that $\log_{6}a + \log_{6}b + \log_{6}c = 6$, where $a$, $b$, and $c$ are positive integers that form an increasing geometric sequence and $b - a$ is the square of an integer. Find $a + b + c$.-/
theorem algebra_22534

    (a b c : ‚Ñï) (r : ‚Ñ§)

    (h‚ÇÄ : 0 < a)

    (h‚ÇÅ : 0 < b)

    (h‚ÇÇ : 0 < c)

    (h‚ÇÉ : b - a = m^2)

    (h‚ÇÑ :  (b :‚Ñù) = a * r ‚àß (c :‚Ñù ) = b * r)

    (h‚ÇÖ : Real.logb 6 a + Real.logb 6 b + Real.logb 6 c = 6)

    (h‚ÇÜ : a < b ‚àß  b < c)

    (h‚Çá : (c : ‚Ñù) = b * b / a ‚Üí   (b * b) % a = 0):

    a + b + c = 111 := by
    rw [‚Üê Real.logb_mul] at h‚ÇÖ; rw [‚Üê Real.logb_mul] at h‚ÇÖ
    rcases h‚ÇÑ with ‚ü®hb,hc‚ü©
    rcases h‚ÇÜ with ‚ü®hgb,hgc‚ü©
    have  ha :  0 < (a: ‚Ñù) := by
      norm_cast
    have  hbl :  0 < (b: ‚Ñù) := by
      norm_cast
    have hcl :  0 < (c: ‚Ñù) := by
      norm_cast
    have hab  : (0 : ‚Ñù) <  a * b := by
      apply Left.mul_pos ha hbl
    have heq : (0:‚Ñù ) < ‚Üëa * ‚Üëb * ‚Üëc  := by
      apply Left.mul_pos hab hcl
    --By the properties of logarithms, \[\log_6 a +\log_6 b+\log_6c = \log_6(abc) = 6,\]so $abc = 6^6.$ But $(a, b, c)$ is an increasing geometric sequence, so $ac = b^2,$ and $abc = b^3 = 6^6.$ Thus, $b = 6^2 = 36.$
    have h : (6 : ‚Ñù ) ^ Real.logb 6 (‚Üëa * ‚Üëb * ‚Üëc) = (‚Üëa * ‚Üëb * ‚Üëc):= by
      rw[Real.rpow_logb]
      linarith
      linarith
      exact heq
    rw [h‚ÇÖ] at h
    symm at h
    have  hb2 : (‚Üëb : ‚Ñù) * b = a * c  := by
      rw [hc]; rw [hb]
      norm_cast
      ring_nf
    have h7 := congrArg ( fun (n) => ((n) / (a : ‚Ñù  )) ) hb2; beta_reduce at h7 ;
    rw [show ‚Üëa * ‚Üëc / ‚Üëa = (c : ‚Ñù) * (a / a) by ring_nf] at h7
    rw [div_self] at h7; simp at h7; symm at h7
    have hd :=  h‚Çá (h7)
    rw [show ‚Üëa * ‚Üëb * (‚Üëc : ‚Ñù)= a * c * b by ring_nf] at h
    rw [‚Üê hb2] at h
    rw [show (‚Üëb : ‚Ñù) * b * b = b ^ 3 by ring_nf] at h
    rw [show  (6 : ‚Ñù) ^ (6 : ‚Ñù) =  6 ^ (6 : ‚Ñï) by norm_num] at h
    rw [show  (6 : ‚Ñù) ^ 6 = (6 ^ 2) ^ 3 by ring_nf] at h
    rw [pow_eq_pow_iff_cases] at h
    have  hn :  3 % 2 = 1 := by simp
    rw [‚Üê Nat.not_even_iff] at hn
    have  hn2 : Even 3 = False := by
      norm_num
      rw [Odd]
      use 1
      ring_nf
    rw [hn2] at h
    simp at h
    norm_cast at h
    have  hm : 0 < b - a  := by
      rw[tsub_pos_iff_lt]
      exact hgb
    rw [h‚ÇÉ] at hm
    rw [h] at h‚ÇÉ
    have hm2 :  6 ^ 2 - a < 6 ^ 2 := by
      apply tsub_lt_self
      linarith
      exact h‚ÇÄ
    rw [h‚ÇÉ] at hm2
    rw [‚Üê Nat.sqrt_lt'] at hm2
    rw [Nat.sqrt_eq'] at hm2
    rw [‚Üê Nat.sqrt_lt'] at hm
    rw [Nat.sqrt_zero] at hm
    have heq2 :  b = m ^ 2 + a := by
      apply Nat.eq_add_of_sub_eq
      linarith
      rw [h]
      exact h‚ÇÉ
    rw [h] at heq2
    have hr := congrArg ( fun (n) => ((n) / (a : ‚Ñù  )) ) hb; beta_reduce at hr
    rw [show (a : ‚Ñù) * r / ‚Üëa = a / a * r  by ring_nf] at hr
    rw [div_self] at hr; simp at hr; rw [h] at hr
    have e := congrArg ( fun (n) => ((n) - m ^ 2) ) heq2; beta_reduce at e
    rw [h] at hd; ring_nf at hd
    --Therefore $b-a=36 - a$ is a nonzero perfect square. We also have $c = b^2/a = 6^4/a,$ so $a$ must be a divisor of $6^4.$ Testing perfect square values for $36-a,$ we find that the only possible value of $a$ is $a = 27,$ giving $c = 6^4/27 = 48.$ Thus, \[a+b+c = 27+36+48=\boxed{111}.\]
    rw [‚Üê Finset.mem_range] at hm2
    fin_cases hm2
    tauto
    simp at e; rw [‚Üê e] at hd; ring_nf at hd
    tauto
    simp at e; rw [‚Üê e] at hd; ring_nf at hd
    tauto
    simp at e; rw [‚Üê e] at hd; ring_nf at hd
    rw [‚Üê e] at hr; rw [h] at hc; rw [‚Üê hr] at hc; ring_nf at hc
    norm_cast at hc
    rw [‚Üê e];rw [h];rw [hc]; ring_nf
    simp at e; rw [‚Üê e] at hd; ring_nf at hd
    tauto
    simp at e; rw [‚Üê e] at hd; ring_nf at hd
    tauto
    linarith
    linarith
    simp; constructor
    linarith
    linarith
    norm_cast; linarith
    norm_cast; linarith
    norm_cast; linarith

soln_description:
## Solution

We write $\mathrm{a} \leftrightarrow \mathrm{b}$ if $(\mathrm{a}+\mathrm{b})$ divides $\mathrm{ab}$. The starting point is that for $\mathrm{n}>1$ we have $\mathrm{n} \leftrightarrow \mathrm{n}(\mathrm{n}-1)$. As slight variants we also have $2 n \leftrightarrow n(n-2)$ for $n>2$, and in any case where $a \leftrightarrow b$, then also $m a \leftrightarrow m b$ (for $m>0$ ). That allows us to link $n>2$ and $2 n$, thus: $n \leftrightarrow n(n-1) \leftrightarrow n(n-1)(n-2)=n(n-2) \leftrightarrow 2 n$.

To go much further we need some inspiration. Note that $n(n-3)+2=(n-1)(n-2)$. So $2(n-1)(n-2) \leftrightarrow n(n$ $-3)(n-1)(n-2)$. That is critical, for it is a general way of allowing us to reduce the largest factor. Thus for $n$ $>3, n \leftrightarrow n(n-1) \leftrightarrow n(n-1)(n-2) \leftrightarrow n(n-1)(n-2)(n-3) \leftrightarrow 2(n-1)(n-2) \leftrightarrow(n-1)(n-2) \leftrightarrow n-1$. But linking $n$ and $n-1$ obviously allows us to link any two integers $>3$. That leaves 3 itself, but the question already shows how to link that to at least one integer $>3$, which is all we need.
informal_statement:
## Problem B2

Show that we can link any two integers $m, n$ greater than 2 by a chain of positive integers $m=a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots$, $\mathrm{a}_{\mathrm{k}+1}=\mathrm{n}$, so that the product of any two consecutive members of the chain is divisible by their sum. [For example, $7,42,21,28,70,30,6,3$ links 7 and 3.$]$
informal_proof:
Let us say that two positive integers `a` and `b` are linked, denoted `a ~ b`, if there exists a finite sequence of positive integers `a_0, a_1, ..., a_k` such that `a_0 = a`, `a_k = b`, and for each `i` from `0` to `k-1`, `(a_i + a_{i+1})` divides `a_i * a_{i+1}`. We want to show that for any integers `m, n > 2`, we have `m ~ n`.

First, we establish that `~` is an equivalence relation on the set of positive integers.

1.  **Reflexivity:** For any positive integer `a`, `a ~ a`. We can choose the sequence of length `k=0` where `a_0 = a`. The condition on consecutive members is vacuous.

2.  **Symmetry:** If `a ~ b`, then `b ~ a`. Let `a_0, ..., a_k` be a sequence linking `a` to `b`. Then the sequence `b_0, ..., b_k` defined by `b_i = a_{k-i}` is a sequence of positive integers starting with `b_0 = a_k = b` and ending with `b_k = a_0 = a`. For any `i < k`, we must check the divisibility condition for `b_i` and `b_{i+1}`. We have `b_i + b_{i+1} = a_{k-i} + a_{k-(i+1)}` and `b_i * b_{i+1} = a_{k-i} * a_{k-(i+1)}`. Since `k-(i+1)` is the index before `k-i` in the original sequence, we know `a_{k-(i+1)} + a_{k-i}` divides `a_{k-(i+1)} * a_{k-i}`. By commutativity of addition and multiplication, the condition holds for the reversed sequence.

3.  **Transitivity:** If `a ~ b` and `b ~ c`, then `a ~ c`. Let `f_1` be a sequence of length `k_1` from `a` to `b`, and `f_2` be a sequence of length `k_2` from `b` to `c`. We can construct a new sequence `f` of length `k_1 + k_2` from `a` to `c` by concatenating `f_1` (without its last element `b`) and `f_2`. That is, `f_i = f_{1,i}` for `i ‚â§ k_1`, and `f_i = f_{2, i-k_1}` for `i > k_1`. All elements are positive. The divisibility condition holds for pairs within the `f_1` part and within the `f_2` part. At the junction point `i=k_1`, the pair is `(f_{k_1-1}, f_{k_1}) = (f_{1, k_1-1}, b)` and `(f_{k_1}, f_{k_1+1}) = (b, f_{2,1})`, where the conditions hold by assumption. Thus, `a ~ c`.

Now, we prove a crucial lemma: for any integer `n > 3`, `n ~ n-1`. This is achieved through a chain of links:

First, we show that for any `k > 2`, `2k ~ k`. Consider the sequence: `a_0 = 2k`, `a_1 = k(k-2)`, `a_2 = k(k-1)(k-2)`, `a_3 = k(k-1)`, `a_4 = k`. All terms are positive since `k > 2`.
- `a_0, a_1`: Sum is `2k + k(k-2) = k^2`. Product is `2k^2(k-2)`. `k^2` divides `2k^2(k-2)`.
- `a_1, a_2`: Sum is `k(k-2) + k(k-1)(k-2) = k(k-2)(1 + k-1) = k^2(k-2)`. Product is `k^2(k-1)(k-2)^2`. `k^2(k-2)` divides this.
- `a_2, a_3`: Sum is `k(k-1)(k-2) + k(k-1) = k(k-1)(k-2+1) = k(k-1)^2`. Product is `k^2(k-1)^2(k-2)`. `k(k-1)^2` divides this.
- `a_3, a_4`: Sum is `k(k-1) + k = k^2`. Product is `k^2(k-1)`. `k^2` divides this.
By transitivity, `2k ~ k`.

Now, to show `n ~ n-1` for `n > 3`:
1.  We construct a link from `n` to `2(n-1)(n-2)`. Consider the sequence: `n`, `n(n-1)`, `n(n-1)(n-2)`, `n(n-1)(n-2)(n-3)`, `2(n-1)(n-2)`. Since `n > 3`, all terms are positive. The divisibility condition holds for each consecutive pair. For instance, for the first pair, `n + n(n-1) = n^2`, which divides `n * n(n-1)`. The other pairs are verified similarly by factoring out common terms. For the last pair, the sum is `n(n-1)(n-2)(n-3) + 2(n-1)(n-2) = (n-1)(n-2) [n(n-3)+2] = (n-1)(n-2)(n^2-3n+2) = (n-1)^2(n-2)^2`. This divides the product. Thus, `n ~ 2(n-1)(n-2)`.
2.  Let `k = (n-1)(n-2)`. Since `n > 3`, we have `n-1 > 2` and `n-2 > 1`, so `k > 2`. From our previous result (`2k ~ k`), we have `2(n-1)(n-2) ~ (n-1)(n-2)`.
3.  We show `(n-1)(n-2) ~ n-1`. The sum is `(n-1)(n-2) + (n-1) = (n-1)(n-2+1) = (n-1)^2`. The product is `(n-1)(n-2) * (n-1)`. The sum clearly divides the product.

Combining these three links by transitivity, we conclude that `n ~ n-1` for all `n > 3`.

With this result, we can show that any two integers `m, n > 3` are linked. Without loss of generality, assume `m ‚â• n`. We can form a chain from `m` to `n` by stepping down one integer at a time: `m ~ m-1 ~ m-2 ~ ... ~ n`. Since we have shown each step is a valid link, by transitivity, `m ~ n`.

This covers all integers strictly greater than 3. The theorem asks for all integers greater than 2, so we must also handle the number 3. We can link `6` and `3`: `6+3=9` and `6*3=18`. Since 9 divides 18, `6 ~ 3`.

Now we can complete the proof for any `m, n > 2`.
- If `m > 3` and `n > 3`, we have already shown `m ~ n`.
- If `m = 3` and `n > 3`: We know `n ~ 6` (since both are `> 3`) and `6 ~ 3`. By transitivity, `n ~ 3`.
- If `m > 3` and `n = 3`: This follows from the previous case by symmetry.
- If `m = 3` and `n = 3`: This is true by reflexivity.

Since `m, n > 2` implies `m, n ‚â• 3`, these cases cover all possibilities. Thus, any two integers `m, n` greater than 2 can be linked.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- ## Problem B2

Show that we can link any two integers $m, n$ greater than 2 by a chain of positive integers $m=a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots$, $\mathrm{a}_{\mathrm{k}+1}=\mathrm{n}$, so that the product of any two consecutive members of the chain is divisible by their sum. [For example, $7,42,21,28,70,30,6,3$ links 7 and 3.$]$

 -/
theorem number_theory_211514 (m n : ‚Ñï) (hm : 2 < m) (hn : 2 < n) :
    ‚àÉ k : ‚Ñï, ‚àÉ a : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñï,
      a 0 = m ‚àß
      a k = n ‚àß
      (‚àÄ i ‚àà Finset.range (k + 1), 0 < a i) ‚àß
      ‚àÄ i ‚àà Finset.range k, (a i + a (i + 1)) ‚à£ a i * a (i + 1) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

/- ## Problem B2

Show that we can link any two integers $m, n$ greater than 2 by a chain of positive integers $m=a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots$, $\mathrm{a}_{\mathrm{k}+1}=\mathrm{n}$, so that the product of any two consecutive members of the chain is divisible by their sum. [For example, $7,42,21,28,70,30,6,3$ links 7 and 3.$]$

 -/
theorem number_theory_211514 (m n : ‚Ñï) (hm : 2 < m) (hn : 2 < n) :
    ‚àÉ k : ‚Ñï, ‚àÉ a : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñï,
      a 0 = m ‚àß
      a k = n ‚àß
      (‚àÄ i ‚àà Finset.range (k + 1), 0 < a i) ‚àß
      ‚àÄ i ‚àà Finset.range k, (a i + a (i + 1)) ‚à£ a i * a (i + 1) := by

  -- We write $\mathrm{a} \leftrightarrow \mathrm{b}$ if $(\mathrm{a}+\mathrm{b})$ divides $\mathrm{ab}$.
  -- We will show that $\mathrm{a} \leftrightarrow \mathrm{b}$ is an equivalence relation on the positive integers.
  let r (m n : ‚Ñï) : Prop := ‚àÉ k : ‚Ñï, ‚àÉ a : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñï,
      a 0 = m ‚àß
      a k = n ‚àß
      (‚àÄ i ‚àà Finset.range (k + 1), 0 < a i) ‚àß
      ‚àÄ i ‚àà Finset.range k, (a i + a (i + 1)) ‚à£ a i * a (i + 1)
  change r m n

  have hr_trans {a b c : ‚Ñï} (h‚ÇÅ : r a b) (h‚ÇÇ : r b c) : r a c := by
    obtain ‚ü®k‚ÇÅ, f‚ÇÅ, hf‚ÇÅ‚ÇÄ, hf‚ÇÅk, hpos‚ÇÅ, hdvd‚ÇÅ‚ü© := h‚ÇÅ
    obtain ‚ü®k‚ÇÇ, f‚ÇÇ, hf‚ÇÇ‚ÇÄ, hf‚ÇÇk, hpos‚ÇÇ, hdvd‚ÇÇ‚ü© := h‚ÇÇ
    use k‚ÇÅ + k‚ÇÇ
    let f (i : ‚Ñï) :=
      if i ‚â§ k‚ÇÅ then f‚ÇÅ i
      else f‚ÇÇ (i - k‚ÇÅ)
    use f
    split_ands
    ¬∑ simp [f, hf‚ÇÅ‚ÇÄ]
    ¬∑ simp [f, hf‚ÇÇk]
      intro h
      simp [h] at hf‚ÇÇk ‚ä¢
      rw [‚Üêhf‚ÇÇk, hf‚ÇÇ‚ÇÄ, hf‚ÇÅk]
    ¬∑ intro i hi
      simp [f]
      by_cases hi‚ÇÅ : i ‚â§ k‚ÇÅ
      ¬∑ simp [hi‚ÇÅ]
        apply hpos‚ÇÅ
        simp
        exact Order.lt_add_one_iff.mpr hi‚ÇÅ
      ¬∑ simp [hi‚ÇÅ]
        apply hpos‚ÇÇ
        simp at hi ‚ä¢
        apply Nat.sub_lt_left_of_lt_add
        ¬∑ push_neg at hi‚ÇÅ
          apply le_of_lt hi‚ÇÅ
        ¬∑ apply lt_of_lt_of_eq hi
          ring
    ¬∑ intro i hi
      simp [f]
      by_cases hi‚ÇÅ : i ‚â§ k‚ÇÅ
      ¬∑ simp [hi‚ÇÅ]
        by_cases hi‚ÇÇ : i + 1 ‚â§ k‚ÇÅ
        ¬∑ simp [hi‚ÇÇ]
          apply hdvd‚ÇÅ
          simp
          exact hi‚ÇÇ
        ¬∑ simp [hi‚ÇÇ]
          push_neg at hi‚ÇÇ
          have : i = k‚ÇÅ := by
            apply Nat.le_antisymm hi‚ÇÅ
            apply Nat.le_of_lt_succ hi‚ÇÇ
          simp [this, hf‚ÇÅk, ‚Üêhf‚ÇÇ‚ÇÄ]
          simp at hi
          apply hdvd‚ÇÇ
          simp
          have : k‚ÇÅ < k‚ÇÅ + k‚ÇÇ := by
            apply lt_of_le_of_lt ?_ hi
            exact Nat.le_of_lt_succ hi‚ÇÇ
          simp at this
          exact this
      ¬∑ simp [hi‚ÇÅ]
        simp at hi‚ÇÅ
        have : ¬¨ i + 1 ‚â§ k‚ÇÅ := by simp; apply lt_trans hi‚ÇÅ; simp
        simp [this]
        rw [show i + 1 - k‚ÇÅ = i - k‚ÇÅ + 1 by rw [Nat.sub_add_comm (le_of_lt hi‚ÇÅ)]]
        apply hdvd‚ÇÇ
        simp at hi ‚ä¢
        apply Nat.sub_lt_left_of_lt_add
        ¬∑ apply le_of_lt hi‚ÇÅ
        ¬∑ exact hi
  have hr_refl (a : ‚Ñï) (ha : a > 0) : r a a := by
    use 0, fun _ => a
    simp
    exact ha
  have hr_symm {a b : ‚Ñï} (h : r a b) : r b a := by
    obtain ‚ü®k, f, hf‚ÇÄ, hfk, hpos, hdvd‚ü© := h
    use k
    let f' (i : ‚Ñï) := f (k - i)
    use f'
    split_ands
    ¬∑ simp [f', hfk]
    ¬∑ simp [f', hf‚ÇÄ]
    ¬∑ intro i hi
      simp [f']
      apply hpos
      simp at hi ‚ä¢
      exact Nat.sub_lt_succ k i
    ¬∑ intro i hi
      simp [f']
      rw [add_comm, mul_comm]
      have : k - i = k - (i + 1) + 1 := by
        rw [‚ÜêNat.sub_sub, Nat.sub_add_cancel]
        simp at hi
        exact Nat.le_sub_of_add_le' hi
      rw [this]
      apply hdvd
      simp at hi ‚ä¢
      exact Nat.zero_lt_of_lt hi
  -- The starting point is that for $\mathrm{n}>1$ we have $\mathrm{n} \leftrightarrow \mathrm{n}(\mathrm{n}-1)$.
  -- As slight variants we also have $2 n \leftrightarrow n(n-2)$ for $n>2$, and in any case where $a \leftrightarrow b$, then also $m a \leftrightarrow m b$ (for $m>0$ ).
  -- That allows us to link $n>2$ and $2 n$, thus: $n \leftrightarrow n(n-1) \leftrightarrow n(n-1)(n-2)=n(n-2) \leftrightarrow 2 n$.
  have hr_double {n : ‚Ñï} (hn : n > 2) : r (2 * n) n := by
    use 4
    let f (i : ‚Ñï) :=
      match i with
      | 0 => 2 * n
      | 1 => n * (n - 2)
      | 2 => n * (n - 1) * (n - 2)
      | 3 => n * (n - 1)
      | 4 => n
      | _ => 0
    use f
    simp
    have h‚ÇÅ : n > 0 := by linarith only [hn]
    have h‚ÇÇ : n > 1 := by linarith only [hn]
    constructor
    ¬∑ intro i hi
      interval_cases i <;> simp [f, hn, h‚ÇÅ, h‚ÇÇ, hn]
    ¬∑ intro i hi
      interval_cases i <;> simp [f]
      ¬∑ use 2 * (n - 2)
        apply Int.natCast_inj.mp
        simp
        rw [Nat.cast_sub h‚ÇÇ]
        ring
      ¬∑ use (n - 1) * (n - 2)
        apply Int.natCast_inj.mp
        simp
        rw [Nat.cast_sub h‚ÇÅ, Nat.cast_sub h‚ÇÇ]
        ring
      ¬∑ use n * (n - 2)
        apply Int.natCast_inj.mp
        simp
        rw [Nat.cast_sub h‚ÇÅ, Nat.cast_sub h‚ÇÇ]
        ring
      ¬∑ use n - 1
        apply Int.natCast_inj.mp
        simp
        rw [Nat.cast_sub h‚ÇÅ]
        ring
  -- To go much further we need some inspiration. Note that $n(n-3)+2=(n-1)(n-2)$. So $2(n-1)(n-2) \leftrightarrow n(n$ $-3)(n-1)(n-2)$.
  -- That is critical, for it is a general way of allowing us to reduce the largest factor.
  -- Thus for $n$ $>3, n \leftrightarrow n(n-1) \leftrightarrow n(n-1)(n-2) \leftrightarrow n(n-1)(n-2)(n-3) \leftrightarrow 2(n-1)(n-2) \leftrightarrow(n-1)(n-2) \leftrightarrow n-1$.
  have hr_sub_one {n : ‚Ñï} (hn : n > 3) : r n (n - 1) := by
