          rw [‚Üê Nat.prime_iff]
          norm_num
        rcases oz with oz | oz
        . omega
        . simp [oz] at dl
          have l_val: l = 1 := by nlinarith
          have k_val: k = 1 := by
            nlinarith
          simp [k_val] at dk
          simp [l_val] at p
          omega
      -- 11 ‚à£ y --
      . replace d11: 11 ‚à£ k := by
          apply Prime.dvd_or_dvd at d11
          rcases d11 with d11 | d11
          . omega
          . exact d11
          norm_num
        apply exists_eq_mul_right_of_dvd at d11
        obtain ‚ü®l,dl‚ü© := d11
        have l_pos: 1 ‚â§ l := by
          omega
        simp [dl] at h
        replace dl: l * x * z = 7 := by nlinarith
        have l_val: l = 1 := by
          by_contra! ne
          replace ne: 2 ‚â§ l := by omega
          have contra: 8 ‚â§ l * x * z := by
            calc
              8 = 2 * (2 * 2) := by norm_num
              _ ‚â§ l * (2 * 2) := by apply Int.mul_le_mul_of_nonneg_right;omega;omega
              _ = 2 * (l * 2) := by ring
              _ ‚â§ x * (l * 2) := by apply Int.mul_le_mul_of_nonneg_right;omega;omega
              _ = 2 * (x * l) := by ring
              _ ‚â§ z * (x * l) := by apply Int.mul_le_mul_of_nonneg_right;omega;nlinarith
              _ = l * x * z := by ring
          rw [dl] at contra
          tauto
        simp [l_val] at h
        replace dl: x * z = 7 := by nlinarith
        have o: 7 ‚à£ x * z := by omega
        have dd7: 7 ‚à£ x ‚à® 7 ‚à£ z := by
          apply Prime.dvd_or_dvd at o
          exact o
          norm_num
        rcases dd7 with d7 | d7
        -- 7 ‚à£ x --
        . apply exists_eq_mul_right_of_dvd at d7
          obtain ‚ü®m,dm‚ü© := d7
          have m_pos: 1 ‚â§ m := by
            omega
          simp [dm] at h
          replace dm: m * z = 1 := by nlinarith
          absurd dm
          nlinarith
        -- 7 ‚à£ z --
        . apply exists_eq_mul_right_of_dvd at d7
          obtain ‚ü®m,dm‚ü© := d7
          have m_pos: 1 ‚â§ m := by
            omega
          simp [dm] at h
          replace dm: m * x = 1 := by nlinarith
          absurd dm
          nlinarith

      -- 11 ‚à£ z --
      . apply exists_eq_mul_right_of_dvd at d11
        obtain ‚ü®l,dl‚ü© := d11
        have p:= dl
        have l_pos: 1 ‚â§ l := by
          omega
        simp [dl] at h
        replace dl: l * k * x = 7 := by nlinarith
        have o: x ‚à£ 7 := by
          rw[‚Üê dl]
          apply Int.dvd_mul_left
        have oz: x = 1 ‚à® x = 7 := by
          replace o: x.natAbs ‚à£ (7: ‚Ñ§).natAbs := by
            rw [Int.natAbs_dvd_natAbs]
            exact o
          rw [Nat.dvd_prime] at o
          norm_cast at o
          rcases o with o | o
          . rw [Int.natAbs_eq_iff] at o
            omega
          . rw [Int.natAbs_eq_iff] at o
            omega
          rw [Nat.prime_iff]
          norm_cast
          rw [‚Üê Nat.prime_iff]
          norm_num
        rcases oz with oz | oz
        . omega
        . simp [oz] at dl
          have l_val: l = 1 := by nlinarith
          have k_val: k = 1 := by
            nlinarith
          simp [k_val] at dk
          simp [l_val] at p
          omega


    -- we show that ¬¨ 13 ‚à£ z --
    have dz: ¬¨ 13 ‚à£ z := by
      by_contra! dz
      clear d13
      apply exists_eq_mul_right_of_dvd at dz
      rcases dz with ‚ü®k,dk‚ü©
      simp [dk] at h
      have k_pos: 1 ‚â§ k := by
        omega
      rw [dk] at d11
      rcases d11 with d11 | d11 | d11
      -- 11 ‚à£ x --
      . apply exists_eq_mul_right_of_dvd at d11
        obtain ‚ü®l,dl‚ü© := d11
        have p:= dl
        have l_pos: 1 ‚â§ l := by
          omega
        simp [dl] at h
        replace dl: l * k * y = 7 := by nlinarith
        have o: y ‚à£ 7 := by
          rw[‚Üê dl]
          apply Int.dvd_mul_left
        have oz: y = 1 ‚à® y = 7 := by
          replace o: y.natAbs ‚à£ (7: ‚Ñ§).natAbs := by
            rw [Int.natAbs_dvd_natAbs]
            exact o
          rw [Nat.dvd_prime] at o
          norm_cast at o
          rcases o with o | o
          . rw [Int.natAbs_eq_iff] at o
            omega
          . rw [Int.natAbs_eq_iff] at o
            omega
          rw [Nat.prime_iff]
          norm_cast
          rw [‚Üê Nat.prime_iff]
          norm_num
        rcases oz with oz | oz
        . omega
        . simp [oz] at dl
          have l_val: l = 1 := by nlinarith
          have k_val: k = 1 := by
            nlinarith
          simp [k_val] at dk
          simp [l_val] at p
          omega
      -- 11 ‚à£ y --
      . apply exists_eq_mul_right_of_dvd at d11
        obtain ‚ü®l,dl‚ü© := d11
        have p:= dl
        have l_pos: 1 ‚â§ l := by
          omega
        simp [dl] at h
        replace dl: l * k * x = 7 := by nlinarith
        have o: x ‚à£ 7 := by
          rw[‚Üê dl]
          apply Int.dvd_mul_left
        have oz: x = 1 ‚à® x = 7 := by
          replace o: x.natAbs ‚à£ (7: ‚Ñ§).natAbs := by
            rw [Int.natAbs_dvd_natAbs]
            exact o
          rw [Nat.dvd_prime] at o
          norm_cast at o
          rcases o with o | o
          . rw [Int.natAbs_eq_iff] at o
            omega
          . rw [Int.natAbs_eq_iff] at o
            omega
          rw [Nat.prime_iff]
          norm_cast
          rw [‚Üê Nat.prime_iff]
          norm_num
        rcases oz with oz | oz
        . omega
        . simp [oz] at dl
          have l_val: l = 1 := by nlinarith
          have k_val: k = 1 := by
            nlinarith
          simp [k_val] at dk
          simp [l_val] at p
          omega
      -- 11 ‚à£ z --
      . replace d11: 11 ‚à£ k := by
          apply Prime.dvd_or_dvd at d11
          rcases d11 with d11 | d11
          . omega
          . exact d11
          norm_num
        apply exists_eq_mul_right_of_dvd at d11
        obtain ‚ü®l,dl‚ü© := d11
        have l_pos: 1 ‚â§ l := by
          omega
        simp [dl] at h
        replace dl: l * x * y = 7 := by nlinarith
        have l_val: l = 1 := by
          by_contra! ne
          replace ne: 2 ‚â§ l := by omega
          have contra: 8 ‚â§ l * x * y := by
            calc
              8 = 2 * (2 * 2) := by norm_num
              _ ‚â§ l * (2 * 2) := by apply Int.mul_le_mul_of_nonneg_right;omega;omega
              _ = 2 * (l * 2) := by ring
              _ ‚â§ x * (l * 2) := by apply Int.mul_le_mul_of_nonneg_right;omega;omega
              _ = 2 * (x * l) := by ring
              _ ‚â§ y * (x * l) := by apply Int.mul_le_mul_of_nonneg_right;omega;nlinarith
              _ = l * x * y := by ring
          rw [dl] at contra
          tauto
        simp [l_val] at h
        replace dl: x * y = 7 := by nlinarith
        have o: 7 ‚à£ x * y := by omega
        have dd7: 7 ‚à£ x ‚à® 7 ‚à£ y := by
          apply Prime.dvd_or_dvd at o
          exact o
          norm_num
        rcases dd7 with d7 | d7
        -- 7 ‚à£ x --
        . apply exists_eq_mul_right_of_dvd at d7
          obtain ‚ü®m,dm‚ü© := d7
          have m_pos: 1 ‚â§ m := by
            omega
          simp [dm] at h
          replace dm: m * y = 1 := by nlinarith
          absurd dm
          nlinarith
        -- 7 ‚à£ y --
        . apply exists_eq_mul_right_of_dvd at d7
          obtain ‚ü®m,dm‚ü© := d7
          have m_pos: 1 ‚â§ m := by
            omega
          simp [dm] at h
          replace dm: m * x = 1 := by nlinarith
          absurd dm
          nlinarith
    -- Finally, we use d13 to arrive at a contradiction --
    tauto

soln_description:
Solution. The equation makes sense only if $1+\cos x>0$, which means $\cos x>-1$, and this is true for all $x \in \mathbb{R}$ except when $\cos x=-1$.

(1 point)

Similarly, the base of the logarithmic function must be positive and different from 1, so we have $\sqrt{2} \sin x>0$ and $\sqrt{2} \sin x \neq 1$, that is,

$$
\sin x>0 \quad \text { and } \quad \sin x \neq \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}
$$

From the equation itself, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
1+\cos x & =2 \sin ^{2} x \\
1+\cos x & =2\left(1-\cos ^{2} x\right) \\
2 \cos ^{2} x+\cos x-1 & =0
\end{aligned}
$$

thus we obtain $\cos x=\frac{1}{2}$ and $\cos x=-1$.

(1 point)

$\cos x=-1$ is not a solution due to the initial condition, and from $\cos x=\frac{1}{2}$ we get $x=\frac{\pi}{3}+2 k \pi$ or $x=-\frac{\pi}{3}+2 k \pi$. Due to the initial condition, the solution is only $x=\frac{\pi}{3}+2 k \pi$.

(1 point)
informal_statement:
Task B-3.1. Solve the equation

$$
\log _{\sqrt{2} \sin x}(1+\cos x)=2
$$
informal_proof:
We want to find all real numbers `x` that satisfy the equation `log _{\sqrt{2} \sin x}(1+\cos x)=2`.

For the expression to be well-defined, we must satisfy three conditions:
1.  The argument of the logarithm must be positive: `1 + cos x > 0`, which implies `cos x > -1`.
2.  The base of the logarithm must be positive: `‚àö2 sin x > 0`, which implies `sin x > 0`.
3.  The base of the logarithm must not be equal to 1: `‚àö2 sin x ‚â† 1`, which implies `sin x ‚â† 1/‚àö2`.

We will show that, under these conditions, the given equation is equivalent to `x` being of the form `œÄ/3 + 2kœÄ` for some integer `k`.

**Part 1: Deriving the solution from the equation.**

Assume that `x` is a solution to the equation. By the definition of a logarithm, the equation `log _{\sqrt{2} \sin x}(1+\cos x)=2` is equivalent to its exponential form:
`1 + cos x = (‚àö2 sin x)¬≤`

Simplifying the right-hand side, we get:
`1 + cos x = 2 sin¬≤x`

Using the Pythagorean identity `sin¬≤x = 1 - cos¬≤x`, we can write the equation solely in terms of `cos x`:
`1 + cos x = 2(1 - cos¬≤x)`
`1 + cos x = 2 - 2cos¬≤x`

Rearranging the terms yields a quadratic equation in `cos x`:
`2cos¬≤x + cos x - 1 = 0`

We can solve this quadratic equation by factoring:
`(2cos x - 1)(cos x + 1) = 0`

This equation gives two possibilities for `cos x`:
`cos x = 1/2` or `cos x = -1`.

However, from our initial condition `1 + cos x > 0`, we know that `cos x` cannot be `-1`. Thus, we must have:
`cos x = 1/2`

The general solution for `cos x = 1/2` is given by `x = ¬±œÄ/3 + 2kœÄ` for any integer `k`. We now have two families of potential solutions to check against our initial conditions.

-   **Case 1: `x = œÄ/3 + 2kœÄ`**
    For these values of `x`, `sin x = sin(œÄ/3 + 2kœÄ) = sin(œÄ/3) = ‚àö3/2`. Since `‚àö3/2 > 0`, this case is consistent with the condition `sin x > 0`.

-   **Case 2: `x = -œÄ/3 + 2kœÄ`**
    For these values of `x`, `sin x = sin(-œÄ/3 + 2kœÄ) = sin(-œÄ/3) = -‚àö3/2`. This contradicts the condition `sin x > 0`. Therefore, this family of solutions is not valid.

From this, we conclude that if `x` is a solution to the equation, it must be of the form `x = œÄ/3 + 2kœÄ` for some integer `k`.

**Part 2: Verifying the solution.**

Now, we must verify that any `x` of the form `x = œÄ/3 + 2kœÄ` is indeed a solution. Let `x = œÄ/3 + 2kœÄ` for some integer `k`.

First, we evaluate `cos x` and `sin x`:
-   `cos x = cos(œÄ/3 + 2kœÄ) = cos(œÄ/3) = 1/2`
-   `sin x = sin(œÄ/3 + 2kœÄ) = sin(œÄ/3) = ‚àö3/2`

Next, we check if these values satisfy the domain conditions:
1.  `1 + cos x = 1 + 1/2 = 3/2 > 0`. The condition is met.
2.  `‚àö2 sin x = ‚àö2 (‚àö3/2) = ‚àö6/2 > 0`. The condition is met.
3.  `‚àö6/2 ‚â† 1`, since this would imply `‚àö6 = 2` or `6 = 4`, which is false. The condition is met.

Since all conditions are satisfied, we can substitute these values into the left-hand side of the original equation:
`log_{\sqrt{2} \sin x}(1+\cos x) = log_{\sqrt{2}(‚àö3/2)}(1+1/2) = log_{‚àö6/2}(3/2)`

To show that this expression equals 2, we must check if the base raised to the power of 2 equals the argument:
`(‚àö6/2)¬≤ = 6/4 = 3/2`

This is precisely the argument of the logarithm. Therefore, the equation holds true for all `x` of the form `x = œÄ/3 + 2kœÄ`.

**Conclusion**

We have shown that any solution must be of the form `x = œÄ/3 + 2kœÄ` and that any such `x` is a valid solution. Thus, the solution set is `{x ‚àà ‚Ñù | x = œÄ/3 + 2kœÄ, k ‚àà ‚Ñ§}`.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
/--
Problem statement (Main theorem of this file):
Task B-3.1. Solve the equation

$$
\log _{\sqrt{2} \sin x}(1+\cos x)=2
$$

Solution:
Rje≈°enje. Jednad≈æba ima smisla jedino ako je $1+\cos x > 0$, odnosno ako je $\cos x > -1$, a to znaƒçi za sve $x \in \mathbb{R}$ osim kada je $\cos x=-1$.

(1 bod)

Isto tako baza logaritamske funkcije mora biti pozitivna i razliƒçita od 1 pa vrijedi $\sqrt{2} \sin x > 0$ i $\sqrt{2} \sin x \neq 1$, odnosno

$$ \sin x > 0 \quad \text { i } \quad \sin x \neq \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} $$

Iz same jednad≈æbe slijedi

$$ \begin{aligned} 1+\cos x & =2 \sin ^{2} x \\ 1+\cos x & =2\left(1-\cos ^{2} x\right) \\ 2 \cos ^{2} x+\cos x-1 & =0 \end{aligned} $$

te dobivamo $\cos x=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{i} \cos x=-1$.

(1 bod)

$\cos x=-1$ nije rje≈°enje zbog poƒçetnog uvjeta, a iz $\cos x=\frac{1}{2}$ dobivamo $x=\frac{\pi}{3}+2 k \pi$ ili $x=-\frac{\pi}{3}+2 k \pi$. Zbog poƒçetnog uvjeta rje≈°enje je samo $x=\frac{\pi}{3}+2 k \pi$.

(1 bod)

-/

lemma cos_eq_one_div_two (x : ‚Ñù) (h : cos x = 1 / 2) :
    ‚àÉ k : ‚Ñ§, x = œÄ / 3 + 2 * k * œÄ ‚à® x = -œÄ / 3 + 2 * k * œÄ := by
    rw [‚Üê cos_pi_div_three, cos_eq_cos_iff] at h
    rcases h with ‚ü®k, h‚ü©
    cases' h with h1 h2
    . use -k
      left
      rw [h1]
      ring_nf
      simp
      ring_nf
    . use k
      right
      rw [(by ring: -œÄ / 3 = -(œÄ / 3))]
      rw [h2]
      ring_nf

theorem algebra_214233 (x : ‚Ñù):
    (1 + cos x) > 0 ‚Üí (sqrt 2 * sin x) > 0 ‚Üí (sqrt 2 * sin x) ‚â† 1 ‚Üí (logb (sqrt 2 * sin x) (1 + cos x) = 2 ‚Üî (‚àÉ k : ‚Ñ§, x = œÄ / 3 + 2 * k * œÄ )) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
/--
Problem statement (Main theorem of this file):
Task B-3.1. Solve the equation

$$
\log _{\sqrt{2} \sin x}(1+\cos x)=2
$$

Solution:
Rje≈°enje. Jednad≈æba ima smisla jedino ako je $1+\cos x > 0$, odnosno ako je $\cos x > -1$, a to znaƒçi za sve $x \in \mathbb{R}$ osim kada je $\cos x=-1$.

(1 bod)

Isto tako baza logaritamske funkcije mora biti pozitivna i razliƒçita od 1 pa vrijedi $\sqrt{2} \sin x > 0$ i $\sqrt{2} \sin x \neq 1$, odnosno

$$ \sin x > 0 \quad \text { i } \quad \sin x \neq \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} $$

Iz same jednad≈æbe slijedi

$$ \begin{aligned} 1+\cos x & =2 \sin ^{2} x \\ 1+\cos x & =2\left(1-\cos ^{2} x\right) \\ 2 \cos ^{2} x+\cos x-1 & =0 \end{aligned} $$

te dobivamo $\cos x=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{i} \cos x=-1$.

(1 bod)

$\cos x=-1$ nije rje≈°enje zbog poƒçetnog uvjeta, a iz $\cos x=\frac{1}{2}$ dobivamo $x=\frac{\pi}{3}+2 k \pi$ ili $x=-\frac{\pi}{3}+2 k \pi$. Zbog poƒçetnog uvjeta rje≈°enje je samo $x=\frac{\pi}{3}+2 k \pi$.

(1 bod)

-/

lemma cos_eq_one_div_two (x : ‚Ñù) (h : cos x = 1 / 2) :
    ‚àÉ k : ‚Ñ§, x = œÄ / 3 + 2 * k * œÄ ‚à® x = -œÄ / 3 + 2 * k * œÄ := by
    rw [‚Üê cos_pi_div_three, cos_eq_cos_iff] at h
    rcases h with ‚ü®k, h‚ü©
    cases' h with h1 h2
    . use -k
      left
      rw [h1]
      ring_nf
      simp
      ring_nf
    . use k
      right
      rw [(by ring: -œÄ / 3 = -(œÄ / 3))]
      rw [h2]
      ring_nf

theorem algebra_214233 (x : ‚Ñù):
    (1 + cos x) > 0 ‚Üí (sqrt 2 * sin x) > 0 ‚Üí (sqrt 2 * sin x) ‚â† 1 ‚Üí (logb (sqrt 2 * sin x) (1 + cos x) = 2 ‚Üî (‚àÉ k : ‚Ñ§, x = œÄ / 3 + 2 * k * œÄ )) := by
    intro h_pos h_base_pos h_base_neq_1
    constructor
    . intro h_log
      rw [logb_eq_iff_rpow_eq h_base_pos h_base_neq_1 h_pos] at h_log
      norm_cast at h_log
      ring_nf at h_log
      field_simp at h_log
      rw [sin_sq] at h_log
      have : cos x = 1 / 2:= by
        rw [(by ring : (1 - cos x ^ 2) = (1 - cos x) * (1 + cos x)), ‚Üê mul_assoc] at h_log
        have : 1 + cos x ‚â† 0 := by positivity
        field_simp at h_log
        linarith

      apply cos_eq_one_div_two x at this
      rcases this with ‚ü®k, hx‚ü©
      cases' hx with hx1 hx2
      . use k
      . have h_sin : sin x = - ‚àö3 / 2 := by
          rw [hx2]
          rw [(by ring : 2 * k * œÄ = k * (2 * œÄ))]
          rw [sin_add_int_mul_two_pi (-œÄ / 3) k]
          rw [(by ring : -œÄ / 3 = -(œÄ / 3))]
          rw [sin_neg, sin_pi_div_three]
          ring_nf

        have : sqrt 2 > 0 := by positivity
        have : sin x > 0 := by
          apply (mul_pos_iff_of_pos_left this).mp
          exact h_base_pos
        have : sin x < 0 := by rw [h_sin]; ring_nf; norm_num
        linarith

    . intro h_exists
      rcases h_exists with ‚ü®k, hx‚ü©
      rw [(by ring : 2 * k * œÄ = k * (2 * œÄ))] at hx
      rw [hx]
      rw [sin_add_int_mul_two_pi (œÄ / 3) k]
      rw [cos_add_int_mul_two_pi (œÄ / 3) k]
      rw [sin_pi_div_three]
      rw [cos_pi_div_three]
      rw [logb_eq_iff_rpow_eq (by positivity) (by aesop) (by positivity)]
      simp
      ring_nf
      norm_num

informal_statement: Positive integers $a, b$, and $c$ are all powers of $k$ for some positive integer $k$. It is known that the equation $a x^{2}-b x+c=0$ has exactly one real solution $r$, and this value $r$ is less than 100 . Compute the maximum possible value of $r$.
informal_proof:
Let the given quadratic equation be `ax¬≤ - bx + c = 0`. We are given that this equation has exactly one real solution, which we denote by `r`.

For a quadratic equation of the form `Ax¬≤ + Bx + C = 0` to have a unique real solution, its discriminant must be zero, provided that `A ‚â† 0`. In our case, the coefficients are `A = a`, `B = -b`, and `C = c`. The coefficient `a` is given by `a = k^x`, where `k` is a positive integer (`k ‚â• 1`) and `x` is a natural number. This ensures that `a` is a positive integer, so `a ‚â† 0`.

The discriminant is `B¬≤ - 4AC = (-b)¬≤ - 4ac = b¬≤ - 4ac`. The condition for a unique solution implies that `b¬≤ - 4ac = 0`.

We are given that `a = k^x`, `b = k^y`, and `c = k^z` for some positive integer `k` and natural numbers `x, y, z`. Substituting these into the discriminant equation gives:
`(k^y)¬≤ - 4(k^x)(k^z) = 0`
`k^(2y) - 4k^(x+z) = 0`
`k^(2y) = 4k^(x+z)`

Since `a, b, c` are positive, `k^x`, `k^y`, `k^z` are all non-zero, so we can divide by `k^(x+z)`:
`k^(2y) / k^(x+z) = 4`
`k^(2y - x - z) = 4`

Since `k` is a positive integer, there are only two possibilities for `k` that satisfy this equation:
1.  `k = 2`, which implies the exponent `2y - x - z` must be `2`.
2.  `k = 4`, which implies the exponent `2y - x - z` must be `1`.

Now, let's determine the value of the unique solution `r`. For a quadratic equation `Ax¬≤ + Bx + C = 0` with a zero discriminant, the unique root is given by `x = -B / (2A)`. For our equation, this is:
`r = -(-b) / (2a) = b / (2a)`

Let's analyze `r` in both possible cases for `k`:
*   If `k=2`, then `a = 2^x` and `b = 2^y`. The solution `r` is:
    `r = 2^y / (2 * 2^x) = 2^y / 2^(x+1) = 2^(y - x - 1)`
*   If `k=4`, then `a = 4^x` and `b = 4^y`. The solution `r` is:
    `r = 4^y / (2 * 4^x) = (2^2)^y / (2 * (2^2)^x) = 2^(2y) / (2 * 2^(2x)) = 2^(2y) / 2^(2x+1) = 2^(2y - 2x - 1)`

In both scenarios, the solution `r` is a power of 2. Since `r = b/(2a)` and `a, b` are positive, `r` must be a positive real number. Thus, `r` must be of the form `2^p` for some integer `p`.

We are given the additional constraint that `r ‚â§ 100`. Combining this with our finding that `r` is a power of 2, we have:
`2^p ‚â§ 100`

We seek the largest possible value of `r`, which corresponds to finding the largest integer `p` that satisfies this inequality. Let's examine the powers of 2:
`2^5 = 32`
`2^6 = 64`
`2^7 = 128`
The largest power of 2 that is less than or equal to 100 is `64`. Therefore, the maximum possible value for `r` is 64. This implies that `r ‚â§ 64`.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib 

/-- Positive integers $a, b$, and $c$ are all powers of $k$ for some positive integer $k$. It is known that the equation $a x^{2}-b x+c=0$ has exactly one real solution $r$, and this value $r$ is less than 100 . Compute the maximum possible value of $r$.-/
theorem Algebra_610402 {a b c : ‚Ñ§} {x y z : ‚Ñï} {k : ‚Ñï} (hk : k > 0) (ha : a = k ^ x ) (hb : b = k ^ y) (hc : c = k ^ z)  
  (h_eq : ‚àÉ! (r : ‚Ñù), (a * (r * r) + (-b) * r + c = 0) ‚àß (r ‚â§ 100)) : 
  let r := Classical.choose h_eq; r ‚â§ 64 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib 

/-- Positive integers $a, b$, and $c$ are all powers of $k$ for some positive integer $k$. It is known that the equation $a x^{2}-b x+c=0$ has exactly one real solution $r$, and this value $r$ is less than 100 . Compute the maximum possible value of $r$.-/
theorem Algebra_610402 {a b c : ‚Ñ§} {x y z : ‚Ñï} {k : ‚Ñï} (hk : k > 0) (ha : a = k ^ x ) (hb : b = k ^ y) (hc : c = k ^ z)  
  (h_eq : ‚àÉ! (r : ‚Ñù), (a * (r * r) + (-b) * r + c = 0) ‚àß (r ‚â§ 100)) : 
  let r := Classical.choose h_eq; r ‚â§ 64 := by 
  -- since the quadratic equation has uniuqe root, then the discriminat of the polynomial is zero, i.e. `b^2-4ac` should be zero.
  have discrim_eq_zero_of_existsUnique {a b c : ‚Ñù} (ha : a ‚â† 0) (h : ‚àÉ! x, a * (x * x) + b * x + c = 0) :
        discrim a b c = 0 := by
        simp_rw [quadratic_eq_zero_iff_discrim_eq_sq ha] at h
        generalize discrim a b c = d at h
        obtain ‚ü®x, rfl, hx‚ü© := h
        specialize hx (-(x + b / a))
        field_simp [ha] at hx
        specialize hx (by ring)
        linear_combination -(2 * a * x + b) * hx
  -- discriminant eq_zero iff there exist unique root
  have discrim_eq_zero_iff {a b c : ‚Ñù} (ha : a ‚â† 0) :
    discrim a b c = 0 ‚Üî (‚àÉ! x, a * (x * x) + b * x + c = 0) := by
      refine ‚ü®fun hd => ?_, discrim_eq_zero_of_existsUnique ha‚ü©
      simp_rw [quadratic_eq_zero_iff_of_discrim_eq_zero ha hd, existsUnique_eq]
  have aneq : a ‚â† 0 := by 
    rw [ha]
    apply pow_ne_zero
    nlinarith
  have aneq' : (a : ‚Ñù) ‚â† 0 := by norm_cast
  have discrim_eq_zero : b ^ 2 - 4 * a * c = 0 := by 
    obtain ‚ü®r, hr, h1‚ü© := h_eq
    have aux : ‚àÉ! (r : ‚Ñù), (a * (r * r) + (-b) * r + c = 0) := by 
      use r
      constructor
      nlinarith
      intro y hy
      simp at h1
      sorry
    have ht1 : discrim (a : ‚Ñù) (-b) c = 0 := (discrim_eq_zero_iff aneq').mpr aux
    unfold discrim at ht1
    ring_nf at ht1
    norm_cast at ht1
    nlinarith
  rw [ha,hb,hc] at discrim_eq_zero
  have eq : (k : ‚Ñ§) ^ (2 * y) = 2 ^ 2 * k ^ (x + z) := by 
    calc 
      _ = ((k : ‚Ñ§) ^ y) ^ 2 := by 
        rw [mul_comm, ‚Üêpow_mul]
      _ = ((k : ‚Ñ§) ^ y) ^ 2 - 4 * (k : ‚Ñ§)^ x * (k : ‚Ñ§) ^ z + 4 * (k : ‚Ñ§) ^ x * (k : ‚Ñ§) ^ z := by 
        ring_nf
      _ = 4 * ((k : ‚Ñ§) ^ x * (k : ‚Ñ§) ^ z) := by 
        rw [discrim_eq_zero]
        simp
        ring
      _ = (2) ^ 2 * (k : ‚Ñ§) ^ (x + z) := by
        simp
        rw [‚Üêpow_add]
  have k_eq : k = (2) := by sorry -- since `2 ‚à£ k`, and only `2 ‚à£ k`
  rw [k_eq] at ha
  rw [k_eq] at hb
  rw [k_eq] at hc
  have k_eq' : k = (2 : ‚Ñù) := by norm_cast
  obtain hx := Classical.choose_spec h_eq
  let r := Classical.choose h_eq
  -- basic property of quadratic equation
  have quadratic_eq : r = b / (2 * a) := by 
    obtain heq' := Classical.choose_spec h_eq
    obtain ‚ü®h1, h2‚ü© := heq'
    obtain ‚ü®hreq, rle‚ü© := h1
    have aneq : (a : ‚Ñù) ‚â† 0 := by 
      rw [ha]
      norm_num
    have dis_eq : discrim a (-b) c = 0 := by 
      unfold discrim
      rw [ha, hb, hc]
      simp
      rw [k_eq] at discrim_eq_zero
      simpa
    have dis_eq' : discrim (a : ‚Ñù) (-b) c = 0 := by 
      unfold discrim
      unfold discrim at dis_eq
      simp
      simp at dis_eq
      norm_cast
    obtain h' := (quadratic_eq_zero_iff_of_discrim_eq_zero aneq dis_eq' (Classical.choose h_eq)).mp hreq
    unfold r
    simpa using h'
  rw [ha, hb] at quadratic_eq
  unfold r at quadratic_eq
  have eq_aux : (((2 : ‚Ñ§) ^ y) : ‚Ñù) / (2 * ‚Üë((2 : ‚Ñ§) ^ x)) = (2 : ‚Ñ§) ^ (y - x - 1) := by 
    calc 
      _ = (((2 : ‚Ñ§) ^ y) : ‚Ñù) / ((2 : ‚Ñ§) ^ (x + 1)) := by 
        simp
        field_simp
        ring
      _ = (2 : ‚Ñ§) ^ (y - x - 1) := by
        simp
        field_simp
        ring_nf
        have yge : y - x - 1 + x = y -1:= by 
          
          sorry
        rw [‚Üêpow_add]
        rw [yge]
        have yeq : y - 1 + 1 = y := by 
          have : y ‚â• 1 := by sorry
          omega
        conv =>
          lhs
          rw [‚Üê yeq]
        ring
  -- the maximal pow of two less than 100 is 64, then the maximal possible r is 64
  have req : r = 2 ^ (y - x - 1) := by sorry
  obtain heq' := Classical.choose_spec h_eq
  obtain ‚ü®h1, h2‚ü© := heq'
  obtain ‚ü®h1, rle‚ü© := h1
  have ineq : r ‚â§ 64 := by 
    rw [req]
    unfold r at req
    rw [req] at rle
    have ineq_aux : y - x - 1 ‚â§ (6) := by sorry
    have eq' : (64 : ‚Ñù) = 2 ^ 6 := by norm_num
    rw [eq']
    sorry

  exact ineq

soln_description:
## Solution

Answer: $\mathrm{a}>\mathrm{b}$.

Note that $\mathrm{a}^{\mathrm{n}}=\mathrm{a}+1>1$ (since $\mathrm{a}$ is positive). Hence $\mathrm{a}>1$. So $\mathrm{a}^{2 \mathrm{n}}=(\mathrm{a}+1)^{2}=\mathrm{a}^{2}+2 \mathrm{a}+1$. Put $\mathrm{a}=1+k$, then $a^{2}=1+2 k+k^{2}>1+2 k$, so $a^{2}+1>2+2 k=2 a$. Hence $a^{2 n}>4 a$. So $(b / a)^{2 n}=(b+3 a) / a^{2 n}<(b+3 a) / 4 a$. If $\mathrm{b} / \mathrm{a} \geq 1$, then $(\mathrm{b}+3 \mathrm{a}) / 4 \mathrm{a} \leq(\mathrm{b}+3 \mathrm{~b}) / 4 \mathrm{a}=\mathrm{b} / \mathrm{a}$, so $(\mathrm{b} / \mathrm{a})^{2 \mathrm{n}}<\mathrm{b} / \mathrm{a}$. Contradiction. Hence $\mathrm{b} / \mathrm{a}<1$.
informal_statement:
## Problem 1

$\mathrm{n}>1$, and $\mathrm{a}$ and $\mathrm{b}$ are positive real numbers such that $\mathrm{a}^{\mathrm{n}}-\mathrm{a}-1=0$ and $\mathrm{b}^{2 \mathrm{n}}-\mathrm{b}-3 \mathrm{a}=0$. Which is larger?
informal_proof:
We are given that $n > 1$ is a natural number and $a, b$ are positive real numbers satisfying $a^n - a - 1 = 0$ and $b^{2n} - b - 3a = 0$. We want to determine which of $a$ or $b$ is larger. We will show that $a > b$.

The proof proceeds by contradiction. Let us assume for the sake of contradiction that $a \le b$.

First, we analyze the properties of $a$. From the equation $a^n - a - 1 = 0$, we can write $a^n = a + 1$. Since we are given that $a > 0$, it follows that $a + 1 > 1$, and thus $a^n > 1$.
This implies that $a > 1$. To see why, suppose $0 < a \le 1$. Since $n > 1$, we would have $a^n \le 1^n = 1$, which contradicts $a^n > 1$. Therefore, it must be that $a > 1$.

Next, we establish a lower bound for $a^{2n}$. Using the relation $a^n = a + 1$, we can write:
$$a^{2n} = (a^n)^2 = (a+1)^2 = a^2 + 2a + 1$$
Since $a > 1$, we have $a - 1 > 0$, which implies $(a-1)^2 > 0$. Expanding this inequality gives $a^2 - 2a + 1 > 0$, which can be rearranged to $a^2 + 1 > 2a$.
Now, substituting this into our expression for $a^{2n}$:
$$a^{2n} = (a^2 + 1) + 2a > 2a + 2a = 4a$$
Thus, we have the strict inequality $a^{2n} > 4a$.

From the second given equation, $b^{2n} - b - 3a = 0$, we have $b^{2n} = b + 3a$.

Now, let's consider the ratio $(b/a)^{2n}$. Using the expressions we've found and the fact that $a$ and $b$ are positive:
$$ \left(\frac{b}{a}\right)^{2n} = \frac{b^{2n}}{a^{2n}} = \frac{b+3a}{a^{2n}} $$
Using our lower bound for $a^{2n}$, we get:
$$ \left(\frac{b}{a}\right)^{2n} < \frac{b+3a}{4a} $$
Now we use our contradictory assumption, $a \le b$. This implies $3a \le 3b$. Therefore:
$$ \frac{b+3a}{4a} \le \frac{b+3b}{4a} = \frac{4b}{4a} = \frac{b}{a} $$
Combining these last two inequalities, we arrive at our first key result:
$$ \left(\frac{b}{a}\right)^{2n} < \frac{b}{a} $$
However, let's re-examine our assumption $a \le b$. Since $a > 0$, we can divide by $a$ to get $1 \le b/a$. We are given $n > 1$, which means the exponent $2n \ge 4 > 1$. For any real number $x \ge 1$ and any exponent $p > 1$, it is true that $x^p \ge x$. Applying this with $x = b/a$ and $p = 2n$, we get:
$$ \left(\frac{b}{a}\right)^{2n} \ge \frac{b}{a} $$
We have now derived two contradictory statements: that $(b/a)^{2n}$ is strictly less than $b/a$, and also that it is greater than or equal to $b/a$. This is a contradiction.

Therefore, our initial assumption that $a \le b$ must be false. We conclude that $a > b$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- ## Problem 1

$\mathrm{n}>1$, and $\mathrm{a}$ and $\mathrm{b}$ are positive real numbers such that $\mathrm{a}^{\mathrm{n}}-\mathrm{a}-1=0$ and $\mathrm{b}^{2 \mathrm{n}}-\mathrm{b}-3 \mathrm{a}=0$. Which is larger?

 -/
theorem algebra_210640 (n : ‚Ñï) (a b : ‚Ñù) (h‚ÇÄ : n > 1) (h‚ÇÅ : 0 < a) (h‚ÇÇ : 0 < b)
    (h‚ÇÉ : a ^ n - a - 1 = 0) (h‚ÇÑ : b ^ (2 * n) - b - 3 * a = 0) :
    a > b := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

/- ## Problem 1

$\mathrm{n}>1$, and $\mathrm{a}$ and $\mathrm{b}$ are positive real numbers such that $\mathrm{a}^{\mathrm{n}}-\mathrm{a}-1=0$ and $\mathrm{b}^{2 \mathrm{n}}-\mathrm{b}-3 \mathrm{a}=0$. Which is larger?

 -/
theorem algebra_210640 (n : ‚Ñï) (a b : ‚Ñù) (h‚ÇÄ : n > 1) (h‚ÇÅ : 0 < a) (h‚ÇÇ : 0 < b)
    (h‚ÇÉ : a ^ n - a - 1 = 0) (h‚ÇÑ : b ^ (2 * n) - b - 3 * a = 0) :
    a > b := by
    --assume by contradiction that b > a
    by_contra h
    push_neg at h
    --one has that a ^ 2n = (a ^ n) ^ 2 = (a + 1) ^ 2 = a ^ 2 + 2a * 1
    have a_pow_two_n : a ^ (2 * n) = a ^ 2 + 2 * a + 1 := by
      rw[(by ring_nf : (1 : ‚Ñù) = 1 ^ 2)]
      nth_rw 3 [(by ring_nf : a = a * 1)]
      rw[‚Üê mul_assoc, ‚Üê add_sq a 1, mul_comm, pow_mul]
      suffices a ^ n = a + 1 by
        rw[sq_eq_sq (by linarith) (by linarith)]
        exact this
      linarith
    --moreover a ^ 2n is bounded by 4a because a^2 + 1 is bounded by 2a
    have bound_a : a ^ (2 * n) > 4 * a := by 
      suffices a ^ 2 + 1 > 2 * a by
        rw[a_pow_two_n, add_assoc, add_comm (2 * a), ‚Üê add_assoc]
        rw[(by linarith : 4 * a = 2 * a + 2 * a)]
        linarith
      have a_gt_one : a > 1 := by 
        by_contra kk 
        push_neg at kk
        have : a ^ n > 1 := by
          calc a ^ n
          _ = a + 1 := by linarith
          _ > 1 := by linarith
        by_contra hk
        push_neg at hk
        have contr : a ^ n ‚â§ 1 := by
          exact pow_le_one‚ÇÄ (le_of_lt h‚ÇÅ) kk
        linarith
      --to do so one writes a = 1 + (a + 1) and developes the square of the sum in a ^ 2 + 1, finding the bound
      calc a ^ 2 + 1 
        = 1 + 2 * (a - 1) + (a - 1) ^ 2 + 1 := by nth_rw 1 [(by ring_nf : a = 1 + (a - 1))]; rw[add_sq]; ring_nf
        _ > 2 + 2 * (a - 1) := by
          suffices (a - 1) ^ 2 > 0 by
            linarith
          exact sq_pos_of_pos (by linarith)
        _ = 2 * a := by linarith
    --b ^ 2n = b + 3a by hypotheses
    have b_pow_n : b ^ (2 * n) = b + 3 * a := by linarith
    --then the ratio of b^2n over a ^ 2n is less than the ratio of the two bounds.
    have div_b_a : (b / a) ^ (2 * n) < (b + 3 * a) / (4 * a) := by
      rw[div_pow]
      refine div_lt_div' (by linarith) (by linarith) (by linarith) (by linarith)
    --this leads to (b/a)^2n < b/a via a chain of estimates
    have hyp1 : (b / a) ^ (2 * n) < (b / a) := by
      suffices (b + 3 * a) / (4 * a) ‚â§ (b / a) by
        linarith
      calc (b + 3 * a) / (4 * a)
      _ ‚â§ (b + 3 * b) / (4 * a) := by 
        have : b + 3 * a ‚â§ b + 3 * b := by linarith
        exact (div_le_div_right (by linarith)).mpr this
      _ = b / a := by ring_nf
    --however this is contradiction, because by assumption we had b/a ‚â• 1 leading to b/a^2n ‚â• b/a
    have hyp2 : (b / a) ^ (2 * n) ‚â• (b / a) := by 
      nth_rw 2 [‚Üê pow_one (b / a)]
      exact pow_le_pow_right (by rw[‚Üê one_le_div h‚ÇÅ] at h; exact h) (by linarith)
    linarith

soln_description:
[Proof] If $(a, b, c)=d \neq 1$, then we can instead discuss $\frac{a}{d}, \frac{b}{d}, \frac{c}{d}$. Therefore, without loss of generality, assume $(a, b, c)=1$.

If the conclusion is not true, then at least one of $|a|,|b|,|c|$ is not equal to 1. Without loss of generality, assume $|a| \neq 1$.
Let $P$ be a prime factor of $a$. Then
$$
a b c\left(\frac{a}{b}+\frac{b}{c}+\frac{c}{a}\right)=a^{2} c+b^{2} a+c^{2} b
$$

is divisible by $p$. Therefore, $c^{2} b$ is divisible by $p$, so $c$ or $b$ is divisible by $p$. Without loss of generality, assume $b$ is divisible by $p$. Thus, $c$ cannot be divisible by $p$.

Let $p^{\prime}$ be the highest power of $p$ that divides $a$, and $p^{s}$ be the highest power of $p$ that divides $b$. Without loss of generality, assume $r \leqslant s$. Then
$$
a b c\left(\frac{a}{c}+\frac{c}{b}+\frac{b}{a}\right)=a^{2} b+c^{2} a+b^{2} c
$$

is divisible by $p^{r+s}$. Note that $a^{2} b$ and $b^{2} c$ are both divisible by $p^{r+s}$, so $c^{2} a$ is also divisible by $p^{r+s}$, which implies that $a$ is divisible by $p^{r+s}$, a contradiction.
Therefore, the conclusion holds, and $|a|=|b|=|c|=1$.
informal_statement:
$3 \cdot 89$ integers $a, b, c$ such that
$$
\frac{a}{b}+\frac{b}{c}+\frac{c}{a} \text { and } \frac{a}{c}+\frac{c}{b}+\frac{b}{a}
$$

are both integers, prove: $|a|=|b|=|c|$.
informal_proof:
Let `a, b, c` be non-zero integers such that the expressions `S_1 = a/b + b/c + c/a` and `S_2 = a/c + c/b + b/a` are both integers. We want to prove that `|a| = |b| = |c|`.

First, we make some simplifications without loss of generality.
1.  We can assume that the greatest common divisor (GCD) of `|a|`, `|b|`, and `|c|` is 1. Let `d = gcd(|a|, |b|, |c|)`. If `d > 1`, we can consider the integers `a' = a/d`, `b' = b/d`, and `c' = c/d`. These are non-zero integers, their GCD is 1, and the expressions `a'/b' + b'/c' + c'/a'` and `a'/c' + c'/b' + b'/a'` are equal to `S_1` and `S_2` respectively, so they are also integers. If we can prove `|a'|=|b'|=|c'|`, then it follows that `|a|/d = |b|/d = |c|/d`, which implies `|a|=|b|=|c|`. So, we assume `gcd(|a|, |b|, |c|) = 1`.

2.  We can assume `0 < |c| ‚â§ |b| ‚â§ |a|`. The hypotheses are symmetric. If we swap `b` and `c`, the expression `S_1` becomes `S_2` and `S_2` becomes `S_1`. Thus, the conditions on `(a, c, b)` are the same as on `(a, b, c)`. Similar symmetries exist for other permutations. We can therefore arrange `a, b, c` such that their absolute values are in non-decreasing order.

We proceed by contradiction. Assume that the conclusion is false, i.e., it is not the case that `|a|=|b|=|c|`. Given our assumption `|c| ‚â§ |b| ‚â§ |a|`, this means that `|a| > |c|`. This also implies `|a| > 1`, because if `|a|=1`, then `|c| ‚â§ |b| ‚â§ 1`, which for non-zero integers forces `|a|=|b|=|c|=1`, contradicting our assumption.

Since `|a| > 1`, there must exist a prime number `p` that divides `|a|`.

Let `k` and `l` be the integer values of `S_1` and `S_2`. By clearing the denominators, we obtain two polynomial equations:
1.  `a¬≤c + ab¬≤ + bc¬≤ = k(abc)`
2.  `a¬≤b + ac¬≤ + b¬≤c = l(abc)`

From equation (1), since `p` divides `a`, `p` divides the right-hand side `k(abc)`. Therefore, `p` must divide the left-hand side `a¬≤c + ab¬≤ + bc¬≤`. As `p` divides `a`, `p` also divides the terms `a¬≤c` and `ab¬≤`. Consequently, `p` must divide the remaining term, `bc¬≤`. Since `p` is prime, this implies that `p` divides `b` or `p` divides `c`.

Note that `p` cannot divide both `|b|` and `|c|`. If it did, then `p` would be a common divisor of `|a|`, `|b|`, and `|c|`, which would mean `gcd(|a|, |b|, |c|) ‚â• p > 1`. This contradicts our assumption that the GCD is 1.

We now analyze the two possible cases. Let `v_p(n)` denote the p-adic valuation of an integer `n`, i.e., the exponent of the highest power of `p` that divides `n`.

**Case 1: `p` divides `|b|` (and thus `p` does not divide `|c|`)**
Let `v_p(a) = r` and `v_p(b) = s`. By assumption, `r ‚â• 1` and `s ‚â• 1`. Since `p` does not divide `c`, we have `v_p(c) = 0`.
We consider two subcases based on the relationship between `r` and `s`.

*   **Subcase 1a: `r ‚â§ s`**
    We analyze equation (2): `a¬≤b + ac¬≤ + b¬≤c = l(abc)`.
    Let's find the p-adic valuation of each term:
    - `v_p(a¬≤b) = 2v_p(a) + v_p(b) = 2r + s`
    - `v_p(ac¬≤) = v_p(a) + 2v_p(c) = r + 0 = r`
    - `v_p(b¬≤c) = 2v_p(b) + v_p(c) = 2s + 0 = 2s`
    Since `r ‚â• 1` and `s ‚â• 1`, we have `r < 2r+s`. Since `r ‚â§ s`, we have `r < 2s` (as `r=s=1` gives `1<2`, and if `s>r`, `r<s<2s`). Thus, `r` is strictly the minimum of the three valuations. The valuation of a sum with a unique minimum valuation is that minimum. So, `v_p(a¬≤b + ac¬≤ + b¬≤c) = r`.
    The valuation of the right-hand side is `v_p(l(abc)) = v_p(a) + v_p(b) + v_p(c) + v_p(l) = r + s + 0 + v_p(l) ‚â• r + s`.
    Equating the valuations gives `r ‚â• r+s`, which implies `s ‚â§ 0`. This contradicts our finding that `s ‚â• 1`.

*   **Subcase 1b: `s < r`**
    We analyze equation (1): `a¬≤c + ab¬≤ + bc¬≤ = k(abc)`.
    The p-adic valuation of each term is:
    - `v_p(a¬≤c) = 2r`
    - `v_p(ab¬≤) = r + 2s`
    - `v_p(bc¬≤) = s`
    Since `s < r`, `s` is strictly smaller than `2r` and `r+2s`. Thus, `v_p(a¬≤c + ab¬≤ + bc¬≤) = s`.
    The valuation of the right-hand side is `v_p(k(abc)) ‚â• r+s`.
    Equating them gives `s ‚â• r+s`, which implies `r ‚â§ 0`. This contradicts `r ‚â• 1`.

Both subcases in Case 1 lead to a contradiction.

**Case 2: `p` divides `|c|` (and thus `p` does not divide `|b|`)**
This case is symmetric to Case 1. Let `v_p(a) = r ‚â• 1`, `v_p(c) = t ‚â• 1`, and `v_p(b) = 0`.

*   **Subcase 2a: `r ‚â§ t`**
    We analyze equation (1): `a¬≤c + ab¬≤ + bc¬≤ = k(abc)`.
    - `v_p(a¬≤c) = 2r + t`
    - `v_p(ab¬≤) = r`
    - `v_p(bc¬≤) = 2t`
    Since `r ‚â§ t`, `r` is the unique minimum valuation. Thus, `v_p(LHS) = r`.
    The valuation of the RHS is `v_p(k(abc)) ‚â• r+t`.
    This leads to `r ‚â• r+t`, which means `t ‚â§ 0`, a contradiction.

*   **Subcase 2b: `t < r`**
    We analyze equation (2): `a¬≤b + ac¬≤ + b¬≤c = l(abc)`.
    - `v_p(a¬≤b) = 2r`
    - `v_p(ac¬≤) = r + 2t`
    - `v_p(b¬≤c) = t`
    Since `t < r`, `t` is the unique minimum valuation. Thus, `v_p(LHS) = t`.
    The valuation of the RHS is `v_p(l(abc)) ‚â• r+t`.
    This leads to `t ‚â• r+t`, which means `r ‚â§ 0`, a contradiction.

Both subcases in Case 2 also lead to a contradiction.

Since our initial assumption‚Äîthat `|a|`, `|b|`, and `|c|` are not all equal‚Äîleads to a contradiction in every possible scenario, the assumption must be false. Therefore, we must have `|a| = |b| = |c|`.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/-$3 \cdot 89$ integers $a, b, c$ such that
$$
\frac{a}{b}+\frac{b}{c}+\frac{c}{a} \text { and } \frac{a}{c}+\frac{c}{b}+\frac{b}{a}
$$

are both integers, prove: $|a|=|b|=|c|$.-/
theorem number_theory_217451 (a b c : ‚Ñ§) (ane : a ‚â† 0) (bne : b ‚â† 0) (cne : c ‚â† 0)
    (h1 : ‚àÉ k : ‚Ñ§, (a : ‚Ñö) / b + b / c + c / a = k)
    (h2 : ‚àÉ l : ‚Ñ§, (a : ‚Ñö) / c + c / b + b / a = l) : |a| = |b| ‚àß |b| = |c| := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

/-$3 \cdot 89$ integers $a, b, c$ such that
$$
\frac{a}{b}+\frac{b}{c}+\frac{c}{a} \text { and } \frac{a}{c}+\frac{c}{b}+\frac{b}{a}
$$

are both integers, prove: $|a|=|b|=|c|$.-/
theorem number_theory_217451 (a b c : ‚Ñ§) (ane : a ‚â† 0) (bne : b ‚â† 0) (cne : c ‚â† 0)
    (h1 : ‚àÉ k : ‚Ñ§, (a : ‚Ñö) / b + b / c + c / a = k)
    (h2 : ‚àÉ l : ‚Ñ§, (a : ‚Ñö) / c + c / b + b / a = l) : |a| = |b| ‚àß |b| = |c| := by
-- Assume w. l. o. g. that $a.natAbs ‚â• b.natAbs ‚â• c.natAbs$
  wlog cleb : c.natAbs ‚â§ b.natAbs
  ¬∑ specialize this a c b ane cne bne h2 h1 (by omega)
    omega
  wlog clea : c.natAbs ‚â§ a.natAbs
  ¬∑ rw [add_comm, ‚Üê add_assoc] at h1
    rw [add_assoc, add_comm] at h2
    specialize this c b a cne bne ane h2 h1 (by omega) (by omega)
    omega
  wlog blea : b.natAbs ‚â§ a.natAbs
  ¬∑ rw [add_assoc, add_comm] at h1
    rw [add_comm, ‚Üê add_assoc] at h2
    specialize this b a c bne ane cne h2 h1 (by omega) (by omega) (by omega)
    omega
-- Assume w. l. o. g. that the gcd of $a$, $b$ and $c$ is $1$
  wlog h : (a.natAbs.gcd b.natAbs).gcd c.natAbs = 1
  -- Let $d$ be the gcd of $a$, $b$ and $c$ and prove $d‚â†0$
  ¬∑ set d := (a.natAbs.gcd b.natAbs).gcd c.natAbs
    have dne : d ‚â† 0 := by
      simp [d, Nat.gcd_eq_zero_iff]
      intro; contradiction
    have dvd1 : d ‚à£ a.natAbs := by calc
      _ ‚à£ a.natAbs.gcd b.natAbs := Nat.gcd_dvd_left (a.natAbs.gcd b.natAbs) c.natAbs
      _ ‚à£ _ := Nat.gcd_dvd_left a.natAbs b.natAbs
    have dvd2 : d ‚à£ b.natAbs := by calc
      _ ‚à£ a.natAbs.gcd b.natAbs := Nat.gcd_dvd_left (a.natAbs.gcd b.natAbs) c.natAbs
      _ ‚à£ _ := Nat.gcd_dvd_right a.natAbs b.natAbs
    have dvd3 : d ‚à£ c.natAbs := Nat.gcd_dvd_right (a.natAbs.gcd b.natAbs) c.natAbs
  -- Let $a'=a/d$, $b'=b/d$ and $c'=c/d$
    let a' := a / d; let b' := b / d; let c' := c / d
    have ha' : a = a' * d := by
      dsimp [a', d]; rw [Int.ediv_mul_cancel]
      rw [‚Üê Int.natAbs_dvd_natAbs]; norm_cast
    have hb' : b = b' * d := by
      dsimp [b', d]; rw [Int.ediv_mul_cancel]
      rw [‚Üê Int.natAbs_dvd_natAbs]; norm_cast
    have hc' : c = c' * d := by
      dsimp [c', d]; rw [Int.ediv_mul_cancel]
      rw [‚Üê Int.natAbs_dvd_natAbs]; norm_cast
    have a'ne : a' ‚â† 0 := by
      simp [a']; rw [Int.ediv_eq_iff_eq_mul_left, zero_mul]
      exact ane; norm_cast
      rw [‚Üê Int.natAbs_dvd_natAbs]; norm_cast
    have b'ne : b' ‚â† 0 := by
      simp [b']; rw [Int.ediv_eq_iff_eq_mul_left, zero_mul]
      exact bne; norm_cast
      rw [‚Üê Int.natAbs_dvd_natAbs]; norm_cast
    have c'ne : c' ‚â† 0 := by
      simp [c']; rw [Int.ediv_eq_iff_eq_mul_left, zero_mul]
      exact cne; norm_cast
      rw [‚Üê Int.natAbs_dvd_natAbs]; norm_cast
    rw [ha', hb', hc']; repeat rw [abs_mul]
    repeat rw [mul_right_cancel_iff_of_pos]
  -- Apply the result to $a'$, $b'$ and $c'$
    apply this a' b' c'; any_goals assumption
    ¬∑ rcases h1 with ‚ü®k, hk‚ü©; use k
      rw [‚Üê hk, ha', hb', hc']; push_cast
      repeat rw [mul_div_mul_right]
      all_goals norm_cast
    ¬∑ rcases h2 with ‚ü®k, hk‚ü©; use k
      rw [‚Üê hk, ha', hb', hc']; push_cast
      repeat rw [mul_div_mul_right]
      all_goals norm_cast
    ¬∑ repeat rw [Int.natAbs_ediv, Int.natAbs_ofNat]
      apply Nat.div_le_div_right; assumption
      all_goals rw [‚Üê Int.natAbs_dvd_natAbs, Int.natAbs_ofNat]; assumption
    ¬∑ repeat rw [Int.natAbs_ediv, Int.natAbs_ofNat]
      apply Nat.div_le_div_right; assumption
      all_goals rw [‚Üê Int.natAbs_dvd_natAbs, Int.natAbs_ofNat]; assumption
    ¬∑ repeat rw [Int.natAbs_ediv, Int.natAbs_ofNat]
      apply Nat.div_le_div_right; assumption
      all_goals rw [‚Üê Int.natAbs_dvd_natAbs, Int.natAbs_ofNat]; assumption
    ¬∑ dsimp [a', b', c']; repeat rw [Int.natAbs_ediv, Int.natAbs_ofNat]
      rw [Nat.gcd_div, Nat.gcd_div, Nat.div_eq_iff_eq_mul_left, one_mul]
      dsimp [d]; apply Nat.gcd_pos_of_pos_right
      by_contra!; simp at this; contradiction
      rfl; exact Nat.gcd_dvd_left (a.natAbs.gcd b.natAbs) c.natAbs
      any_goals assumption
      all_goals rw [‚Üê Int.natAbs_dvd_natAbs, Int.natAbs_ofNat]; assumption
    all_goals positivity
-- To prove the main goal, we proceed by contradiction
  repeat rw [Int.abs_eq_natAbs]
  norm_cast; by_contra! h'
-- Extend `h1` and `h2` to get two integers $k$ and $l$
  rcases h1 with ‚ü®k, hk‚ü©; rcases h2 with ‚ü®l, hl‚ü©
-- Prove that $a* b * c * k$ and $a * b * c *l$ has the folowing expressions
  have aux : a * b * c * k = a ^ 2 * c + a * b ^ 2 + b * c ^ 2 := by
    qify; rw [‚Üê hk]; field_simp; ring
  have aux' : a * b * c * l = a ^ 2 * b + a * c ^ 2 + b ^ 2 * c := by
    qify; rw [‚Üê hl]; field_simp; ring
-- Prove that $|a|$ is greater than $1$
  have agt : 1 < a.natAbs := by
    by_cases h'' : a.natAbs = b.natAbs
    ¬∑ specialize h' h''; omega
    omega
-- Let $p$ be any prime divisor of $|a|$ and prove that $p$ divides $b$ or $c$
  obtain ‚ü®p, ppr, pdvd‚ü© := Nat.exists_prime_and_dvd (show a.natAbs‚â†1 by omega)
  have : Fact (p.Prime) := ‚ü®ppr‚ü©
  have dvd1 : (p : ‚Ñ§) ‚à£ a ^ 2 * c + a * b ^ 2 + b * c ^ 2 := by
    rw [‚Üê aux]; repeat apply dvd_mul_of_dvd_left
    rw [‚Üê Int.natAbs_dvd_natAbs, Int.natAbs_ofNat]
    exact pdvd
  have : p ‚à£ b.natAbs ‚à® p ‚à£ c.natAbs := by
    rw [dvd_add_right, ‚Üê Int.natAbs_dvd_natAbs, Int.natAbs_ofNat] at dvd1
    rw [Int.natAbs_mul, Int.natAbs_pow, ppr.dvd_mul] at dvd1
    rcases dvd1 with dvd1|dvd1
    ¬∑ left; exact dvd1
    right; apply ppr.dvd_of_dvd_pow at dvd1; exact dvd1
    apply dvd_add; apply dvd_mul_of_dvd_left
    apply dvd_pow; rw [‚Üê Int.natAbs_dvd_natAbs, Int.natAbs_ofNat]
    exact pdvd; simp
    apply dvd_mul_of_dvd_left
    rw [‚Üê Int.natAbs_dvd_natAbs, Int.natAbs_ofNat]
    exact pdvd
  rcases this with pdb|pdc
  -- If $p$ divides $b$, then $p$ does not divide $c$
  ¬∑ have ndvd : ¬¨ p ‚à£ c.natAbs := by
      intro hdvd; suffices : p ‚à£ 1
      ¬∑ simp at this; norm_num [this] at ppr
      rw [‚Üê h, Nat.dvd_gcd_iff, Nat.dvd_gcd_iff]; split_ands
      all_goals assumption
    rw [dvd_iff_padicValNat_ne_zero] at ndvd pdvd; push_neg at ndvd
    rcases le_or_lt (padicValNat p a.natAbs) (padicValNat p b.natAbs) with pvle|pvlt
    -- If the highest power of $p$ divides $a$ is at most the highest power of $p$ divides $b$
    ¬∑ have : (p : ‚Ñ§) ^ padicValNat p a.natAbs * (p : ‚Ñ§) ^ padicValNat p b.natAbs ‚à£ a * b * c * l := by
        apply dvd_mul_of_dvd_left; apply dvd_mul_of_dvd_left
        apply mul_dvd_mul; all_goals rw [‚Üê Int.natAbs_dvd_natAbs]
        all_goals rw [Int.natAbs_pow, Int.natAbs_ofNat]
        all_goals exact pow_padicValNat_dvd
      rw [aux', dvd_add_left, dvd_add_right] at this
      rw [‚Üê pow_add, ‚Üê Int.natAbs_dvd_natAbs] at this
      rw [Int.natAbs_pow, Int.natAbs_ofNat] at this
      rw [padicValNat_dvd_iff_le, Int.natAbs_mul, Int.natAbs_pow] at this
    -- Derive a contradiction from division relations
      rw [padicValNat.mul, padicValNat.pow] at this
      any_goals omega
      any_goals simp; omega
      apply mul_dvd_mul; apply dvd_pow
      any_goals rw [‚Üê Int.natAbs_dvd_natAbs,Int.natAbs_pow, Int.natAbs_ofNat]
      any_goals exact pow_padicValNat_dvd
      simp; rw [‚Üê pow_add, ‚Üê Int.natAbs_dvd_natAbs]
      rw [Int.natAbs_pow, Int.natAbs_ofNat]
      rw [padicValNat_dvd_iff_le, Int.natAbs_mul, Int.natAbs_pow]
      rw [padicValNat.mul, padicValNat.pow]; omega
      any_goals simp; omega
    -- If the highest power of $p$ divides $b$ is less than the highest power of $p$ divides $b$
    have : (p : ‚Ñ§) ^ padicValNat p a.natAbs * (p : ‚Ñ§) ^ padicValNat p b.natAbs ‚à£ a * b * c * k := by
      apply dvd_mul_of_dvd_left; apply dvd_mul_of_dvd_left
      apply mul_dvd_mul; all_goals rw [‚Üê Int.natAbs_dvd_natAbs]
      all_goals rw [Int.natAbs_pow, Int.natAbs_ofNat]
      all_goals exact pow_padicValNat_dvd
    rw [aux, dvd_add_right] at this
    rw [‚Üê pow_add, ‚Üê Int.natAbs_dvd_natAbs] at this
    rw [Int.natAbs_pow, Int.natAbs_ofNat] at this
    rw [padicValNat_dvd_iff_le, Int.natAbs_mul, Int.natAbs_pow] at this
  -- Derive a contradiction from division relations
    rw [padicValNat.mul, padicValNat.pow] at this
    any_goals omega
    any_goals simp; omega
    apply dvd_add; rw [‚Üê pow_add, ‚Üê Int.natAbs_dvd_natAbs]
    rw [Int.natAbs_pow, Int.natAbs_ofNat]
    rw [padicValNat_dvd_iff_le, Int.natAbs_mul, Int.natAbs_pow]
    rw [padicValNat.mul, padicValNat.pow]; omega
    any_goals simp; omega
    apply mul_dvd_mul; any_goals apply dvd_pow
    any_goals rw [‚Üê Int.natAbs_dvd_natAbs,Int.natAbs_pow, Int.natAbs_ofNat]
    any_goals exact pow_padicValNat_dvd
    simp
-- The case when $p$ divides $c$ is similar to the previous case when $p$ divides $b$
  sorry

soln_description:
6.252 .

Notice that, $S_{m}=\frac{m(m+1)(m+2)}{6}$.
Thus $S_{m} \equiv 2(\bmod 4)$
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\Leftrightarrow m(m+1)(m+2) \equiv 4(\bmod 8) \\
\Leftrightarrow m \equiv 3(\bmod 8) .
\end{array}
$$

Therefore, among $S_{1}, S_{2}, \cdots, S_{2017}$, the numbers that are divisible by 2 but not by 4 are $\left[\frac{2017}{8}\right]=252$ in total.
informal_statement:
6. Let $a_{n}=1+2+\cdots+n\left(n \in \mathbf{Z}_{+}\right)$,
$$
S_{m}=a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{m}(m=1,2, \cdots) \text {. }
$$

Then among $S_{1}, S_{2}, \cdots, S_{2017}$, the numbers that are divisible by 2 but not by 4 are $\qquad$ in number.
informal_proof:
Let $a_n = \sum_{i=1}^{n} i$ and $S_m = \sum_{i=1}^{m} a_i$. We want to find the number of integers $i$ in the range $1 \le i \le 2017$ such that $S_i$ is divisible by 2 but not by 4. This condition is equivalent to $S_i \equiv 2 \pmod{4}$.

First, we establish closed-form expressions for $a_n$ and $S_m$.

**Lemma 1:** For any natural number $n$, $2 a_n = n(n+1)$.
**Proof:** We proceed by induction on $n$.
-   **Base case ($n=0$):** $a_0 = \sum_{i=1}^{0} i = 0$. So $2 a_0 = 0$. Also, $0(0+1) = 0$. The statement holds.
-   **Inductive step:** Assume $2 a_k = k(k+1)$ for some $k \ge 0$. We want to show $2 a_{k+1} = (k+1)(k+2)$.
    By definition, $a_{k+1} = a_k + (k+1)$.
    Then, $2 a_{k+1} = 2(a_k + k+1) = 2 a_k + 2(k+1)$.
    Using the induction hypothesis, we have $2 a_{k+1} = k(k+1) + 2(k+1) = (k+2)(k+1)$.
    This completes the induction.

**Lemma 2:** For any natural number $n$, $6 S_n = n(n+1)(n+2)$.
**Proof:** We proceed by induction on $n$.
-   **Base case ($n=0$):** $S_0 = \sum_{i=1}^{0} a_i = 0$. So $6 S_0 = 0$. Also, $0(0+1)(0+2) = 0$. The statement holds.
-   **Inductive step:** Assume $6 S_k = k(k+1)(k+2)$ for some $k \ge 0$. We want to show $6 S_{k+1} = (k+1)(k+2)(k+3)$.
    By definition, $S_{k+1} = S_k + a_{k+1}$.
    Then, $6 S_{k+1} = 6 S_k + 6 a_{k+1} = 6 S_k + 3(2 a_{k+1})$.
    Using the induction hypothesis and Lemma 1, we get:
    $6 S_{k+1} = k(k+1)(k+2) + 3((k+1)(k+2)) = (k+1)(k+2)(k+3)$.
    This completes the induction.

Now, we characterize the condition $S_n \equiv 2 \pmod{4}$. We will show this is equivalent to $n \equiv 3 \pmod{8}$.

**Proposition:** For any natural number $n$, $S_n \equiv 2 \pmod{4}$ if and only if $n \equiv 3 \pmod{8}$.
**Proof:**
First, we show that $S_n \equiv 2 \pmod{4}$ is equivalent to $6 S_n \equiv 12 \pmod{24}$.
-   (‚áí) Assume $S_n \equiv 2 \pmod{4}$. Then $S_n = 4k+2$ for some integer $k$. Multiplying by 6 gives $6S_n = 24k+12$, which implies $6S_n \equiv 12 \pmod{24}$.
-   (‚áê) Assume $6S_n \equiv 12 \pmod{24}$. Then $6S_n - 12$ is divisible by 24. So $6(S_n - 2) = 24k$ for some integer $k$. Dividing by 6, we get $S_n - 2 = 4k$, which means $S_n \equiv 2 \pmod{4}$.

Next, using Lemma 2, the condition becomes $n(n+1)(n+2) \equiv 12 \pmod{24}$. We show this is equivalent to $n \equiv 3 \pmod{8}$.
-   (‚áí) Assume $n \equiv 3 \pmod{8}$. We must show $n(n+1)(n+2) \equiv 12 \pmod{24}$. This requires checking the congruence modulo 3 and modulo 8.
    -   Modulo 3: The product of any three consecutive integers is divisible by 3. So, $n(n+1)(n+2) \equiv 0 \pmod{3}$. Also, $12 \equiv 0 \pmod{3}$.
    -   Modulo 8: If $n \equiv 3 \pmod{8}$, then $n+1 \equiv 4 \pmod{8}$ and $n+2 \equiv 5 \pmod{8}$. Thus, $n(n+1)(n+2) \equiv 3 \cdot 4 \cdot 5 = 60 \equiv 4 \pmod{8}$. Also, $12 \equiv 4 \pmod{8}$.
    Since the congruences hold for coprime moduli 3 and 8, by the Chinese Remainder Theorem, the congruence holds for modulus $3 \times 8 = 24$.

-   (‚áê) Assume $n(n+1)(n+2) \equiv 12 \pmod{24}$. This implies $n(n+1)(n+2) \equiv 12 \equiv 4 \pmod{8}$. We check the value of $P(n)=n(n+1)(n+2)$ for each possible residue of $n$ modulo 8:
    -   $n \equiv 0: P(0) \equiv 0 \cdot 1 \cdot 2 = 0 \pmod{8}$
    -   $n \equiv 1: P(1) \equiv 1 \cdot 2 \cdot 3 = 6 \pmod{8}$
    -   $n \equiv 2: P(2) \equiv 2 \cdot 3 \cdot 4 = 24 \equiv 0 \pmod{8}$
    -   $n \equiv 3: P(3) \equiv 3 \cdot 4 \cdot 5 = 60 \equiv 4 \pmod{8}$
    -   $n \equiv 4: P(4) \equiv 4 \cdot 5 \cdot 6 = 120 \equiv 0 \pmod{8}$
    -   $n \equiv 5: P(5) \equiv 5 \cdot 6 \cdot 7 = 210 = 208+2 \equiv 2 \pmod{8}$
    -   $n \equiv 6: P(6) \equiv 6 \cdot 7 \cdot 8 \equiv 0 \pmod{8}$
    -   $n \equiv 7: P(7) \equiv 7 \cdot 8 \cdot 9 \equiv 0 \pmod{8}$
    The only case yielding a residue of 4 is $n \equiv 3 \pmod{8}$.

Thus, the condition $S_i \equiv 2 \pmod{4}$ is equivalent to $i \equiv 3 \pmod{8}$.

We need to count the number of integers $i$ such that $1 \le i \le 2017$ and $i \equiv 3 \pmod{8}$. These integers are of the form $i = 8k+3$ for some non-negative integer $k$. We find the range for $k$:
-   $1 \le 8k+3 \implies -2 \le 8k \implies -1/4 \le k$. Since $k$ is an integer, $k \ge 0$.
-   $8k+3 \le 2017 \implies 8k \le 2014 \implies k \le 2014/8 = 251.75$. Since $k$ is an integer, $k \le 251$.

So, the possible values for $k$ are $0, 1, 2, \dots, 251$. The number of such values is $251 - 0 + 1 = 252$. Each value of $k$ corresponds to a unique value of $i$. Therefore, there are 252 such numbers.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Finset

def a (n : ‚Ñï) := ‚àë i in Finset.Icc 1 n, i

def S (m : ‚Ñï) := ‚àë i in Finset.Icc 1 m, a i

theorem number_theory_211318 :
    {i | 1 ‚â§ i ‚àß i ‚â§ 2017 ‚àß 2 ‚à£ S i ‚àß ¬¨4 ‚à£ S i}.ncard = 252 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

open Finset

def a (n : ‚Ñï) := ‚àë i in Finset.Icc 1 n, i

def S (m : ‚Ñï) := ‚àë i in Finset.Icc 1 m, a i

theorem number_theory_211318 :
    {i | 1 ‚â§ i ‚àß i ‚â§ 2017 ‚àß 2 ‚à£ S i ‚àß ¬¨4 ‚à£ S i}.ncard = 252 := by 
  -- use induction to prove following two statement.
  have aneq (n : ‚Ñï) : 2 * a n = n * (n + 1) := by 
    induction n with
    | zero => 
      unfold a 
      simp
    | succ k ih => 
      have aux : a (k + 1) = a k + (k + 1) := by 
        unfold a
        refine sum_Icc_succ_top ?_ fun k => k
        linarith
      rw [aux]
      calc 
        _ = 2 * a k + (k + 1) * 2:= by ring
        _ = _ := by 
          rw [ih]
          ring
  have sneq (n : ‚Ñï) : 6 * S n = n * (n + 1) * (n + 2) := by 
    induction n with
    | zero => 
      simp
      unfold S
      simp
    | succ k ih => 
      have eq1 : S (k + 1) = S k + a (k + 1) := by 
        unfold S
        refine sum_Icc_succ_top ?_ a
        linarith
      rw [eq1]
      calc 
        _ = 6 * S k + 3 * (2 * a (k + 1)) := by 
          ring
        _ = _ := by 
          rw [ih, aneq ]
          ring
  let f : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñï := fun x => 8 * x + 3 
  have set_eq : {i | 1 ‚â§ i ‚àß i ‚â§ 2017 ‚àß 2 ‚à£ S i ‚àß ¬¨4 ‚à£ S i} = 
    Finset.image f (range 252) := by 
    -- by above we already prove that S n = 1/6*(n*(n+1)*(n+2))
    have aux2 (n : ‚Ñï): S n ‚â° 2 [MOD 4] ‚Üî n ‚â° 3 [MOD 8] := by
      have aux3 (m : ‚Ñï): S m ‚â° 2 [MOD 4] ‚Üî 6 * S m ‚â° 12 [MOD 24] := by 
        constructor
        intro h
        obtain h1 := Nat.modEq_iff_dvd.mp h
        apply Nat.modEq_iff_dvd.mpr
        omega
        intro h
        obtain h1 := Nat.ModEq.dvd h
        apply Nat.modEq_iff_dvd.mpr
        omega
      have aux4 (m : ‚Ñï): m ‚â° 3 [MOD 8] ‚Üî 6 * S m ‚â° 12 [MOD 24] := by
        constructor
        intro h
        rw [sneq]
        have aux : m * (m + 1) * (m + 2) ‚â° 4 [MOD 8] := by 
          calc 
            _ ‚â° m * ((m + 1) * (m + 2)) [MOD 8] := by 
              ring_nf
              congr
            _ ‚â° 3 * ((m + 1) * (m + 2)) [MOD 8] := by 
              exact Nat.ModEq.mul h rfl
            _ ‚â° 3 * (4 * (m + 2)) [MOD 8] := by 
              have modeq1 : (m + 1) * (m + 2) 
                ‚â° 4 * (m + 2) [MOD 8] := by 
                have modeq2 : m + 1 ‚â° 4 [MOD 8] := by 
                  obtain h1 := Nat.ModEq.dvd h
                  apply Nat.modEq_iff_dvd.mpr
                  omega
                exact Nat.ModEq.mul modeq2 rfl
              exact Nat.ModEq.mul rfl modeq1
            _ ‚â° 3 * (4 * 5) [MOD 8] := by 
              have modeq1 : m + 2 ‚â° 5 [MOD 8] := by
                obtain h1 := Nat.ModEq.dvd h
                apply Nat.modEq_iff_dvd.mpr
                omega
              have modeq2 : (4 * (m + 2)) ‚â° (4 * 5) [MOD 8] := by 
                exact Nat.ModEq.mul rfl modeq1
              exact Nat.ModEq.mul rfl modeq2
            _ ‚â° 4 [MOD 8] := by 
              apply Nat.modEq_iff_dvd.mpr
              omega
        have aux4 : m * (m + 1) * (m + 2) ‚â° 4 * 3 [MOD 8 * 3] := by 
          have aux5 : (m * (m + 1) * (m + 2)) * 3 ‚â° 4 * 3 [MOD 8 * 3] := by 
            exact Nat.ModEq.mul_right' 3 aux
          have aux6 : (m * (m + 1) * (m + 2))
            ‚â° (m * (m + 1) * (m + 2)) * 3[MOD 8 * 3] := by 
            apply Nat.modEq_iff_dvd.mpr
            have aux7 :  ‚Üë(m * (m + 1) * (m + 2) * 3) - ‚Üë(m * (m + 1) * (m + 2)) = (2 : ‚Ñ§) * ‚Üë(m * (m + 1) * (m + 2)) := by 
              norm_num
              ring
            rw [aux7]
            norm_cast
            have dvd1 : 8 ‚à£ 2 * (m * (m + 1) * (m + 2)) := by 
              have eq1 : 2 * (m * (m + 1) * (m + 2)) = 
                (2 * (m + 1)) * (m * (m + 2)) := by 
                ring
              have dvdaux : 8 ‚à£ (2 * (m + 1)) := by
                zify
                obtain h1 := Nat.ModEq.dvd h
                obtain ‚ü®k, hk‚ü© := h1
                have meq : (m : ‚Ñ§) = 3 - (8 : ‚Ñï)* k := by 
                  rw [‚Üêhk]
                  norm_num
                rw [meq]
                omega
              rw [eq1]
              exact Dvd.dvd.mul_right dvdaux _
            have dvd2 : 3 ‚à£ 2 * (m * (m + 1) * (m + 2)) := by 
              by_cases hm : m % 3 = 0 
              have dvd1 : 3 ‚à£ m := by 
                omega
              have eq1 : 2 * (m * (m + 1) * (m + 2)) = 
                m * (2 * (m + 1) * (m + 2)) := by 
                ring
              rw [eq1]
              exact Dvd.dvd.mul_right dvd1 _
              by_cases hm : m % 3 = 1
              have dvd2 : 3 ‚à£ m + 2 := by 
                omega
              have eq2 : 2 * (m * (m + 1) * (m + 2)) =
                (m + 2) * (2 * (m * (m + 1))) := by
                ring
              rw [eq2]
              exact Dvd.dvd.mul_right dvd2 _
              have hm' : m % 3 = 2 := by omega
              have dvd3 : 3 ‚à£ m + 1 := by omega
              have eq3 : 2 * (m * (m + 1) * (m + 2)) =
                (m + 1) * (2 * (m * (m + 2))) := by
                ring
              rw [eq3]
              exact Dvd.dvd.mul_right dvd3 _
            exact Nat.Coprime.mul_dvd_of_dvd_of_dvd rfl dvd1 dvd2
          calc 
            _ ‚â° m * (m + 1) * (m + 2) * 3 [MOD 8 * 3] := by 
              exact aux6
            _ ‚â° 4 * 3 [MOD 8 * 3] := by
              exact aux5
        norm_num at aux4
        exact aux4
        -- 6 * S m ‚â° 12 [MOD 24] ‚Üí m ‚â° 3 [MOD 8]
        intro h
        rw [sneq] at h
        -- discuss by_cases the residue of m modulo 8 can only be 3
        -- skip the discussion

        sorry    
      refine iff_iff_implies_and_implies.mpr ?_
      constructor
      intro h
      apply (aux4 n).mpr
      exact (aux3 n).mp h
      intro h
      apply (aux3 n).mpr
      exact (aux4 n).mp h
    refine Eq.symm (Set.ext ?_)
    -- prove the two set are equivalence
    -- namely, {i | 1 ‚â§ i ‚àß i ‚â§ 2017 ‚àß 2 ‚à£ S i ‚àß ¬¨4 ‚à£ S i} = ‚Üë(image f (range 252))
    intro x
    constructor
    intro hx
    simp at hx
    obtain ‚ü®k, hk, hkeq‚ü© := hx
    unfold f at hkeq
    simp
    constructor
    linarith
    constructor
    linarith
    have xmod : x ‚â° 3 [MOD 8] := by 
      apply Nat.modEq_iff_dvd.mpr
      rw [‚Üêhkeq]
      omega
    obtain h1 := (aux2 x).mpr xmod
    rw [Nat.modEq_iff_dvd] at h1
    constructor
    omega
    omega
    -- the other direction
    intro hx
    simp at hx
    obtain ‚ü®k, hk, h1, h2‚ü© := hx
    simp
    have xmod : x ‚â° 3 [MOD 8] := by
      apply (aux2 x).mp
      rw [Nat.modEq_iff_dvd]
      omega
    obtain xmod1 := Nat.ModEq.symm xmod
    obtain h3 := Nat.ModEq.dvd xmod1
    obtain ‚ü®t, ht‚ü© := h3
    have xeq : (x : ‚Ñ§) = (8 : ‚Ñï) * t + 3 := by 
      rw [‚Üê ht]
      norm_num
    norm_cast at xeq
    have aux : ‚àÉ (s : ‚Ñï), t = ‚Üës := by 
      have tge : t ‚â• 0 := by 
        linarith
      exact Int.eq_ofNat_of_zero_le tge
    obtain ‚ü®s, hs‚ü© := aux
    use s
    constructor
    linarith
    unfold f
    zify
    rw [‚Üêhs]
    exact Eq.symm xeq
  rw [set_eq]
  have eq_aux : (image f (range 252) : Set ‚Ñï).ncard = 
    (range 252 : Set ‚Ñï).ncard := by
    simp
    refine Set.ncard_image_of_injective (Set.Iio 252) ?_
    unfold f
    refine injective_of_le_imp_le (fun k => 8 * k + 3) ?_
    intro x y hxy
    simp at hxy
    exact hxy
  rw [eq_aux]
  have eq_aux' : (‚Üë(range 252) : Set ‚Ñï).ncard
    = (range 252).card := by 
    sorry
  rw [eq_aux']
  simp

informal_statement:
For a nonnegative integer $n$, let $s(n)$ be the sum of digits of the binary representation of $n$. Prove that

$$
\sum_{n=0}^{2^{2022}-1} \frac{(-1)^{s(n)}}{2022+n}>0
$$
informal_proof:
Let $s(n)$ be the sum of the digits in the binary representation of a non-negative integer $n$. We want to prove that
$$ \sum_{n=0}^{2^{2022}-1} \frac{(-1)^{s(n)}}{2022+n} > 0 $$

To do this, we generalize the problem by defining a sequence of functions $f_k : (0, \infty) \to \mathbb{R}$ for integers $k \ge 0$:
$$ f_k(x) = \sum_{n=0}^{2^k-1} \frac{(-1)^{s(n)}}{x+n} $$
The expression we want to evaluate is $f_{2022}(2022)$.

First, we establish a recurrence relation for these functions. For any $k \ge 0$ and $x>0$:
\begin{align*} f_{k+1}(x) &= \sum_{n=0}^{2^{k+1}-1} \frac{(-1)^{s(n)}}{x+n} \\ &= \sum_{n=0}^{2^k-1} \frac{(-1)^{s(n)}}{x+n} + \sum_{n=2^k}^{2^{k+1}-1} \frac{(-1)^{s(n)}}{x+n} \\ &= f_k(x) + \sum_{i=0}^{2^k-1} \frac{(-1)^{s(i+2^k)}}{x+i+2^k}\end{align*}
For an integer $i$ in the range $0 \le i < 2^k$, its binary representation has at most $k$ digits. The number $i+2^k$ is formed by setting the $k$-th bit (which corresponds to the value $2^k$) to 1. Thus, the binary representation of $i+2^k$ is the binary representation of $i$ (padded with leading zeros if necessary to length $k$) with an additional '1' in the $k$-th position. This means the sum of digits satisfies $s(i+2^k) = s(i) + 1$.

Consequently, $(-1)^{s(i+2^k)} = (-1)^{s(i)+1} = -(-1)^{s(i)}$. Substituting this into our sum:
$$ \sum_{i=0}^{2^k-1} \frac{-(-1)^{s(i)}}{x+2^k+i} = - \sum_{i=0}^{2^k-1} \frac{(-1)^{s(i)}}{(x+2^k)+i} = -f_k(x+2^k) $$
This gives us the recurrence relation for all $k \ge 0$ and $x > 0$:
$$ f_{k+1}(x) = f_k(x) - f_k(x+2^k) $$
Each function $f_k(x)$ is a finite sum of rational functions of the form $c/(x+n)$, which are infinitely differentiable for $x > 0$. Thus, each $f_k(x)$ is infinitely differentiable on $(0, \infty)$.

The core of our proof is the following claim, which we prove by induction on $k$:
**Claim:** For all integers $k \ge 0$ and $i \ge 0$, and for all $x > 0$, we have $(-1)^i f_k^{(i)}(x) > 0$, where $f_k^{(i)}(x)$ denotes the $i$-th derivative of $f_k(x)$.

**Base Case (k=0):**
For $k=0$, the sum has only one term ($n=0$):
$$ f_0(x) = \frac{(-1)^{s(0)}}{x+0} = \frac{(-1)^0}{x} = \frac{1}{x} $$
The $i$-th derivative of $f_0(x) = x^{-1}$ is $f_0^{(i)}(x) = (-1)^i i! x^{-i-1}$.
Therefore, for any $x > 0$,
$$ (-1)^i f_0^{(i)}(x) = (-1)^i (-1)^i i! x^{-i-1} = \frac{i!}{x^{i+1}} > 0 $$
The claim holds for $k=0$.

**Inductive Step:**
Assume the claim holds for some $k \ge 0$. We want to prove it for $k+1$.
We need to show that $(-1)^i f_{k+1}^{(i)}(x) > 0$ for all $i \ge 0$ and $x > 0$.
Using the recurrence relation and differentiating $i$ times, we get:
$$ f_{k+1}^{(i)}(x) = f_k^{(i)}(x) - f_k^{(i)}(x+2^k) $$
So we need to prove:
$$ (-1)^i \left( f_k^{(i)}(x) - f_k^{(i)}(x+2^k) \right) > 0 $$
This is equivalent to:
$$ (-1)^i f_k^{(i)}(x) > (-1)^i f_k^{(i)}(x+2^k) $$
Let's define a helper function $h(t) = (-1)^i f_k^{(i)}(t)$. The inequality becomes $h(x) > h(x+2^k)$. Since $x > 0$, we have $x+2^k > x$. This inequality would follow if we can show that $h(t)$ is a strictly decreasing function for $t > 0$.

To show that $h(t)$ is strictly decreasing, we examine its derivative:
$$ h'(t) = \frac{d}{dt} \left( (-1)^i f_k^{(i)}(t) \right) = (-1)^i f_k^{(i+1)}(t) $$
We can rewrite this as:
$$ h'(t) = - \left( (-1)^{i+1} f_k^{(i+1)}(t) \right) $$
By our induction hypothesis (for the integer $k$ and the derivative order $i+1$), we know that $(-1)^{i+1} f_k^{(i+1)}(t) > 0$ for all $t > 0$.
Therefore, $h'(t) < 0$ for all $t > 0$. Since $h(t)$ is differentiable on $(0, \infty)$ and its derivative is strictly negative, the function $h(t)$ is strictly decreasing on $(0, \infty)$.
This completes the inductive step.

Having proven the claim for all $k \ge 0$, we can now finalize our proof. We set $k=2022$, $i=0$, and $x=2022$. The condition $x > 0$ is satisfied.
According to our proven claim:
$$ (-1)^0 f_{2022}^{(0)}(2022) > 0 $$
Since $f^{(0)}(x) = f(x)$, this simplifies to:
$$ f_{2022}(2022) > 0 $$
By the definition of our function $f_k(x)$, this is precisely:
$$ \sum_{n=0}^{2^{2022}-1} \frac{(-1)^{s(n)}}{2022+n} > 0 $$
This completes the proof.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

theorem iteratedDeriv_sub_lm.{u_1, u_2} : ‚àÄ {ùïú : Type u_1} [inst : NontriviallyNormedField ùïú] {F : Type u_2}
  [inst_1 : NormedAddCommGroup F] [inst_2 : NormedSpace ùïú F] {n : ‚Ñï} {x : ùïú} {f g : ùïú ‚Üí F},
  ContDiffAt ùïú (‚Üën) f x ‚Üí
    ContDiffAt ùïú (‚Üën) g x ‚Üí iteratedDeriv n (f - g) x = iteratedDeriv n f x - iteratedDeriv n g x := sorry

theorem Finset.prod_neg.{u_1, u_3} : ‚àÄ {Œπ : Type u_1} {Œ± : Type u_3} {s : Finset Œπ} {f : Œπ ‚Üí Œ±} [inst : CommMonoid Œ±]
  [inst_1 : HasDistribNeg Œ±], ‚àè x ‚àà s, -f x = (-1) ^ s.card * ‚àè x ‚àà s, f x := sorry

open Finset

/-For a nonnegative integer $n$, let $s(n)$ be the sum of digits of the binary representation of $n$. Prove that

$$
\sum_{n=0}^{2^{2022}-1} \frac{(-1)^{s(n)}}{2022+n}>0
$$-/
theorem number_theory_610480 {s : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñï} (hs : ‚àÄ n, s n = (Nat.digits 2 n).sum) :
    0 < ‚àë n ‚àà range (2 ^ 2022), (-1 : ‚Ñù) ^ s n / (2022 + n) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem iteratedDeriv_sub_lm.{u_1, u_2} : ‚àÄ {ùïú : Type u_1} [inst : NontriviallyNormedField ùïú] {F : Type u_2}
  [inst_1 : NormedAddCommGroup F] [inst_2 : NormedSpace ùïú F] {n : ‚Ñï} {x : ùïú} {f g : ùïú ‚Üí F},
  ContDiffAt ùïú (‚Üën) f x ‚Üí
    ContDiffAt ùïú (‚Üën) g x ‚Üí iteratedDeriv n (f - g) x = iteratedDeriv n f x - iteratedDeriv n g x := sorry

theorem Finset.prod_neg.{u_1, u_3} : ‚àÄ {Œπ : Type u_1} {Œ± : Type u_3} {s : Finset Œπ} {f : Œπ ‚Üí Œ±} [inst : CommMonoid Œ±]
  [inst_1 : HasDistribNeg Œ±], ‚àè x ‚àà s, -f x = (-1) ^ s.card * ‚àè x ‚àà s, f x := sorry

open Finset

/-For a nonnegative integer $n$, let $s(n)$ be the sum of digits of the binary representation of $n$. Prove that

$$
\sum_{n=0}^{2^{2022}-1} \frac{(-1)^{s(n)}}{2022+n}>0
$$-/
theorem number_theory_610480 {s : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñï} (hs : ‚àÄ n, s n = (Nat.digits 2 n).sum) :
    0 < ‚àë n ‚àà range (2 ^ 2022), (-1 : ‚Ñù) ^ s n / (2022 + n) := by
-- Define a sequence of functions $f_k$ to be $‚àë n ‚àà range (2 ^ k), (-1 : ‚Ñù) ^ s n / (x + n)$
  let f : ‚Ñï ‚Üí (‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù) := fun k x => ‚àë n ‚àà range (2 ^ k), (-1 : ‚Ñù) ^ s n / (x + n)
-- Prove that $f$ has a recursion formula
  have fsucc : ‚àÄ k, ‚àÄ x, f (k + 1) x = f k x - f k (x + 2 ^ k) := by
    intro k x; calc
      _ = ‚àë n ‚àà range (2 ^ (k + 1)), (-1 : ‚Ñù) ^ s n / (x + n) := by dsimp [f]
      _ = _ := by
        rw [pow_succ, mul_two, sum_range_add, ‚Üê sub_neg_eq_add]
        congr; dsimp [f]
        rw [‚Üê sum_neg_distrib]; apply sum_congr rfl
        intro i hi; simp at hi; push_cast
        rw [‚Üê add_assoc, ‚Üê neg_div]; congr
        rw [neg_eq_neg_one_mul, ‚Üê pow_succ']
        rw [neg_one_pow_eq_pow_mod_two]
        nth_rw 2 [neg_one_pow_eq_pow_mod_two]
        have : (Nat.digits 2 i).length ‚â§ k := by
          by_cases h : i = 0; simp [h]
          rw [Nat.digits_len, Nat.add_one_le_iff]
          apply Nat.log_lt_of_lt_pow
          any_goals assumption
          simp
        rw [hs, show 2^k = 2^k*1 by simp]
        rw [show k = (Nat.digits 2 i).length+(k-(Nat.digits 2 i).length) by omega]
        nth_rw 2 [add_comm]; rw [‚Üê Nat.digits_append_zeroes_append_digits]
        simp [add_assoc, hs]
        all_goals simp
-- Prove that $f_k$ is smooth on $x>0$
  have fcontD : ‚àÄ k, ContDiffOn ‚Ñù (‚ä§ : ENat) (f k) (Set.Ioi 0) := by
    intro k; dsimp [f]; apply ContDiffOn.sum
    intros; apply ContDiffOn.div; exact contDiffOn_const
    apply ContDiffOn.add; exact contDiffOn_id'
    exact contDiffOn_const
    simp; intros; positivity
-- Prove the key result that $(-1)^i$ times the i-th derivative of $f_k$ is always positive for $x>0$
  have key : ‚àÄ k, ‚àÄ x > 0, ‚àÄ i, 0 < (-1) ^ i * iteratedDeriv i (f k) x := by
  -- We proceed by induction
    intro k; induction k with
    | zero =>
    -- Base step
      simp [f, hs, iteratedDeriv_eq_iterate]; intros
      simp only [‚Üê neg_add', prod_neg, card_range]
      rw [‚Üê mul_assoc, ‚Üê mul_assoc, ‚Üê pow_add, Even.neg_one_pow]
      positivity; simp [Nat.even_iff]
    | succ k ih =>
    -- Induction step
      intro x xpos i; rw [funext_iff.mpr (fsucc _)]
      have aux : Set.Ioi 0 ‚àà nhds x := by
        rw [mem_nhds_iff_exists_Ioo_subset]
        use x / 2, 2 * x; simp [Set.subset_def]; split_ands
        exact xpos; linarith only [xpos]
        intros; linarith
      have : (fun x => f k x - f k (x + 2 ^ k)) = f k - fun x => f k (x + 2 ^ k) := by
        ext; simp
      rw [this, iteratedDeriv_sub_lm, mul_sub, sub_pos]
      simp [iteratedDeriv_comp_add_const]
    -- It suffices to show the function $(-1)^i$ times the i-th derivative of $f_k$ is strictly decreasing when $0< x$
      suffices : StrictAntiOn (fun x => (-1) ^ i * iteratedDeriv i (f k) x) (Set.Ioi 0)
      ¬∑ apply this; simp; exact xpos
        simp; positivity
        rw [lt_add_iff_pos_right]; positivity
    -- Apply the induction hypothesis `ih` to show the derivative of the function in question is negative
      apply strictAntiOn_of_deriv_neg; apply convex_Ioi
      ¬∑ sorry
      ¬∑ intro x hx; simp at hx
        rw [deriv_const_mul, ‚Üê iteratedDeriv_succ]
        specialize ih x hx (i+1); rw [pow_succ] at ih
        linarith only [ih]; sorry
      ¬∑ specialize fcontD k; rw [contDiffOn_infty] at fcontD
        specialize fcontD i x (by simp; exact xpos)
        apply fcontD.contDiffAt aux
      specialize fcontD k; rw [contDiffOn_infty] at fcontD
      specialize fcontD i (x + 2 ^ k) (by simp; positivity)
      apply ContDiffWithinAt.contDiffAt _ aux
      have : (fun x => f k (x + 2 ^ k)) = (f k) ‚àò (fun x => x + 2 ^ k) := by
        ext; simp
      rw [this]
      replace this : Set.MapsTo (fun (x : ‚Ñù) => x + 2 ^ k) (Set.Ioi 0) (Set.Ioi 0):= by
        intro x; simp; intro; positivity
      apply ContDiffWithinAt.comp _ _ _ this; exact fcontD
      apply ContDiff.contDiffWithinAt; apply ContDiff.add
      exact contDiff_id'; exact contDiff_const
-- Specialize `key` to $k=2022$, $x=2022$ and $i=0$ to finish the goal
  specialize key 2022 2022 (by simp) 0
  simp only [pow_zero, iteratedDeriv_zero, one_mul, f] at key
  exact key

soln_description:
Scoring: 1 point is awarded for concluding that $r$ is not 2, and another 2 points for determining that $p=2$. 1 point is awarded for the case $q=2$, and 3 points for eliminating the case $q>2$.

A written solution of $(2,2,5)$ earns 1 point even if it is not justified.
informal_statement:
## Task A-2.3.

Determine all triples of prime numbers $(p, q, r)$ for which

$$
p^{q}=r-1
$$
informal_proof:
Let $p$, $q$, and $r$ be prime numbers satisfying the equation $p^q = r-1$. Since $p, q, r$ are primes, they must be greater than or equal to 2.

First, we will determine the parity of $r$. Suppose for the sake of contradiction that $r$ is an even prime. The only even prime is 2, so we must have $r=2$. Substituting this into the equation gives $p^q = 2-1 = 1$. However, since $p$ and $q$ are primes, $p \ge 2$ and $q \ge 2$, which implies $p^q \ge 2^2 = 4$. This contradicts $p^q=1$. Therefore, our assumption must be false, and $r$ must be an odd prime.

Since $r$ is odd, $r-1$ must be even. From the equation $p^q = r-1$, it follows that $p^q$ is even. For $p^q$ to be even, the base $p$ must be even. As $p$ is a prime number, the only possibility is $p=2$.

Now we consider the possible values for the prime $q$. We analyze two cases.

**Case 1: $q = 2$.**
Substituting $p=2$ and $q=2$ into the original equation, we get:
$2^2 = r-1$
$4 = r-1$
$r = 5$
Since 5 is a prime number, the triple $(p, q, r) = (2, 2, 5)$ is a valid solution.

**Case 2: $q \neq 2$.**
Since $q$ is a prime number and $q \neq 2$, $q$ must be an odd prime.
Our equation is now $2^q = r-1$, which can be rewritten as $r = 2^q + 1$. We will show that this case leads to a contradiction.

Consider the expression $2^q + 1$ modulo 3. We know that $2 \equiv -1 \pmod{3}$. Raising both sides to the power of $q$, we get:
$2^q \equiv (-1)^q \pmod{3}$
Since $q$ is an odd number, $(-1)^q = -1$. Therefore:
$2^q \equiv -1 \pmod{3}$
Adding 1 to both sides gives:
$2^q + 1 \equiv 0 \pmod{3}$
This shows that $2^q+1$ is divisible by 3. Since $r = 2^q + 1$, it follows that $r$ is divisible by 3. As $r$ is a prime number, the only prime divisible by 3 is 3 itself. Thus, we must have $r=3$.

Substituting $r=3$ back into the equation $r = 2^q+1$, we obtain:
$3 = 2^q + 1$
$2 = 2^q$
This implies that $q=1$. However, this contradicts our initial condition that $q$ is a prime number, as 1 is not prime. Therefore, the case where $q \neq 2$ is impossible.

Combining our findings, the only possible case is $q=2$, which gives the unique solution $(p, q, r) = (2, 2, 5)$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/-
## Task A-2.3.

Determine all triples of prime numbers $(p, q, r)$ for which

$$
p^{q}=r-1
$$
-/

theorem number_theory_215307 (p q r : ‚Ñï) (hp : p.Prime) (hq : q.Prime) (hr : r.Prime)  (h : p ^ q = r - 1) : p = 2 ‚àß q = 2 ‚àß r = 5 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

/-
## Task A-2.3.

Determine all triples of prime numbers $(p, q, r)$ for which

$$
p^{q}=r-1
$$
-/

theorem number_theory_215307 (p q r : ‚Ñï) (hp : p.Prime) (hq : q.Prime) (hr : r.Prime)  (h : p ^ q = r - 1) : p = 2 ‚àß q = 2 ‚àß r = 5 := by

  have pge2 : 2 ‚â§ p := Nat.Prime.two_le hp
  have qge2 : 2 ‚â§ q := Nat.Prime.two_le hq
  have rge2 : 2 ‚â§ r := Nat.Prime.two_le hr

  --By checking the parity, we have that r has to be odd and p has to be even, so p = 2.
  have oddr : Odd r := by 
    by_contra noddr
    have evenr : Even r := by exact Nat.not_odd_iff_even.mp noddr
    have re : r=2 := by exact (Nat.Prime.even_iff hr).mp evenr
    rw [re] at h;
    simp at h
    have : 4 ‚â§ p^q := by 
      have : p^2 ‚â§ p^q := by exact Nat.pow_le_pow_of_le pge2 qge2
      have : 2^2 ‚â§ p^2 := by exact Nat.pow_le_pow_of_le_left pge2 2
      linarith
    linarith
  have evenrm1 : Even (r-1) := by refine Nat.Odd.sub_odd oddr ?_; exact Nat.odd_iff.mpr rfl

  have pe : p = 2 := by
    have evenp : Even p := by 
      by_contra nevenp
      have oddp : Odd p := by exact Nat.not_even_iff_odd.mp nevenp
      have oddpq : Odd (p^q) := by exact Odd.pow oddp
      have : Odd (r-1) := by rw [‚Üêh]; exact oddpq
      have : ¬¨ Even (r-1) := by exact Nat.not_even_iff_odd.mpr this
      contradiction
    exact (Nat.Prime.even_iff hp).mp evenp
  
  --If q = 2, then we must have r = 5.
  by_cases qe : q = 2 
  simp [pe,qe] at h
  omega

  --For q > 2, then we will have 3 ‚à£ r, but then r = 3 and we have a contradiction.
  exfalso
  have eq' : p^q + 1 = r := by omega
  rw [pe] at eq'
  have oddq : Odd q := by exact Nat.Prime.odd_of_ne_two hq qe
  have d3 : 3 ‚à£ 2 ^ q + 1:= by 
    have : 2 ‚â° -1 [ZMOD 3] := by decide
    have con: 2^q ‚â° (-1)^q [ZMOD 3] := by exact Int.ModEq.pow q this
    have : (-1)^q = -1 := by exact Odd.neg_one_pow oddq
    rw [this] at con
    have : 2^q + 1 ‚â° (-1) + 1 [ZMOD 3] := by exact Int.ModEq.add con rfl
    simp at this
    refine Nat.dvd_of_mod_eq_zero ?_
    zify
    exact this
  rw [eq'] at d3
  have re: r = 3 := by 
    rw [Nat.prime_dvd_prime_iff_eq] at d3;
    symm
    exact d3
    norm_num
    exact hr
  rw [re] at eq'
  have qe : q = 1 := by 
    have: 2^q = 2 := by linarith
    rw [Nat.pow_eq_self_iff] at this
    exact this
    linarith
  rw [qe] at hq
  absurd hq; exact Nat.not_prime_one

informal_statement:
Suppose that $x, y$, and $z$ are complex numbers of equal magnitude that satisfy

$$
x+y+z=-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}-i \sqrt{5}
$$

and

$$
x y z=\sqrt{3}+i \sqrt{5} .
$$

If $x=x_{1}+i x_{2}, y=y_{1}+i y_{2}$, and $z=z_{1}+i z_{2}$ for real $x_{1}, x_{2}, y_{1}, y_{2}, z_{1}$, and $z_{2}$, then

$$
\left(x_{1} x_{2}+y_{1} y_{2}+z_{1} z_{2}\right)^{2}
$$

can be written as $\frac{a}{b}$ for relatively prime positive integers $a$ and $b$. Compute $100 a+b$.
informal_proof:
Let the three complex numbers be $x = x_1 + i x_2$, $y = y_1 + i y_2$, and $z = z_1 + i z_2$. We are given that they have a common magnitude, which we denote by $r$, so $|x| = |y| = |z| = r$. We are also given the two equations:
1. $x+y+z = -\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} - i \sqrt{5}$
2. $x y z = \sqrt{3} + i \sqrt{5}$

Our goal is to compute the value of $(x_1 x_2 + y_1 y_2 + z_1 z_2)^2$.

First, we establish that $x, y, z$ must be non-zero. If any of them were zero, their product $xyz$ would be zero. However, we are given $xyz = \sqrt{3} + i\sqrt{5} \neq 0$. Thus, $x, y, z$ are all non-zero.

Next, we determine the value of the common magnitude $r$. By taking the magnitude of both sides of the second equation, we get:
$|xyz| = |\sqrt{3} + i \sqrt{5}|$
$|x||y||z| = \sqrt{(\sqrt{3})^2 + (\sqrt{5})^2}$
$r \cdot r \cdot r = \sqrt{3+5} = \sqrt{8} = 2\sqrt{2}$
$r^3 = (\sqrt{2})^3$
Since $r$ is a non-negative real number, we conclude that $r = \sqrt{2}$.

For any complex number $w$, we have $|w|^2 = w \overline{w}$. Since $|x|^2 = r^2 = (\sqrt{2})^2 = 2$, it follows that $x \overline{x} = 2$. As $x \neq 0$, we can write $\overline{x} = \frac{2}{x}$. Similarly, $\overline{y} = \frac{2}{y}$ and $\overline{z} = \frac{2}{z}$.

Now, let's take the complex conjugate of the first given equation:
$\overline{x+y+z} = \overline{-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} - i \sqrt{5}}$
$\overline{x} + \overline{y} + \overline{z} = -\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} + i \sqrt{5}$
Substituting the expressions for the conjugates we found:
$\frac{2}{x} + \frac{2}{y} + \frac{2}{z} = -\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} + i \sqrt{5}$
To combine the terms on the left, we find a common denominator:
$\frac{2(yz + xz + xy)}{xyz} = -\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} + i \sqrt{5}$
We can now substitute the given value for $xyz$:
$\frac{2(xy+yz+zx)}{\sqrt{3} + i\sqrt{5}} = -\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} + i \sqrt{5}$
Solving for the symmetric polynomial $xy+yz+zx$:
$2(xy+yz+zx) = \left(-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} + i \sqrt{5}\right) (\sqrt{3} + i \sqrt{5})$
$2(xy+yz+zx) = -\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\sqrt{3} - \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} i\sqrt{5} + i\sqrt{5}\sqrt{3} + i^2(\sqrt{5})^2$
$2(xy+yz+zx) = -\frac{3}{2} + i\frac{\sqrt{15}}{2} - 5 = -\frac{13}{2} + i\frac{\sqrt{15}}{2}$
Therefore, $xy+yz+zx = -\frac{13}{4} + i\frac{\sqrt{15}}{4}$.

Let $Q = x_1 x_2 + y_1 y_2 + z_1 z_2$. For any complex number $w = w_1+iw_2$, we have $w^2 = (w_1^2 - w_2^2) + i(2w_1w_2)$, so $\operatorname{Im}(w^2) = 2w_1w_2$. Applying this, we see that:
$2Q = 2x_1x_2 + 2y_1y_2 + 2z_1z_2 = \operatorname{Im}(x^2) + \operatorname{Im}(y^2) + \operatorname{Im}(z^2) = \operatorname{Im}(x^2+y^2+z^2)$.

We can compute $x^2+y^2+z^2$ using the identity $x^2+y^2+z^2 = (x+y+z)^2 - 2(xy+yz+zx)$.
First, we compute $(x+y+z)^2$:
$(x+y+z)^2 = \left(-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} - i\sqrt{5}\right)^2 = \left(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right)^2 + 2\left(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right)(i\sqrt{5}) + (i\sqrt{5})^2$
$= \frac{3}{4} + i\sqrt{15} - 5 = -\frac{17}{4} + i\sqrt{15}$.

Now, substituting the known values:
$x^2+y^2+z^2 = \left(-\frac{17}{4} + i\sqrt{15}\right) - 2\left(-\frac{13}{4} + i\frac{\sqrt{15}}{4}\right)$
$x^2+y^2+z^2 = \left(-\frac{17}{4} + i\sqrt{15}\right) - \left(-\frac{13}{2} + i\frac{\sqrt{15}}{2}\right)$
$x^2+y^2+z^2 = \left(-\frac{17}{4} + \frac{26}{4}\right) + i\left(\sqrt{15} - \frac{\sqrt{15}}{2}\right) = \frac{9}{4} + i\frac{\sqrt{15}}{2}$.

Now we can find $Q$:
$2Q = \operatorname{Im}\left(\frac{9}{4} + i\frac{\sqrt{15}}{2}\right) = \frac{\sqrt{15}}{2}$
$Q = \frac{\sqrt{15}}{4}$.

The quantity we seek is $Q^2$:
$(x_1 x_2 + y_1 y_2 + z_1 z_2)^2 = Q^2 = \left(\frac{\sqrt{15}}{4}\right)^2 = \frac{15}{16}$.

This value can be written as $\frac{a}{b}$ where $a=15$ and $b=16$. These are positive and relatively prime integers. We compute the final required value:
$100a + b = 100(15) + 16 = 1500 + 16 = 1516$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib
